# Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH


## €250,000,000 % Senior Secured Notes due 2031

Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH, organized as a limited liability company (Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung) under German law (the “Issuer”), is
offering (the “Offering”) €250,000,000 aggregate principal amount of % senior secured notes due 2031 (the “Notes”). Interest on the Notes will be
payable semi-annually in arrears on and of each year, commencing on July 15, 2024. The Notes will mature on January 15, 2031.

The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes on or after January 15, 2027 at the redemption prices set out in this offering memorandum. Prior to
January 15, 2027, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts (as defined herein), if any, plus the Applicable Premium, as described in this offering memorandum.
In addition, prior to, January 15, 2027, the Issuer may also redeem at its option up to 35% of the original principal amount of the Notes with the net
proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price set forth in this offering memorandum. Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting
a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 101% of the principal
amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, we may
redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes.

The Notes will be governed by German law and will constitute senior obligations of the Issuer, will be secured by first ranking liens over the Collateral
(as defined below) (although any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility, Priority Hedging Liabilities and
Cash Management Liabilities (each as defined herein) that are secured by the Collateral will receive priority over the Notes with respect to any proceeds
received upon any enforcement action over the Collateral), will rank equal among themselves and equal in right of payment with all existing and future
obligations of the Issuer that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, will be effectively subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness
of the Issuer that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such
indebtedness, will rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in right of payment to the
Notes, and will be structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not Guarantors (as defined
below).

The Notes will be guaranteed (the “Guarantees”) on a senior basis by certain subsidiaries of the Issuer (the “Guarantors”). The Notes will initially be
secured by first ranking liens over shares of or the partnership interests in the Issuer, each Guarantor (other than Wepa Italia S.r.l.) and Wepa Deutschland
Verwaltungs-GmbH, certain machinery and equipment and real property in Germany, certain machinery and equipment in the United Kingdom as well
as any loans of the Parent against the Issuer (the “Collateral”) as described in more detail under “Description of the Notes—General—Security; Release
_of Collateral”. The Guarantees and the security interests over the Collateral will be subject to certain significant contractual and legal limitations and_
subject to certain defenses under applicable law. Applicable law may require that a security interest in certain assets can only be properly perfected and its
priority retained through certain actions which, in the case of some Collateral, may not be completed until after the Issue Date. See “Certain Insolvency
_Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the_
_Notes—Each Guarantee and the Collateral will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain_
_defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability”. The Guarantees and the security interests may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk_
_Factors—Risks Related to the Notes—There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral and the Guarantees_
_may be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Holders’ Representative”, “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor_
_Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—General—Security; Release of Collateral”._

This offering memorandum includes information on the terms of the Notes and the Guarantees, including with regard to redemption and repurchase
prices, guarantees, covenants and transfer restrictions. The Notes will be represented by global notes deposited with Clearstream Banking AG, Frankfurt
am Main, Germany (“Clearstream Banking”). Definitive notes representing individual Notes will not be issued. Transfer of the Notes will be subject to
the rules of Clearstream Banking and the terms of a book entry registration agreement (“Book Entry Registration Agreement”) among Clearstream
Banking and the Issuer with respect to the Notes. The Notes will be issued in denominations of €1,000 and will be transferable only in minimum
aggregate principal amounts of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. The Notes will be ready for delivery, in book entry form only,
on or about, 2024.

There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”)
for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There is no assurance
that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted, or that such listing will be
maintained.


**Investing in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. See “Risk Factors” beginning on page 27.**

their experience in our industry and the markets in which we operate, and (ii) in respect of the performance of
our operations, our internal analysis of our audited and unaudited financial and other information. As some
of the foregoing information was compiled or provided by our management and is not publicly available, such
information accordingly may not be considered to be as independent as that provided by other third-party
sources.

For example, certain information in this offering memorandum regarding our estimated share of the private
label tissue market in different geographies is based on our internal private label mapping during the course of
2022 (our “Internal Private Label Mapping 2022”). As the RISI Report, for example, only includes data about
the overall private label tissue market, we conduct our own research to allow us to estimate and track our own
market share in the private label tissue market. As part of this research, members of our own salesforce collect
what we consider to be representative product samples across selected retail stores in each of our core markets.
Based on product codes and other identifying information of these samples, we then attempt to project,
approximate and estimate our own market share as well as the market shares of other private label producers
in each market. We believe that the research methods and procedures as well as the assumptions we use in our
Internal Private Label Mapping 2022 are reasonable and consistent with established industry practice, and we
also try to sense-check our projections and estimates by cross-checking them against information about total
values of the relevant tissue markets from the RISI Report. We therefore also believe the resulting projections
and estimates of market shares to be fair approximations of our actual market share in each relevant market
that are useful in helping us manage our business. However, the relevant estimates and projections, by their
nature, involve method-based simplifications and uncertainties, and there is no guarantee that our actual
private label market shares may not differ from the estimated private label market shares set forth in this
offering memorandum. Accordingly, prospective investors should not place undue reliance on, and be
conscious of the approximative character of, the estimated private label market shares as set forth in this
offering memorandum.

**OUR COMPANY**

We are a leading European, family-owned producer and supplier of tissue products with a market share (by
production volumes) of 8.1% in Europe and 10.2% in Western Europe, both according to RISI. Based on our
Internal Private Label Mapping 2022, we believe we are the leading private label consumer tissue paper
producer in our core markets of Germany, the BeNeLux region, France and Italy with a market share, by
volume, between approximately 17–32% in these markets. In addition, we believe we are the second largest
private label consumer tissue paper producer in the UK and the third largest in Poland. We are convinced we
differentiate ourselves from our competitors through our strong and future-oriented commitment to the
European tissue paper business, with a clear focus on sustainability, product innovation and continuous
strategic investments in our asset base.

Headquartered in Arnsberg, Germany, we offer a full range of folded and rolled tissue products such as toilet
paper, kitchen towels, handkerchiefs, hand towels, facial tissues, napkins, industrial paper rolls and paper
towels as well as semi-finished products (i.e. jumbo reels and de-inked pulp). We produce our tissue products
on 22 paper machines and over 80 converting lines. Our fourteen production sites are located strategically
across Europe in Germany, Italy, France, Poland, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, and we had an
average of 3,785 employees in 2022. Our production capacities make us the third largest producer of tissue
products (by volume) in the European tissue market, a market exhibiting resilient demand characteristics with
low product substitution risk. As of the date of this offering memorandum, we have an installed tissue paper
production capacity of 850,000 tons and an installed tissue paper converting capacity of 847,000 tons to
convert tissue paper into tissue products. Approximately 48% of our production capacity and 45% of our
converting capacity is located in Germany, our core market and Europe’s largest tissue market. We also own
technologically advanced facilities for the production of de-inked pulp from recovered paper, with an annual
capacity of more than 390,000 tons. Due to this and our long-standing focus on sustainable products and
production, we believe we are the largest producer of tissue products from recovered paper and hybrid
products in Europe, with total sales of €1,636.4 million in 2022. In the twelve-month period ended
September 30, 2023, we sold 724,000 tons of finished tissue products, 35,000 tons of de-inked pulp and 29,000
tons of jumbo reels across Europe, which generated €1,865.1 million and €318.2 million of sales and EBITDA,
respectively, in such period.

We operate our business primarily through our two business units Consumer and Professional. In our
Consumer business unit, we are a private-label specialist for European retailers, selling our tissue products
branded under our retail customers’ own labels. Our Professional business unit with the brands BlackSatino
and Satino by WEPA stands for sustainable and professional hygiene solutions for large commercial and
institutional customers, served through leading distributors. In addition to our two core business units, and in
line with our vision to be the most sustainable, best-in-class partner for personal and professional hygiene
solutions, we have recently set up a “New Business Areas” business unit, focusing on the expansion of our
product and service portfolio, in particular through innovation, e-commerce and circular economy.

Our Consumer business unit, which represented 85% of our sales from finished products in our financial year
2022 and 86% of our sales from finished products in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023,
offers a full range of consumer tissue products: toilet paper, kitchen towels, facial tissues, handkerchiefs and
napkins. While the key focus of our Consumer business unit is on the private label sector, we also market some
products under our own brands such as Mach m!t…, Comprami, Perla and Scala. Our Professional business
unit, which has a more regional focus within Central Europe and Poland, focuses on tissue products for large
commercial and institutional customers, such as government agencies, hotels, restaurants, private enterprises,
hospitals and other healthcare providers. It offers a broad range of tissue products with a focus on our own
brands Satino by WEPA and BlackSatino, including toilet paper and paper towels, industrial rolls, kitchen
rolls as well as accessories like comprehensive dispenser systems for washrooms. In addition to the brand
business, our Professional business unit offers also private label and unbranded products. In both
business units, we also generate revenues from the sale of semi-finished products, such as de-inked pulp and
jumbo reels, with the amount of such sales varying and primarily depending on our own internal demand.

**OUR STRENGTHS**

We believe that we benefit from the following strengths.

**_Leading Market Positions in Attractive and Resilient End-Markets_**

We are the third largest producer by volume of tissue products in Western Europe, having increased our
market share in Europe from 6.9% in 2015 to 8.1% in 2022 according to RISI. In addition, we believe we are
the largest producer of private label consumer tissue products across our core markets, by volume. For
example, in our home market Germany, which is also our biggest market, we are the largest private label
consumer tissue producer, holding a market share of 28.5% by volume, and we also believe we hold leading
market positions in private label consumer tissue production in each of our other core markets France (first
by capacity, holding a market share of 32.9%), the BeNeLux region (first by capacity, holding a market share


-----

of 27.6%), Italy (first by capacity, holding a market share of 16.8%), the United Kingdom (second by capacity,
holding a market share of 22.1%) and Poland (third by capacity, holding a market share of 16.9%), all based
on our Internal Private Label Mapping 2022. With regard to sustainable tissue products, we believe we are the
largest producer of tissue products from recovered paper and hybrid products in Europe, with total volumes
of approximately 294,000 tons in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023. Above all, we believe
that our significant existing scale, purchasing power, geographic coverage and strategically well-positioned
production sites give us a competitive advantage over smaller players and enhance our ability to compete with
other leading players in these markets more effectively. Additionally, we believe our competitive position
profits from our clear and future-oriented commitment to the European private label segment in the Consumer
business unit, focusing on long-term strategic customer relations, providing supply reliability, product
innovations and improvement potential for our customers’ sustainability footprint.

Our core tissue products benefit from utility-like consumer demand, high penetration rates, low substitution
risk and resilient demand characteristics. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a generally
increased awareness of hygiene and, as a result, demand for tissue products. Tissue consumption has seen
stable growth rates in Western Europe and strong growth rates in Eastern Europe. According to RISI,
consumption of tissue products in Western Europe grew by an average of 0.7% per annum and in Eastern
Europe by an average of 4.6% per annum between 2011 and 2021, to 6.8 million tons and 2.5 million tons of
tissue, respectively, in 2021. Demand for our core consumer tissue products increased by an average of 1.0%
per annum between 2011 and 2021 in Western Europe and by an average of 4.8% per annum in Eastern
Europe. For the period between 2021 and 2031, RISI expects the average growth rate of tissue consumption in
Western Europe to increase to 1.1% per annum, with growth rates in Eastern Europe expected to continue to
exceed rates in Western Europe, primarily due to the still significantly lower per capital consumption of tissue
paper in many Eastern European countries. We believe that demographic changes, increased urbanization,
higher product penetration levels, developments in tissue quality as well as increased pressure on our customers
to meet their self-imposed sustainability goals (where they are widely dependent on suppliers to provide
sustainably sourced raw materials due to the nature of the retail business model) will continue to underpin
demand growth for our products.

Unlike many of our competitors who serve both the branded and the private label sectors, our Consumer
business unit focuses on the key private label sector. Both in 2022 and the nine-month period ended
September 30, 2023, 97% of the sales of the Consumer business unit related to private label sales. The private
label sector represented 78.2% (by volume) of the overall German tissue market in 2022, according to RISI,
and also accounts for the majority of the overall tissue market in many other European markets in which we
operate. The overall market share of private label tissue products, by volume, relative to branded products, has
increased in Western Europe from 64.4% in 2015 to 71.5% in 2022, according to RISI. This increase has been
driven by the expansion of discount retailers, who primarily sell private label goods, an increased share of
private label tissue products being sold by non-discount retailers as well as by consumers substituting higherpriced branded products with lower-priced private label products of comparable quality.

We believe that our focus on the private label sector, combined with our significant existing scale and
purchasing power, our European network of fourteen strategically located production sites, our recent
investments into expanding and optimizing our production capabilities as well as our high quality and
sustainable products make us an attractive partner for large retailers (our key customers) across Europe and
positions us well to solidify our market leading positioning in the Consumer business, while capturing further
growth opportunities in this attractive and generally resilient market.

Our Professional business unit, which focuses on sales to large commercial and institutional customers, such
as government agencies, hotels, restaurants, private enterprises, hospitals and other healthcare providers,


-----

generated €229.1 million in sales or 15.5% of our total sales from finished products in 2022. We believe that we
have a market share of 6% in the away-from-home segment in Western Europe. While tissue consumption in
this segment has not yet reached pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels, demand has started to recover, with a further
positive development and a positive outlook predicted by RISI. For the period from 2021 to 2026, RISI
expects the average growth rate of away-from-home tissue consumption in Western Europe to be 2.5% per
annum, and 1.3% per annum between 2026 and 2031, and therefore to exceed the expected growth rates in the
consumer tissue business. We believe that, with our strong existing Professional platform, combined with our
focus on sustainable products and our recent product innovations such as fibers from old corrugated board
(“OCC”) and miscanthus grass, we are well positioned to benefit from the growth of the away-from-home
tissue market and the market trend that customers request more sustainable products to meet their own
sustainability targets.

**_Strong and Long-Standing and Well-Diversified Customer Relationships_**

We have strong and long-standing customer relationships, with some of our key customer relationships dating
back more than 40 years, and the relationships with many of our top ten customers (by volume) in 2022
existing for more than 20 years. We have historically grown mostly with our large German customers as they
have expanded across Europe, but we have also significantly diversified our client base over the last decade
both by acquiring businesses with an existing customer-base in several of the markets in which we operate
today and by successfully entering into new relationships with key customers in our markets.

Our growing geographic coverage, our production and supply chain excellence as well as our significant
investments into expanding and optimizing our production capacities, have allowed us to gain new customers
and to strengthen the relationship with existing customers. As of the date of this offering memorandum, we
supply approximately 460 customers across our Consumer and Professional business units and we have welldiversified customer relationships. In our Consumer business unit, our customers include Aldi, dm, Edeka,
Lidl, Müller, Netto and REWE in Germany, Auchan, Carrefour, Casino, Intermarché and Leclerc in France,
Esselunga and Eurospin in Italy, Biedronka in Poland, Aldi, Coop and Tesco in the United Kingdom and
Colruyt and Superunie in the BeNeLux region. In addition, we supply IKEA worldwide with napkins. Our
Professional business unit serves leading distributors in the professional hygiene sector, such as GVS eG,
igefa, Abena, Metro Cash & Carry, CWS and MTS, cash & carry wholesalers as well as distributors for office
supplies.

As a result of our significant volume growth over the last decade, we have been able to further diversify our
customer base and the relative portion of our sales to our long-standing largest customer Lidl has decreased
to 16% of our total sales in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023, compared to historic levels of
25% in 2012. Overall, we achieved this diversification without losing significant volumes from any of our key
customers.

We believe our performance and reliability throughout the COVID-19 pandemic and periods marked by
extreme energy price peaks following the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which at times forced certain other
market participants to reduce or suspend product deliveries, has further strengthened our reputation. During
the COVID-19 pandemic, we were able to demonstrate to our customers that we are a reliable, innovative and
transparent partner, ensuring both supply security and solid quality standards, while certain of our
competitors were not able to comply with their contractual supply commitments. At the same time, in light of
the significant supply chain issues in the market and tissue producers suffering from high energy costs, our
customers increasingly realized the value of long-term and fair arrangements with reliable and resilient
suppliers. We closely partnered with many of our customers to mitigate the negative consequences of the
energy crisis on various stakeholders, including our customers and their end consumers. As part of this
process, for many of our customers, we have been able to shorten the price cycles from previously one year to
periods of three to six months, allowing for a faster pass through of input cost increases to our customers.

In addition, we also believe that our ability to supply high quality, cost efficient and innovative products has
enabled us to benefit from a continuing trend among major retailers to consolidate their supplier bases and
work with larger partners that have the required scale, competencies and capacity to supply them efficiently
with a consistent quality across their markets and with partners that can enable them to execute their
sustainability strategy. In many instances, we are operating as a fundamental part of the supply chains of our
key customers, by improving their inventory management, security of supply and customer service. As part of
our new “concept supplier” strategy, and as further described under “—Our Strategy—Partner of Choice for
_Our Customers”, we offer the relevant customers cross-functional collaboration and to closely align our_
strategic plans with their strategic priorities, in particular in relation to the introduction and development of
new sustainable and/or innovative products, customer brands and value-added services.

**_Innovation Leader with a long-standing Focus on Sustainable Products and Production_**

As early as 1983, we began producing recycled tissue paper and subsequently started to invest significantly in
facilities for the recycling of recovered paper and in developing recycled tissue products. In 2010, we were the
first tissue producer in Europe to launch a range of high quality “hybrid” toilet paper and kitchen towels
based on fresh fiber, but with a minimum of 30% of recycled fiber content added to the raw material mix.
Over the years, we have gained significant additional expertise in recycled and hybrid products, be it from
improved quality (i.e. brightness, softness), different input fibers, including most recently OCC, and flexible
hybrid grades with different fiber shares of different fresh fibers like pulp or from miscanthus grass. Today, we
believe we are the leading producer of tissue products from recovered paper and hybrid products in Europe by
volume. Our leading market position in the field of recycled and hybrid tissue products is supported by our
well-invested asset base for the recycling of recovered paper in Arnsberg, Giershagen, Mainz and Kriebstein,
Germany, Swalmen, the Netherlands, Piechowice, Poland and Château-Thierry, France, with a total annual
stock preparation capacity of more than 390,000 tons of de-inked pulp.

In addition to our strong focus on recovered paper for the production of tissue paper, we have also become an
innovation leader for sustainable tissue products and operations. Driven by an increasing dependency of our
retail customers on their suppliers to meet their own sustainability goals and following a continuously
increasing end-consumer demand in products from sustainable fibers, we have focused on the development of
new sustainable tissue products as part of our 4+1 sustainability strategy, as further described under “—Our
_Strategy—Strong Commitment to Sustainability”. For example, we have successfully launched tissue products_
made from OCC, a fiber which can be reused multiple times before becoming tissue fiber, which in most cases
is also the end-use, and which has, as a recycled fiber, a reduced ecological footprint of 70% compared to pure


-----

pulp. Due to steadily shrinking availability of high bright graphic paper for recycling purposes, products
made from OCC have a significant potential for further growth. We have also launched a new fiber production
based on miscanthus grass. Miscanthus grass can be grown on fields that are no longer suitable for agriculture
due to exhausted soil. It can grow on those fields for several years, resulting in a better environmental footprint
compared to wood plantations. Our current test line for the production of miscanthus grass-based fibers has
a capacity of 350 tons per annum. In light of the significant potential of such fiber and the fact that we are
already successfully distributing our first miscanthus-based products, we have recently started the construction
of a production line with an annual production capacity of 8,000 tons. The ramp-up of this production line is
expected for 2025.

As a result of our long-standing focus on sustainable tissue products and operations, we believe we are
particularly well-positioned to benefit from demand trends for more sustainable products. In the twelvemonth period ended September 30, 2023, approximately 50% of the finished products produced by us
consisted of recycled or hybrid tissue products, with 22.2% of our finished products being recycled paperbased products (of which 0.6%, or approximately 4,700 tons, related to our new OCC-based products in the
first year of introduction) and 25.4% being hybrid paper products. We further sold 35,000 tons of de-inked
pulp in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023. In addition to the clear benefits of recycled and
hybrid tissue products from an ecological and sustainability perspective, we believe that our strength and
expertise in recycled and (in particular) hybrid tissue products give us significant commercial advantages. It
allows us to diversify our product portfolio, helps us balance fluctuations in the price of raw materials (i.e.,
soften the impact of price increases for fresh fiber) and opens up opportunities to improve our margins as well
as our customers´ margins for value added by incorporating recycled fiber into higher quality/value products
(i.e. by convincing customers to partially substitute lower quality recycled tissue products with hybrid or OCC
products). Our efforts producing recycled and hybrid tissue products have been validated with various ecolabels and certifications for our products, such as the EU Ecolabel, the “Blue Angel” (“Blauer Engel”) label in
Germany, the European Eco Label and the Nordic Swan for Europe. Furthermore, we were also awarded with
a Silver Star award in EcoVadis’s sustainability rating, our miscanthus-based product line BlackSatino
GreenGrow has been awarded with the Purus Innovation Award 2023 and our Satino PureSoft products,
made from OCC, have been awarded with the German Bundespreis Ecodesign 2023 award.

**_Efficient Production via Well-Invested and Strategically Located Asset Base_**

We operate fourteen production sites, including one focused solely on raw-material production (de-inked
pulp), strategically located across Europe in Germany, Italy, France, Poland, the Netherlands and the UK.
This network largely mirrors the footprint of our key pan-European customers and thus enables us to supply
our customers in a timely, cost-effective manner. Mainly due to disproportionally high freight costs relative to
the value of products shipped, it is not economical for participants in our industry to supply customers more
than a certain distance from a particular production site. The alignment of our production sites with the
geographic footprint of our major customers is therefore an important competitive advantage. In addition,
our geographic footprint enables us to reduce delivery times and, typically, to guarantee delivery to our
customers within a short and competitive time from the receipt of an order. Our geographic footprint also
permits us to optimize our inventories by shortening the supply chain which, in turn, lowers our storage and
transportation costs. It further allows us to align our individual production sites with the preferences of endcustomers in specific regions, which improves our product offering, service quality, reliability and efficiency.
During the COVID-19 pandemic as well as the energy crisis as a consequence of the Russian invasion in
Ukraine, our European footprint provided us with the necessary degree of flexibility to continue our
production at the required level and serve our customers’ needs.

We are convinced that the continuous strategic development of our asset base remains key to our continued
success as a leading, cost efficient tissue producer in Europe. To further strengthen our market position and
competitiveness, we implemented a number of strategic capital expenditure projects between 2020 and 2023,
notwithstanding the special challenges we faced as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and the Russian
invasion of Ukraine. In that period, we invested a total of €316 million into our business. This includes an
investment of €122 million in two new, highly efficient paper machines at our production sites in Piechowice,
Poland and Bridgend, UK. We also successfully completed a pan-European investment project which included
11 new converting lines for our plants in Germany, France, the Netherlands, Poland and the UK. Additionally,
we have taken strategic measures to allow a fast shift to different energy sources such as liquified natural gas
and oil in the event of a gas shortage. As part of our project “Bluetec”, we have developed alternative energy
sources for the paper drying process in paper machines, such as electricity, steam or thermal oil instead of
direct gas firing, and have installed 2.9MW of solar capacity on the roofs of our facilities at our production
sites in Swalmen, the Netherlands, and Salanetti, Italy, with further installations planned at other production
sites, including an extension of the existing solar capacity in Salanetti, Italy.


-----

With our latest acquisition of a stock preparation unit (used for the preparation of de-inked pulp from
recovered paper) located in close proximity to our tissue paper manufacturing site in Kriebstein, Germany,
which we acquired from the insolvent Kübler & Niethammer Papierfabrik Kriebstein GmbH in June 2023, we
believe we have generated synergies for our manufacturing sites in Kriebstein and Leuna, Germany and
Piechowice, Poland with regard to efficiency and cost savings, as well as increased flexibility for the Group.
With the addition of the former Kübler & Niethammer stock preparation unit to our de-inked pulp capacities,
we have increased our stock preparation capacity by 43,500 tons p.a. and thereby widely balanced our
integrated internal production of de-inked pulp with our actual demand for recycled tissue. This gives us the
opportunity to further focus our specialized de-inked pulp mill in Château-Thierry on differentiated fiber
production from circular economy and offer alternative and more sustainable fibers either to third parties or
to further grow our sustainable product portfolio. This includes a broader co-operation approach, e.g., the
most recent joint venture for production of biogas from recycled paper scrap in Château-Thierry as a first
step.

**_Strong and Proven Financial Track Record, providing Stability even in very Challenging Market Environments_**

Over the last years, we have significantly strengthened our financial resilience. In particular, we have
(i) substantially diversified our customer base and expanded our product portfolio, (ii) reduced or exited
unprofitable business lines (e.g. the crepe business), customer relationships and markets, (iii) expanded our
geographic footprint in new and/or attractive target markets, (iv) significantly reduced our reliance on fresh
fiber as our main raw material (e.g. by continuing to develop our hybrid products) and focused on innovations
around using more recycled- or alternative fiber tissue products (such as fibers from OCC and fibers made
from miscanthus grass) and (v) continued to significantly invest in further optimizing and expanding our
asset base, including targeted expansion investments and sustainable capacity management measures intended
to drive further cost reductions, portfolio optimization and efficiency improvements and working capital
reductions such as our 2 new, highly efficient paper machines and our 11 new converting lines. In addition to
these measures, we have successfully carried on our continuous improvement process, a systematic and
ongoing program to continuously improve our profitability and cash position. We have also continued to
refine our adaptive and balanced risk management strategy, which, among other things, relies on adaptive
and rolling hedging measures designed to limit our exposure to short- to mid-term fluctuations in the price of
pulp, exchange rates and energy prices, our ability to preserve cash in the mid-term through the adaptation of
the amount of our capital expenditures and a stable financing structure.

The measures taken have allowed us to successfully navigate the significant economic challenges imposed on
us and our industry between 2020 to 2022, including labor shortages during the COVID-19 pandemic, supply
chain disruptions resulting in record high price levels for pulp in Europe, the Russian invasion of Ukraine as
well as the resulting energy crisis with energy prices increasing as high as 15x higher than at the beginning of
2020. Despite these multiple market-driven crises within a short time period, we believe our performance
during such challenging times has helped us to further strengthen our long-standing reputation as a reliable,
innovative and transparent partner with enduring, strong and trusted relationships with our customers,
allowing us to become even more resilient. We successfully shortened contract cycles with our customers and
succeeded in implementing required price increases without losing business or trust. In addition, we
implemented further measures to reduce volatility, such as a rolling 18 months forecasting on a monthly basis
which is harmonized to the pricing strategy and broader sourcing of energy and materials. We also introduced
the function of a business resilience manager to proactively manage volatility by collaborating crossfunctionally across our Group. As a result, we believe we can adapt more quickly and more proactively to
changing price levels and seasonality (i.e. energy pricing during summer vs. winter periods). For additional
measures we plan to adopt as part of our Perform & Transform Strategy 2026 to guide our business within
potential future volatile, uncertain, complex and ambiguous (“VUCA”) market environments, see also “—Our
_Strategy—Focus on Strong Profitability and Financial Resilience” and “—Our Strategy—Continuous Striving_
_for Efficiency through Cost and Technology Leadership”._

We believe that due to the positive impact of the various measures and developments described above, we have
emerged from the market-driven challenges of this multi-crisis period significantly stronger than before. While
the Russian invasion of Ukraine created very significant challenges for our business, both our sales and
EBITDA increased significantly from €1,205.9 million and €93.1 million, respectively, in 2021, to
€1,636.4 million and €145.6 million, respectively, in 2022. In the twelve-month period ended September 30,
2023, we reported sales and EBITDA of €1,865.1 million and €318.2 million, respectively. Our EBITDA
margin (i.e., EBITDA as a percentage of our total operating performance for the period) amounted to 17.0%
in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023, compared to 8.6% in the twelve-month period ended
December 31, 2022 and 7.7% in the twelve-month period ended December 31, 2021, reflecting our ability to


-----

pass-through cost increases to our customers with continued momentum. In addition, we had a free cash flow
(adjusted by ABS Program) of €200 million in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023, while our
Net Debt was reduced to €503 million with a corresponding Net Debt Ratio of 1.6x as of September 30, 2023.

**_Experienced Management and Committed Family Shareholders_**

Our company was founded in 1948 by Paul Krengel, and even today, our Group continues to be 100% owned
by members of the Krengel family. We believe that the strong personal and financial commitment from our
family shareholders ensures prudent investment strategies, a focus on stability and long-term value generation.
Martin Krengel, in particular, has overseen the growth of the business through his role as our Chief Executive
Officer and has been involved in the business since 1985.

The strong personal and financial commitment of our family shareholders is augmented by a strong and
highly-experienced management team with extensive industry experience. In response to the increasing size
and complexity of the Group as well as the industry we are operating in, we have successfully structured our
organization in a matrix with clear business unit and functional responsibilities and have expanded both the
size of our Management Board and our highly experienced senior management team in recent years. Our
Chief Executive Officer Martin Krengel and our long-term Chief Financial Officer Ralph Dihlmann, who
has been with the Group since 2014, have been joined by Andreas Krengel as member of our management
board in 2021. With a degree in business economics and previously serving as our Chief Strategy Officer,
Andreas Krengel is now responsible as Chief Executive Officer for both our Professional business unit and
our recently set up new business unit “New Business Areas”. Andreas Krengel’s management role in our
Professional business unit, his appointment to our Management Board and his management positions in our
family shareholders’ holding entities serve the goal of securing our future as a successful family-owned
business into the next generation.

Also in 2021, the Management Board was joined by Harm Bergmann-Kramer. Having graduated in
engineering, Harm Bergmann-Kramer has held various international management positions across the paper
industry for 19 years prior to taking over responsibility as our Chief Operating Officer. The latest addition to
our Management Board has been Menno Oosterhoff who joined us in 2022. With a degree in business
administration, Menno Oosterhoff has 24 years of extensive sales experience across the international
consumer goods industry and assumed the role as Chief Executive Officer for our Consumer business unit.

**OUR STRATEGY**

We want to be recognized by our customers as the partner of choice for hygiene paper in Europe and become
the market leader in sustainability with a strong culture and a strong focus on performance in everything we
do. To achieve this goal, we developed our “Perform & Transform Strategy 2026”, which builds on the original
“Perform & Transform” strategy we developed for the period from 2020 until 2023.

The key elements of our Perform & Transform Strategy 2026, as further described below, are (i) a focus on
strong profitability and financial resilience, (ii) a continuous striving for efficiency, through cost and
technology leadership, (iii) the goal to become the partner of choice for our customers for hygiene paper by
building on our reputation as a strong and reliable supplier and by differentiating ourselves as a “concept
supplier”, (iv) a strong commitment to sustainability, as well as (v) our efforts to promote employee
engagement and performance through the establishment of a “performance with care” culture across our
organization and by becoming the “best place to work” for our employees.

**_Focus on Strong Profitability and Financial Resilience_**

A key element of our Perform & Transform Strategy 2026 is our goal to achieve a high degree of financial
resilience and strategic flexibility through (i) improvements to our ability to monitor, manage and improve
our margins, (ii) development of digital management tools supporting fast and proactive analytics, resilience
management and increased adaptivity of our supply chain, and (iii) an increased focus on optimizing how we
fund our operations. In particular, we have been putting a higher focus on proactive resilience management
and on digitizing and consistently cascading our decision-making processes to enable us to actively shape and
guide our business within VUCA market environments. This includes investments in forward-looking
management and forecasting tools, adaptive pricing and hedging measures as well as adaptive supply chain
measures. To strengthen our resilience in VUCA environments, we are also investing into diversifying and
broadening our production, supply chain and raw materials footprint. We have taken various measures
intended to strengthen our resilience and stabilize our gross margins at adequate levels, including the
development and introduction of product innovations (see also “—Strong Commitment to Sustainability”
below), efforts to differentiate and position ourselves as a “concept supplier” (see also “—Partner of Choice


-----

_for our Customers” below), the continuous development and improvement of our balanced risk management_
strategy and the introduction of more sophisticated contract and pricing structures that are better suited to
VUCA environments. On a case-by-case basis, this may include price balancing mechanisms and adaptive/
index pricing in longer-term agreements or the conclusion of shorter term, fixed price contracts. We have
introduced cash conversion as a key performance indicator to increase the awareness among our various
stakeholders of our cash generation capabilities, and we are also being more deliberate and proactive in
managing our inventories, treating working capital as an investment and inventory management as part of
our overall resilience management.

In all our decision-making, we recognize that a stable finance structure is critical to our long-term success.
This does not only include the ability to generate free cash flows sufficient to cover our regular maintenance
capital expenditures and other ongoing expenses, but also means that we must be able to further make
significant, controlled and “through-the-cycle” investments into long-term improvements of our regional,
technical and sustainability footprint. To ensure our continued ability to weather and/or adapt to future
VUCA environments (such as rapid and/or sustained increases in pulp, recycled paper or energy prices), we
plan to further enhance our proactive performance management, including requirements on more sustainable
margins based on expected input cost and additional services to ensure resilience, and to further enhance our
ability to preserve cash in the mid-term by adapting our discretionary capital expenditures.

Our focus on strong profitability will also cover measures related to our strategic portfolio management and
further efficiency improvements. We will continue to pursue our long-term strategy of gradually expanding
our customer base as well as our product portfolio and regional footprint as part of a continuous and
deliberate portfolio management process. Active portfolio management as (i) a continuous improvement
process, (ii) supplemented by customer-oriented innovations, (iii) supported by bolt-on acquisitions and
(iv) through regional organic growth has allowed us to significantly expand our business and to reduce our
dependence on any particular individual customers, products or regions, all while continuously working on
further efficiency improvements.

**_Continuous Striving for Efficiency through Cost and Technology Leadership_**

As our product offering mainly consists of commodity-like products, with market participants traditionally
focused primarily on price, a continuous focus on working efficiently and controlling costs (i.e. the ability to
continue to find ways to “do more with less”) has always been crucial to our ability to remain competitive and
to continue to operate in our industry. As part of the original Perform & Transform strategy we developed for
the strategic period from 2020 until 2023, we already set ourselves the goal to become the most efficient
company in the European tissue industry and initiated several related, group-wide initiatives. These include
initiatives aimed at achieving savings and efficiency improvements in the areas of fiber, energy and logistics.
With our Perform & Transform Strategy 2026, we continue to emphasize our goal to become the most efficient
and competitive company in our industry, through both cost and technology leadership, building on our
investments in our modern asset base over the last decade.

Building on a structure that we believe is already lean to begin with, we plan to continuously strive to achieve
cost leadership though additional efficiency improvements as part of our long-standing continuous
improvement program. As part of this program, we are executing numerous optimization initiatives in
different areas such as production, supply chain, sales, procurement and shared services. We further plan to
continue our other efficiency programs (such as our manufacturing excellence (“ManEx”) program) and
strategic operational programs (such as our Bluetec program). The aim of our long-standing ManEx program,
for example, is to continuously and sustainably improve our knowledge, our structures and our processes
within our organization by using benchmarking and by identifying and adopting best practices. We believe
there is still significant potential for us to “do more” with our existing asset base (including a potential
significant increase in the notional production capacity of our existing assets) through further standardization,
optimization and simplification of our production and manufacturing processes and a further simplification
of our product groups. With our “Bluetec”program, we aim to diversify our energy mix by increasing our use
of renewable energy (such as solar power, biomass and wind power) and to further reduce our reliance on
conventional sources of energy, in particular gas, thereby “future proofing” our business. For example, we
have already installed 2.9MW of solar capacity on the roofs of our facilities at our production sites in Salanetti,
Italy and Swalmen, the Netherlands, with plans to install additional solar capacity on the roofs of our facilities
at our production sites in Leuna, Müschede, Giershagen and Salanetti. However, in this regard, we also expect
to benefit from proposed future investments outside the Group by our Parent in complementary business
areas such as renewable energy, alternative fibers and circular economy business models, which we expect will
allow us to preserve capital and focus our own capital expenditures, efforts and other resources on further


-----

expanding and improving our asset base that is more directly related to our core tissue business. See also
“—Strong Commitment to Sustainability” and “Sustainability” below.

The second element of our drive for efficiency and competitiveness is technology leadership. This is because
we view technology leadership as a crucial enabler of efficiency-based cost leadership. We therefore not only
continuously strive to further optimize the capacity and the utilization of our paper machines and converting
lines as part of our ManEx program and other operational efficiency programs, but we also plan to continue
to improve and upgrade our asset base. In some cases, this may include replacing less efficient older equipment
with more efficient modern equipment, but we also have a dedicated program aimed at identifying and
implementing technology improvement projects (drawing either on our own internal resources and technical
expertise or working in tandem with external partners) in which we are either a first adopter of a particular
industry in our industry or even the inventor of new technology.

To achieve the full benefits of all these projects and initiatives, we believe it is crucial that we can deliver them
on time, on budget and on target, and we have therefore been putting a very strong emphasis on excellence in
project management and project execution and invested in enhanced project management and project
execution capabilities.

**_Partner of Choice for Our Customers_**

A further key element of our Perform & Transform Strategy 2026 is our goal to become the partner of choice
for our customers for hygiene paper by building on our reputation as a strong and reliable supplier and by
differentiating ourselves as a “concept supplier”. With competition in our markets traditionally focused
primarily on price, we have always viewed our ability to deliver our products at the right cost and with the
right level of service, quality and reliability as a basic, yet crucial requirement to be able to remain competitive
in our industry. We therefore strive to maintain and further strengthen our long-standing reputation as a
reliable, innovative and transparent partner with enduring, strong and trusted relationships with our
customers. In many cases, we are already fully embedded in the supply chains of our customers. We believe
our performance and reliability throughout the COVID-19 pandemic and periods marked by extreme energy
price peaks following the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which at times forced certain other market participants
to reduce or suspend product deliveries, has further strengthened our reputation. We also believe that the
COVID-19 pandemic and recent market volatility have led to an important shift in how we are perceived,
especially by our larger customers, i.e. not just as a (theoretically replaceable) supplier of commodity-like
products, but as a critical supply chain partner. Furthermore, we believe we are now the only remaining
company with a clear focus on the private label tissue market and with the scale, capabilities and pan-European
footprint necessary to be able to supply our larger customers across multiple markets.

Building on this reputation and market position, we have invested significant time, effort and other resources
in recent years to move beyond the status of a mere supplier of tissue products. Specifically, one of our key
strategic goals for 2026 is to generate more than 50% of our sales, by volume, from costumers for which we act
as a “concept supplier”. As a “concept supplier”, we offer the relevant customers cross-functional
collaboration and to closely align our strategic plans with their strategic priorities, in particular in relation to
the introduction and development of new sustainable and/or innovative products, customer brands and
value-added services. In the first nine months of 2023, we generated approximately 15% of our sales, by
volume, from costumers for which we act as a “concept supplier”, and we believe that that the added value we
are providing as a “concept supplier” allows us and the relevant customers to generate both higher and more
stable margins in relation to such sales. We can offer the relevant customers unique and tailored solutions and,
in some cases have created and implemented joint business plans with individual customers. The relevant
customers can, but do not have to, opt into a range of additional, value-added services, including support
with product and packaging innovations, robust supply chain management and optimization, joint
forecasting, combined truck loading, category management, sustainability and circular solutions and tailored
price balancing mechanisms and adaptive/index pricing in longer-term agreements. For example, we can offer
customers of our Professional business unit that want to be able to offer their customers sustainable tissue
solutions our own range of sustainable brands as well as product innovations, and we collaborate with our
customers on circular solutions such as hand towel return services. At the same time, there is an increasing
recognition among many of our customers that the only way they can meet their self-imposed sustainability
goals is to collaborate with more sophisticated suppliers that can deliver the required improvements (e.g. with
regard to reduced CO2 footprints and/or increased recycling contents of particular products) in a way that is
“audit proof” and satisfies relevant third party verifiers. We have invested significantly in the relevant
value-adding capabilities, capabilities that many of our smaller competitors, in particular, and/or competitors
that are mere “converters” with no tissue paper production of their own simply lack. See also “—Strong
_Commitment to Sustainability” and “Sustainability” below._


-----

To be the partner of choice for our customers, we may further make additional investments to expand and
strengthen our regional footprint, either in the form of investment into new or expanded production facilities
or opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions. Following the consolidation amongst European retail groups, it has
become even more important that we can supply our customers across their respective markets. We want to be
able to offer our customers bespoke concepts for their own brands in all markets in which they operate,
including bespoke specifications, qualities and price mechanisms. We therefore continue to carefully assess
potential bolt-on acquisitions from time to time, not only to be able to match the pan-European footprints of
our customers, but also to potentially acquire attractive customer bases, to further broaden our portfolio
and/or to leverage our asset base.

**_Strong Commitment to Sustainability_**

We believe we are already an innovation leader with our long-standing focus on sustainable products and
production. See also “Our Strengths—Innovation Leader with a Long-standing Focus on Sustainable Products
_and Production”above and “Sustainability”below. Our strong commitment to sustainability, our aspiration to_
act sustainably in everything we do and our goal to be the most sustainable tissue producer are therefore
further key elements of our Perform & Transform Strategy 2026.

We believe that sustainability is part of our DNA and that our authentic and genuine approach to
sustainability, based on decades of innovation leadership, in particular with regard to recycled and hybrid
tissue products, will serve us well as a key differentiator from many of our competitors. In order to build on
this key strength, we developed our “4+1 Strategy”which defines our sustainability goals in four distinct areas
into which we have divided our sustainability efforts: (i) future fibers, (ii) sustainable production,
(iii) sustainable products and (iv) portfolio extension through innovation. The guiding principle for all of
these goals and for how we want to operate as a business is a strong value foundation (i.e. the “+1”in our “4+1
Strategy”) that encourages responsible conduct as an employer, social commitment, compliance and product
safety.

_Future fibers._ We have long been convinced that recycled paper is the most sensible raw material, from a
sustainability perspective, for tissue products because (i) recycled tissue products have a significantly lower
ecological footprint than comparable pure pulp tissue products, and (ii) the fiber used in the production of
tissue products, in most cases, is irretrievably lost after the use of the product. At the same time, our
technologically advanced production capabilities allow us to produce recycled and hybrid tissue products of a
quality and brightness that is comparable to that of tissue products produced with virgin pulp. However, in
part due to digitalization and a change in working patters, high-quality recovered paper grades, such as office
paper, are becoming increasingly scarce in the market. We are therefore investing significantly in new
technologies, new processes and innovative products that use lower grades of recovered paper, such as OCC.
In addition, we have been investing into alternative virgin fibers (i.e. alternatives to wood-based virgin fibers)
for tissue such as fibers from miscanthus grass cultivated in Europe on fallow land. These alternative types of
fibers not only have significantly improved ecological footprints compared to pulp, but they also help us
diversify our fiber mix. Our ultimate goal is to create a fiber portfolio which addresses a broad range of
sustainability requirements, such as CO2 reduction, biodiversity, land use, waste avoidance and reduced
transportation requirements. In 2022, for example, we launched two new fiber innovations: (i) Black Satino
GreenGrow, a miscanthus-based tissue paper, and (ii) our Satino PureSoft Sortiment, based on OCC-based
tissue paper. According to the German Federal Environmental Agency, the OCC-based tissue paper
constitutes the biggest innovation in the paper segment in the last decade.

_Sustainable production and operational efficiency._ With regard to operational efficiency, we plan to
significantly reduce our CO2 and water footprint and to follow a zero-waste approach, with the goal to become
CO2 neutral by 2040. We strive to reach CO2 neutrality with a balanced mix of investments into our own
sustainable energy production, such as solar, wind and biogas, as well as through relevant power purchase
agreements with third parties, which may include power purchase agreement with our Parent or other affiliates
as described below. Our climate targets are flanked by continuous efficiency improvements and the increasing
use of renewable energy. See also “—Continuous Striving for Efficiency through Cost and Technology
_Leadership” above._

_Sustainable hygiene paper portfolio._ Regarding our goal to offer the most sustainable hygiene paper portfolio,
we have evaluated our hygiene paper portfolio based different sustainability criteria. We plan to use the results
of this evaluation to identify options for the sustainable further development of our portfolio, and to
transparently communicate with customers on how to make their product range more environmentally
friendly. These efforts also include innovative packaging solutions. Among other things, we have set ourselves


-----

a target to use recycled material for 60% of our packaging material by 2025 and save 8,000 tons of primary
plastics in our packaging every year.

_Portfolio extension through innovation._ We are expanding our existing product portfolio with the goal of
leadership in sustainable hygiene solutions in Europe. We believe that only ecologically and socially sustainable
innovations and business models allow for robust economic profitability in the long-term. We are therefore
committed to sustainability in the expansion of our product portfolio and in the area of research and
development. In 2022, we introduced a mandatory sustainability assessment for all our investments. This
assessment takes into account the environmental and social added value for society and for our company, and
includes an analysis of potential environmental, social and governance risks.

To meet our sustainability goals, including environmental protection, fiber diversification, increased
competitiveness, regulatory compliance, and to take advantage of sustainable growth opportunities, we further
plan to develop an investment roadmap to identify how we can “future proof” our business, for example, by
(i) increasing our use of renewable energy and reducing our reliance on conventional sources of energy, in
particular gas, (ii) improving and securing our access to “future fibers” and/or (iii) by further integrating
circular economy aspects into our production processes and product life cycles. See also “—Continuous
_Striving for Efficiency through Cost and Technology Leadership” above. In this regard, we expect to benefit_
from proposed future investments outside the Group by our Parent in complementary business areas such as
renewable energy, alternative fibers and circular economy business models. As these activities and business
areas mostly fall outside our core expertise as a tissue producer and involve different skill sets, expertise,
funding models and investment horizons, developing and/or integrating them into our organization would
potentially create significant challenges and might therefore distract us from our core business. We may
therefore conclude that it is preferable for all our stakeholders that any potential significant future investments
in those areas to be make outside the Group by our Parent or other affiliates. This approach would allow us to
potentially gain contractual exposure (e.g. via power purchase agreements) and preferential access (albeit only
through related party agreements on an arm’s length basis) to these important complementary business areas,
while allowing us to preserve capital and focus our own capital expenditures, efforts and other resources on
further expanding and improving our asset base that is more directly related to our core tissue business. As
part of such an approach, we may conclude that it is in the best interest of the Group to sell (on arm’s length
terms) WEPA Greenfield S.A.S. and its dry de-inked pulp production site in Château-Thierry, France to our
Parent. Acquired in March 2019 in an opportunistic transaction, our de-inked pulp production in ChâteauThierry is not integrated into any of our tissue paper production sites and our only business that relies on
third party sales of semi-finished products. A sale to our Parent or another affiliate might therefore allow us to
free up capital to reinvest into our core business, while preserving preferential access to the de-inked pulp
produced at the site.

**_Establish our Performance with Care Culture and Offering the Best Place to Work_**

The final element of our Perform & Transform Strategy 2026 consists of our efforts to promote employee
engagement and performance through the establishment of a “performance with care” culture across our
organization and by becoming the “best place to work”for our employees. We believe that we can only achieve
our other strategic goals if our employees across our organization work focused and with passion and take
ownership of their decisions and actions. As a family-owned company, we are highly committed to enable and
challenge our people with care. While the “performance” element remains key to our overall success and our
strategic goals, we also believe that caring for our employees is crucial to our continued success. We want to
facilitate high operating performance while fostering a care culture, including through the use of professional
steering and management tools. We believe that the tools we have implemented will help our employees to
prioritize, help us to build teams based on the strength of individuals and support life-long learning. Through
our WEPA Academy we aim to provide a platform that ensures that each employee gets the opportunity to
gain the skills necessary to master his/her role and to deliver on his/her goals.

The success of our business depends on our ability to attract, develop and retain qualified management
personnel and skilled workers in the long term. We compete with a large number of other companies when
recruiting qualified employees. In all Western European markets in which we operate, there is an increasing
shortage of qualified personnel, especially workers with technical or engineering skills. As part of the “Best
Place to Work” element of our strategy, we aim to tackle these challenges by creating an attractive working
environment. This leveraging the potential benefits of digitalization in supporting our employees in their
personal learning and growth. In particular, we aim to offer interesting and purposeful work to our employees,
build learning and development into our daily work routines and to make our employees engage and identify
with our Group’s mission. We believe that this approach is yielding tangible benefits for our business. For
example, encouraging and enabling our employees to “upskill”, work in different positions and/or learn to


-----

operate different equipment may not only make work more interesting and improve job satisfaction, but may
give us more flexibility to deploy those employees in different areas of our organization in response to changes
in our operations, to cover absences by other employees or for other reasons. By capitalizing on the potential
benefits of digitalization, we want to create a workplace that provides our employees with a level of flexibility
to choose where and how they do their work. We also want for our employees to be supported, not replaced,
by digitalization and developments in the area of artificial intelligence.

**THE REFINANCING AND THE TRANSACTIONS**

The “Refinancing”refers to the issuance of €250 million aggregate principal amount of the Notes pursuant to
the Offering and the use of a portion of the proceeds from the Offering (i) to redeem in full the Existing
Floating Rate Notes on or about, 2024, and (ii) to pay other costs, fees and expenses incurred in
connection with the Refinancing, including underwriting fees and commissions, commitment, placement,
financial advisory and other transaction costs and professional fees. The Offering and the use of proceeds
therefrom, including the Refinancing, the financing of a portion of the purchase price we paid for the UK
Acquisition, and the proposed declaration and payment of an extraordinary cash dividend of €20 million to
our Parent on or around, 2024 are collectively referred to as the “Transactions”.

You should read “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalization” and “Description of Other Indebtedness” for a more
detailed description of the expected use of proceeds and our capitalization and financing arrangements
following the completion of the Transactions.

**RECENT DEVELOPMENTS**

On January 10, 2024, we acquired all shares in Star Tissue UK Ltd. (now: Wepa Professional UK Ltd.), a
tissue paper converting and distribution company located in the United Kingdom (the “UK Acquisition”).
With a tissue paper converting capacity of 27,000 tons p.a. and approximately 130 employees, the UK
Acquisition serves to strengthen our Professional business in the United Kingdom. We also believe that it will
allow us to generate synergies with our paper production sites. We understand that in the twelve-month period
ended September 30, 2023, Wepa Professional UK Ltd.’s EBITDA was a high single digit million euro amount
based on financial information provided by the seller. As a result, the UK Acquisition is broadly leverage
neutral. The purchase price we paid for the UK Acquisition was a low-to-mid-double digit million euro
amount. We have agreed with the seller to keep the exact purchase price confidential.

**TRADING UPDATE**

Based on management accounts, our total sales revenues decreased by approximately €9 million or 2.9%, from
approximately €313 million in the two-month period ended November 30, 2022 to approximately €304 million
in the two-month period ended November 30, 2023. This decrease was primarily due to a reduction of the
average sales prices for our finished products, following a strong decline in market prices of our main input
factors seen since the beginning of the fourth quarter of 2022, especially for pulp, recovered paper, electricity
and gas. Sales volumes of our finished products increased by approximately 8,000 tons or 7.1%, from
approximately 119,000 tons in the two-month period ended November 30, 2022 to approximately 128,000
tons in the two-month period ended November 30, 2023, resulting from a structurally higher demand in both
our Consumer and Professional business units, while sales of semi-finished products increased by
approximately 7,000 tons or 78.5%, from approximately 9,000 tons in the two-month period ended
November 30, 2022 to approximately 16,000 tons in the two-month period ended November 30, 2023,
primarily due to the sale of our increased inventory of jumbo reels which we had set up as a hedge against
anticipated disruptions to production related to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, including the possibility of
a gas embargo and gas shortages during the winter period of 2022. Our EBITDA in the two-month period
ended November 30, 2023 decreased by approximately €4 million or 7.9%, to approximately €52 million,
while our EBITDA margin continued to remain on a high level of 17.3% in the two-month period ended
November 30, 2023, compared to an EBITDA of approximately €56 million, or 17.1% EBITDA margin, in
the two-month period ended November 30, 2022. Without the €1.7 million in expenses we recorded in October
and November 2023 in connection with the Refinancing, our EBITDA in the two-month period ended
November 30, 2023 would have been approximately €53 million, a decrease of only 4.9% compared to our
EBITDA in the two-month period ended November 30, 2022. Our Free Cash Flow (adjusted for ABS
program) in the two-month period ended November 30, 2023 increased by €26 million, to approximately
€29 million, compared to a Free Cash Flow (adjusted for ABS program) of approximately €4 million in the
two-month period ended November 30, 2022. Our EBITDA and our EBITDA margin in the two-month
period ended November 30, 2023 confirmed the strong result levels seen in prior months, due to the only slow
decrease of sales prices for our products reflecting the lower price levels for input costs, our improved cost


-----

efficiency, increased sales of higher-margin products such as our hybrid and sustainable fiber products and
our overall strengthened market position in the European tissue paper industry.

The foregoing financial information is based on internal unaudited consolidated monthly accounts for
the months of October and November 2023 and 2022, respectively, which were prepared by and are the
responsibility of our management. This financial information has not been audited, reviewed, compiled or
the subject of any procedures by our independent auditors or any other audit firm and no opinion nor any
other form of assurance is expressed with respect thereto. The foregoing financial information is inherently
subject to modification during the preparation of our financial statements as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2023. The presented financial information is not representative for any three-month or any
twelve-month period and should not be regarded as an indication, forecast or representation by us or any
other person regarding our financial performance for the three-month period or the fiscal year ended
December 31, 2023 or regarding our future financial performance.

**MARKET UPDATE**

While we had seen a decrease in market prices for pulp and recovered paper in Europe until the end of the
third quarter of 2023, pulp demand in China had already started to recover several months ago and local
paper industry had absorbed the suppliers’ price increases. Since the beginning of the fourth quarter of 2023,
the European pulp market appears to have entered a new cycle as well. By the end of November 2023, prices
for softwood pulp were approximately 4.5% higher than by the end of the third quarter of 2023, and prices for
hardwood pulp increased by approximately 15.7%, however remaining significantly below the market price
peaks seen in 2022. Recovered paper pricing remained overall stable at a relatively low level in both October
and November 2023, and prices for electricity and gas also continued to be generally stable, with some more
volatility.
