Our Consumer business unit, which represented 85% of our sales from finished products in our financial year
2022 and 86% of our sales from finished products in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023,
offers a full range of consumer tissue products: toilet paper, kitchen towels, facial tissues, handkerchiefs and
napkins. While the key focus of our Consumer business unit is on the private label sector, we also market some
products under our own brands such as Mach m!t…, Comprami, Perla and Scala. Our Professional business
unit, which has a more regional focus within Central Europe and Poland, focuses on tissue products for large
commercial and institutional customers, such as government agencies, hotels, restaurants, private enterprises,
hospitals and other healthcare providers. It offers a broad range of tissue products with a focus on our own
brands Satino by WEPA and BlackSatino, including toilet paper and paper towels, industrial rolls, kitchen
rolls as well as accessories like comprehensive dispenser systems for washrooms. In addition to the brand
business, our Professional business unit offers also private label and unbranded products. In both
business units, we also generate revenues from the sale of semi-finished products, such as de-inked pulp and
jumbo reels, with the amount of such sales varying and primarily depending on our own internal demand.

**KEY FACTORS AFFECTING THE COMPARABILITY OF OUR RESULTS OF OPERATIONS**

**COVID-19 Pandemic**

Our results of operations in 2020 and 2021 were significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, which
led to a significant volatility of sales in both our Consumer and Professionals business units. At the start of
the COVID-19 pandemic in March and April 2020, panic buying by end-consumers occurred across most
parts of Europe, particularly with respect to toilet paper and other hygienic articles. In order to be able to


-----

meet the resulting unprecedented short-term demand for our products and to be able to continue to supply
our customers, we were forced to adapt both our sales and manufacturing operations to focus on core
products. This initial sales peak was followed by a sharp sales decline in April and May 2020, which gave us the
opportunity to restock our warehouses. However, sales in the second quarter of 2020 differed significantly
between regions. While sales in Italy returned to a normal level, sales in the BeNeLux region decreased due to
a general closure of all non-food stores (including drugstores). As a result of a drop in the market prices for
pulp, we further faced strong pressure from our customers to reduce the prices for our products in almost all
regions, which resulted in price reductions in the third quarter of 2020. See also “Key Factors Affecting our
_Results of Operations—Exposure to Fluctuations in Pulp and Recovered Paper Prices” below for the impact of_
the COVID-19 pandemic on the prices of our main raw materials, pulp and recovered paper. In response to
rising infection figures in the fourth quarter of 2020, retailers across Europe filled their warehouses in
anticipation of further lockdowns. Increasingly stringent COVID-19 restrictions in many jurisdictions led to
renewed panic buying, especially in Germany and the United Kingdom, but not to the same extent as in the
first quarter of 2020. Our Professional business unit was especially hard hit by the COVID-19 pandemic as a
result of the closure of hotels, restaurants, schools and other public spaces, while sales by volume of our
Consumer business unit increased by 7% in 2020, with large parts of the population spending more time at
home.

The COVID-19 pandemic continued to have a significant impact on the tissue industry across Europe and, as
a result, on our results of operations in 2021, especially in the first quarter. Following a further increase in
sales of tissue paper at the end of 2020 in many of our key markets, mirroring increasing infection levels, there
was a corresponding decline in tissue paper sales across Europe in the first quarter of 2021, which had a
significant negative impact on our sales. In addition, some retailers had pursued a policy of high stock levels
and partially built up inventories with imported products in order to be prepared for further panic buying.
This was particularly evident in Germany, where retailers mainly filled their warehouses with various branded
products from Eastern Europe and Russia. This approach by a number of our key customers led to a
comparatively low demand for our products from those customers during the first half of 2021. In the second
quarter of 2021, sales recovered slowly in both our Consumer and Professionals business unit, but volatility in
sales volumes was still noticeable. Sales of our Professional business unit only rebounded gradually, in response
to the gradual removal of COVID-19 restrictions, with restaurants, cafés and hotels gradually allowed to
reopen across Europe. Sales volumes in our Consumer business unit returned to normal levels by the end of
the third quarter of 2021, and with schools, offices, restaurants and hotels reopening, sales volumes of our
Professional business unit also gradually started to recover, although they remained below pre-pandemic levels.

High infection numbers during parts of 2020 and 2021, as well as country-specific rules and regulations, such
as lockdowns and other COVID-19 restrictions, in response to the high infection numbers led to further
changes in shopping behavior by end-consumers. These behavioral changes added to the volatility in sales
volumes and impacted supply chains and distribution channels, creating additional challenges for us. In
particular, we observed a change in consumer purchasing behavior towards “one-stop shopping”in all regions,
which led to supermarkets temporarily taking market share from discounters and drugstores. Supermarkets
that offered an online shopping option also benefited. For example, German retailer and WEPA customer
Edeka entered into a new purchasing partnership with Dutch online supermarket group Picnic in 2020. The
COVID-19 pandemic further accelerated the existing trend towards more online shopping. Examples of how
we responded to this trend include a collaboration with Amazon in Germany, with the first products from
Amazon’s “Essentials” range (partly produced by us) available to consumers since the fourth quarter of 2021.
In 2021, we also launched e-commerce cooperations with e-retailers Rohlik Group and Cleangang.

In addition to the unprecedented volatility of our sales and changes in shopping behavior during 2020 and
2021, the COVID-19 pandemic also created a number of other challenges for our Group. First and foremost,
we had to ensure the health and safety of our employees, while also meeting our delivery commitments to our
customers, which we successfully managed to achieve notwithstanding the special challenges posed by the
COVID-19 pandemic. In line with significant fluctuations of the incidence of COVID-19 infections in the
general population, fluctuating infection levels among our employees led to significant staff absences.
However, as these staff absences affected different production sites at different times and to different degrees,
we were largely able to compensate localized staff-shortages by shifting production to less affected production
sites due to our broad production network and geographic footprint, although this did create logistical
challenges.

As described above, our results of operations in 2021 were significantly negatively impacted by the COVID-19
pandemic. As a result, the comparability of our results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2020
and December 31, 2021, in particular, with the other periods under review and with future periods might be


-----

limited. However, we believe that our business demonstrated resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Throughout the Covid-19 pandemic, we managed to meet our delivery obligations to our customers and we
managed to preserve sufficient liquidity without the need for any additional capital measures. Although we
still felt the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, with very volatile infection figures, our sales volumes and
margins in both our Consumer and Professional business units recovered strongly during 2022. See also “Risk
_Factors—We may be adversely affected by uncertainty and/or unfavorable economic and/or political conditions”._

With the COVID-19 pandemic now officially behind us, the shopping behavior of our end-customers has
again shifted, due to the ongoing cost of living crisis as well as worries about the growing climate crisis and
therefore increasing sustainability awareness and the ongoing war in Ukraine and worsening geopolitical
climate. See also “—Russia-Ukraine Conflict, Supply Chain Shortages and Cost Inflation” below. Specifically,
end-consumers appear to have become increasingly price aware during 2022 and 2023, which has allowed
discounters and drugstores to win back market share. The growth of the online business has also slowed
noticeably, although e-commerce remains an important future market for our Group.

**Russia-Ukraine Conflict, Supply Shortages and Cost Inflation**

In February 2022, Russia launched a military attack against Ukraine. In response, the United States, the EU,
the United Kingdom and other countries have been imposing increasingly stringent sanctions on a number of
Russian and Belarusian persons and entities, including, but not limited to, certain financial institutions, energy,
media, technology and defense companies, as well as individuals associated with the Russian President and
his government. The Russian Federation has responded with the imposition of countersanctions on so-called
“unfriendly” states (which include EU Member States). These developments have led to a high degree of
uncertainty in the global markets.

We have not had any operations in either Russia or Ukraine, except for some immaterial and sporadic
purchases of semi-finished good and sales of finished goods, which we quickly terminated following the start
of the Russian invasion in the Ukraine. However, the Russian war against Ukraine has created, or exacerbated,
significant challenges for our business. Steep further increases in energy prices, fears of gas supply shortages
and general supply shortages due to worldwide supply chain disruptions posed major challenges for Europe,
with the tissue industry particularly affected as an energy-intensive sector. In addition, sharply rising raw
material and transport prices as well as rising rates of inflation across Europe made significant, incremental
price increases for our finished and semi-finished products unavoidable during the course of 2022. See also
“Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Exposure to Fluctuations in Pulp and Recovered Paper
_Prices”, “—Exposure to Fluctuations in Energy Prices” and “—Exposure to Fluctuations in Freight/Logistics_
_Costs” below._

In responding to the unprecedent cost increases during the course of 2022, in particular with regard to energy
costs, we believe we benefited from our performance during the COVID-19 pandemic, which helped us to
further strengthen our long-standing reputation as a reliable, innovative and transparent partner with longstanding, strong and trusting relationships with our customers. We successfully shortened contract cycles
with our customers and took various measures to enhance the energy efficiency of our production to allow us
to respond more quickly to the ongoing volatility of our input costs.

With the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic slowly receding during the course of 2022, the war in Ukraine
and the unprecedented energy price increases which followed quickly became the dominant drivers for our
business starting in the first quarter of 2022. Panic buying occurred again in the immediate aftermath of the
invasion of Ukraine, and the steep energy price increases continued in the second and third quarter of 2022,
especially after Russia almost completely stopped gas deliveries to Europe. The impact of these energy price
increases was compounded by production constraints, limited freight capacity, raw materials price increases,
and staff shortages due to ongoing COVID-19 restrictions. Most retailers therefore shifted their focus to
security of supply to avoid empty shelves. In response to the steep increases in the prices for our raw materials
and energy, in particular, we successfully implemented several rounds of significant, incremental sales price
increases for our products beginning in the fourth quarter of 2021 and throughout 2022, with the last round
of substantial sales price increases coming into effect at the beginning of the fourth quarter of 2022, based on
peak pulp and energy prices during the third quarter of 2022. As before, we strove for transparency with our
customers by clearly communicating the development of our input costs and the outlook for the winter period.
As a result of our strong customer relationships, we succeeded in implementing the required price increases
without losing business or trust.

The extent and duration of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, resulting sanctions and any related market
disruptions are impossible to predict, but could be substantial, particularly if current or new sanctions


-----

continue for an extended period of time or if geopolitical tensions result in expanded or prolonged military
operations. Although the length and impact of the ongoing military conflict in Ukraine is highly
unpredictable, it could have a further material adverse effect on European economies, including the markets in
which we operate.

While the Russian invasion of Ukraine created very significant challenges for our business, both our sales and
EBITDA increased significantly from €1,205.9 million and €93.1 million, respectively, in 2021, to
€1,636.4 million and €145.6 million, respectively, in 2022, and €1,865.1 million and €318.2 million, respectively,
in in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023, as we successfully managed to pass increases in our
input costs through to our customers, as described above. As with our response to the challenges posed by the
COVID-19 pandemic (see “—COVID-19 Pandemic” above), we believe that the way in which we have
overcome the challenges caused, or exacerbated, by the Russian invasion of Ukraine demonstrates the
resilience of our business. But see also “Risk Factors—We may be adversely affected by uncertainty and/or
_unfavorable economic and/or political conditions”._

**KEY FACTORS AFFECTING OUR RESULTS OF OPERATIONS**

**Revenue Drivers**

Our revenues are driven by demand from retailers (and their end customers) in our Consumer business unit
and by specialist distributors and wholesalers (and their end customers) in our Professional business unit.
Sales to our Consumer customers are driven by underlying demand for our products, which in recent years
has generally grown steadily and independently from the overall economic environment. Sales to our
Professional customers have some correlation to overall economic trends, although this is limited by our
exposure to customers in the government, health care and educational sectors. See “Key Factors Affecting the
_Comparability of Our Results of Operations—COVID-19 Pandemic” above, for the unprecedented disruption_
and volatility of our sales of both our Consumer and Professional business units caused by the COVID-19
pandemic during 2020, 2021 and parts of 2022.

The volumes we sell are determined by our relationships with our customers and competition from alternative
suppliers, which has been stable in most of our core markets. Although new players could enter the market or
existing players could add new capacity, given lead time requirements of 18 to 24 months, we believe we will
have good visibility on any new capacity being added. A change to overall capacity levels could lead to a
change in levels of competition, which would affect our results of operations.

In addition to general market factors, our revenues have also been, and will continue to be, affected by a
number of investments we have made in recent years and by the additional capital expenditures we intend to
incur in the short- to mid-term. See also “—Expansion Projects and Investment Program; Sustainable Capacity
_Management” above._

**Exposure to Fluctuations in Pulp and Recovered Paper Prices**

The main raw materials for the production of our products are pulp and recovered paper. Pulp is our largest
and recovered paper our third largest purchasing cost item, accounting for 34.8% (€379.4 million) and 9.4%
(€102.7 million), respectively, of our cost of materials in 2022. This compares to 32.1% (€229.3 million) and
12.8% (€91.6 million), respectively, of our cost of materials in 2021, and 36.3% (€246.3 million) and 10.8%
(€73.3 million), respectively, of our cost of materials in 2020. In the nine-month period ended September 30,
2023, pulp and recovered paper accounted for 38.3% (€297.2 million) and 7.2% (€56.3 million), respectively,
of our cost of materials. The prices for our raw materials, especially pulp and recovered paper, are affected by
various factors, in particular global supply and demand conditions, economic conditions in other paper
industry sectors as well as speculation, and can therefore be highly volatile. The market development for both
raw materials can be tracked through industry indices like “FOEX-PIX” for pulp (www.foex.fi) and Euwid in
particular for recovered paper. The PIX is a benchmark index and published weekly for the main pulp grades
NBSK (softwood) and BHKP (hardwood) on a gross price basis. The PIX is published both in U.S.$ and
Euro, although pulp prices are typically quoted in U.S.$ in the international markets and the euro value of the
PIX therefore merely reflects the relevant U.S.$ value of the PIX, as converted into Euros at the prevailing
exchange rate. When we agree prices for pulp and recovered paper with our suppliers, we typically negotiate
the relevant prices on a monthly basis. These prices are then tracked and published by the PIX and Euwid,
respectively. In order to maximize the specific rebates (i.e. the notional discounts from the relevant prices
published by the PIX and Euwid) negotiated with our suppliers, we continuously try to further optimize our
procurement processes and to fully leverage our purchasing power across the Wepa Group with our suppliers.
In recent years we introduced various ways of price determination in addition to the established traditional
“gross price less rebate”—pattern.


-----

On average, we use a mix of approximately 30% softwood and 70% hardwood-pulp-grades in our tissue
production, with this share varying depending on the intended characteristics of the end product. Pulp prices
can be volatile, but we regard the extreme volatility since 2020 as unprecedent. Steep price decreases during
the first half of 2020 were followed by even steeper and sustained price increases during most of 2021 and
2022, only to be followed by even faster decreases starting in the first quarter of 2023. See also “Key Factors
_Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—COVID-19 Pandemic” and “—Russia-Ukraine_
_Conflict, Supply Shortages and Cost Inflation” above. The average price per ton for pulp, based on PIX prices_
for a 30%/70% mix of softwood and hardwood pulp decreased from U.S.$895 in 2019 to U.S.$729 in 2020,
followed by steep increases to U.S.$1,070 in 2021 and U.S.$1,322 in 2022 and a decrease to U.S.$1,151 in the
nine-month period ended September 30, 2023. In September 2023, the average price decreased to U.S.$ 908.
The equivalent prices per ton in Euro, the functional currency for the Wepa Group, also decreased from €798
in 2019 to €640 in 2020, followed by steep increases to €906 in 2021 and €1,260 in 2022 and a decrease to
€1,063 in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023. In September 2023, the average price decreased
to €846. While the overall trend was partly offset by a stronger euro during 2022, the euro had been weaker
than the US dollar in all the other years during the periods under review. During the same periods, the
availability and price per ton of the preferred recovered paper grade “Sorted Office Paper”(SOP, EN 643 2.06)
as reported by Euwid was even more volatile, as changes in office working (and printer) patterns led to low
collection rates of Sorted Office Paper, in particular, with the COVID-19 pandemic accelerating the secular
decline of the graphic printing and writing sector. At the margin, the availability of middle and lower grades
of recovered paper was also impacted by a tight pulp market. The average price per ton of Sorted Office Paper
decreased from €151 in 2019 to €129 in 2020, followed by a steep increase to €180 in 2021 and to €253 in 2022,
followed by a decrease to €156 in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023, dropping to a similar level
as in 2020 by September 2023.

During 2020, the most important factors influencing the pulp market were related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The demand for pulp dropped as increasingly stringent COVID-19 restrictions took effect across the globe,
especially in the printing and writing sector, and resulted in price levels for pulp at or even below marginal
costs. Prices remained stable throughout 2020 for BHKP, whereas the price for NBSK quickly lost some gains
achieved during the second quarter of 2020, to only recover modestly towards the end of 2020. By the end of
2020, softwood traded at a premium of approximately U.S.$150 over hardwood pulps. In comparison to the
fourth quarter of 2019, prices in U.S. dollars for NBSK were about 6% higher in the fourth quarter of 2020
and unchanged for BHKP, while the average prices per ton during 2020 were approximately 14% lower for
NBSK and approximately 21% lower for BHKP than the relevant average prices per ton during 2021. Demand
and supply of recovered paper were also negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by the
significant drop in demand affecting large parts of the paper industry as well as an interruption of collection
activities. During the fourth quarter of 2020, the prices for recovered paper were at a similar level as during
the fourth quarter of 2019, but the full year average prices during 2020 were approximately 10% lower than
the fully year average prices during 2019.

After an unusual period of stable prices at comparatively low levels during most of 2020, the market turned at
the end of 2020 for softwood pulp, swiftly followed by the market for hardwood at the very beginning of 2021.
This kicked off a price rally that led to all-time-high prices within just seven months, after which both markets
plateaued. Only the price for softwood pulp decreased somewhat towards the end of 2021. The reasons for
these unprecedented price levels were multifold, but most were, in our view, directly or indirectly linked to the
COVID-19 pandemic. They included higher than expected demand in particular from the European printing
and writing sector, which was very hard hit during the first period of the pandemic and did not expect a
recovery in 2021, so that pulp contracts were adapted to the expected low capacity utilization. However, with
global supply chains disrupted and fewer goods imported from Asia, the European printing and writing
sector experienced an unexpectedly strong year in 2021. With global supply chains strained, demand for
market pulp therefore significantly exceeded availability, and for most of the year, softwood maintained its
premium of about U.S.$160 per ton over hardwood pulps. This premium decreased to U.S.$130 for a short
period at the end of 2021. In comparison to the fourth quarter of 2020, prices in U.S.$ for both NBSK and
BHKP were more than 50% higher in the fourth quarter of 2021, while in the full year average of 2021 was
approximately 42% higher for NBSK and approximately 49% higher for BHKP than 2020. Similarly, the
market for recovered paper took an unexpectedly strong upward turn during the entire year of 2021. Even
more severe for the lower grades, which were coming from extremely low, partly negative, price levels at the
beginning of 2020, our preferred white middle grades showed significant price increases during the course of
2021, as collection rates had not recovered from a COVID-19 pandemic-related drop and the scarce supply
met a strong demand from all sectors. By the fourth quarter of 2021, our average purchase price per ton for
recovered paper had increased by about 50% compared to the fourth quarter of 2020, whereas the full year
average price per ton we paid during 2021 was approximately 30% higher than in 2020.


-----

By the beginning of 2022, the disruption of global supply chains caused by the COVID-19 pandemic had
improved the order books of the European paper industry on the back of lower imports from Asia, and the
related demand for pulp in Europe met a once again limited supply cause by, among other factors,
transportation issues. These COVID-19-related factors coincided with several additional extraordinary
developments, setting the stage for another unexpected and unprecedented rally in pulp prices during almost
the entire year in 2022. Those developments included a long-lasting strike at one major pulp producer in
Europe, the impact of the Russian war against Ukraine on cross-border wood trades and availability of freight
capacity and climate-related production losses on the Iberian peninsula. During the first nine month of 2022,
prices for softwood pulp increased by U.S. $236 or 19%, whereas prices for hardwood increased by the same
amount (21%) within just the first six months of 2022. By the end of 2022, prices for softwood pulp were
approximately 13% higher than by end 2021, and prices for hardwood pulp increased by approximately 21%.
The full year averages were about 17% higher for NBSK and 27% higher for BHKP. The availability of certain
recovered paper grades was another dominating factor throughout 2022, with the COVID-19 pandemic
resulting in changes in office working (and printing) patterns that led to low collection rates of, in particular,
Sorted Office Paper and accelerating the secular decline of the graphic printing and writing sector. At the
margin, availability of middle and better grades was also impacted by the tight pulp market. Nevertheless, the
prices for recovered paper initially remained stable, and in some cases even decreased slightly at the beginning
of 2022, following the steep increase in prices towards the end of 2021. However, beginning in the second
quarter of 2022, recovered paper prices increased sharply, peaking in July 2022, before collapsing again during
the second half of 2022, with some of the poor-quality grades even falling below the costs of collection. The
average prices for recovered paper fell by approximately 20% from the third to the fourth quarter of 2022,
with prices in the fourth quarter of 2022 approximately 11% higher than in the fourth quarter of 2021.
Nevertheless, average prices for recovered paper during the full year 2022 were still approximately 22% higher
than during 2021.

Market prices at the beginning of 2023 were still influenced by supply disruptions. However, pulp availability
started to improve significantly during the first quarter of 2023 as supply chain disruptions related to the
COVID-19 pandemic were resolved and additional pulp capacity hit the market. At the same time, demand
for pulp from the global, and specifically the European, paper industry deteriorated significantly. This quickly
led to pulp supply exceeding demand and, as a result, to a significant shift in market sentiment in the pulp
market. While prices for softwood pulp already started to decrease in the fourth quarter of 2022, prices for
hardwood pulp started to fall from record highs from February 2023 onwards. While the supply situation on
the market for softwood pulp was not as strong as for hardwood pulp, prices for softwood pulp were still
dragged down by the significant excess supply in the market for hardwood pulp. During the third quarter of
2023, demand for pulp from Asia slowly started to grow from low levels, which led to a reversal in the price
trend for pulp in the Asian market. However, pulp prices in Europe continued to decline during the entire
third quarter. By the end of the third quarter of 2023, prices for softwood pulp were approximately 19.8 %
lower than by the end of 2022, and prices for hardwood pulp decreased by approximately 40.6%. As with
pulp, weak demand for paper products also affected prices in the market for recovered paper. Even though
availability of recovered paper was not good with respect to absolute tons sold, it was still good enough to
exceed the demand for higher grades of recovered paper, which significantly impacted market prices. While
the impact on different grades of recovered paper varied based on varying market dynamics and timing, the
market for recovered paper generally experienced a significant downward correction during the nine-month
period ended September 30, 2023 from the record levels seen during the summer of 2022. The average purchase
price per ton we paid for recovered paper during the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023 was
approximately 30% lower than during the nine-month period ended September 30, 2022.

Historically, we have only been partially successful in passing the full costs of increased raw material prices on
to our customers. Since many of our customer contracts do not provide for automatic price adjustments,
there is typically a time lag between the time of any increases in underlying raw material costs and the time at
which we are able to renegotiate the prices our customers pay for our finished tissue products. Our sales
volumes are mainly subject to framework agreements with our retail customers, which allow those customers
to place orders “on demand” at prices that are fixed for the duration of the agreement. Although these
agreements generally do not contain minimum purchase obligations, we are in regular dialogue with our
customers and normally have reasonable visibility over sales volumes for the upcoming year. See, however,
“Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—COVID-19 Pandemic” above for the
unprecedented volatility in demand caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. To allow us to respond more quickly
to the extraordinary and ongoing volatility of our input costs caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and the war
in Ukraine, we negotiated significantly shorter contract cycles with many of our customers of approximately
3 to 4 months, compared to historic contract cycles of up to 12 to 18 months, although we have since extended
the duration of contracts again with certain of our customers to 3 to 6 months. With certain customers for


-----

which we are a “concept supplier”, in particular, we have also entered into longer-term agreements that contain
adaptive/index pricing mechanisms. See also “Business—Our Strategy—Partner of Choice for Our Customers”.

In order to limit our exposure to fluctuations in the price of pulp, our main raw material and largest purchasing
cost item, we have developed a specific hedging strategy which involves a multistage process designed to
separately address (i) fluctuations in the market price of pulp, as quoted in U.S. dollars as well as
(ii) fluctuations in the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar against the euro, our reporting currency and the
currency in which we generate most of our sales revenues.

Our Procurement department continuously monitors the market price development for pulp and, in close
coordination with our Treasury department and the newly introduced resilience management, typically tries
to lock in pulp prices (as quoted in U.S. dollars) with regard to up to two thirds of our projected pulp
requirements over a rolling 12 to 18-month period. We satisfy the balance of our pulp requirements at
prevailing market prices and by using spot opportunities.

Our Treasury department separately hedges our projected Group-wide U.S. dollar requirements, which
primarily relate to pulp purchases. Under the relevant internal Treasury guidelines, we try to lock in exchange
rates with regard to our projected U.S. dollar requirements on a rolling basis through a variety of different
hedging instruments, in particular through the use of forward contracts and options. In doing so, we take a
staggered approach, pursuant to which we hedge approximately 75% of our projected U.S. dollar requirements
over a rolling 12-month period (with up to 90% being hedged for the immediate short-term). We hedge a
lower percentage of our projected U.S. dollar requirements for periods more than 12 months in the future. We
satisfy the balance of our U.S. dollar requirements through the spot market.

Unlike for pulp, there are no derivative instruments available that would allow us to hedge our exposure to
fluctuations in the prices of the recovered paper grades we require. The only way to lock in recovered paper
prices is therefore via direct agreements with our recovered paper suppliers, which is regularly possible for
periods up to 3-4 months.

See also “Business—Our Strategy—Strong Commitment to Sustainability” below, on our efforts to strengthen
our operational and environmental resilience by investing in circular economy business models and
diversifying our fiber portfolio, including through new fiber product innovations based on miscanthus-based
and OCC-based tissue paper.

**Exposure to Fluctuations in Energy Prices**

Our production processes, in particular the production of de-inked pulp and the operation of our paper
machines, require large amounts of energy, in the form of electricity, natural gas and steam. Energy expenses
were our second largest procurement cost item in 2022 after the cost for pulp and amounted to €263.8 million,
or 24.2%, of our total cost of materials in 2022, €116.3 million, or 16.3%, in 2021, €76.8 million, or 11.3%, in
2020, and €172.7 million, or 22.2%, in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023.

The key drivers of our energy expenses are fluctuations of the market prices for energy, as well as regulatory
decisions. Our total energy expenses have increased during recent years, primarily as a result of higher
production capacities and rising market prices for electricity and natural gas. However, the volatility and
sharp increases in energy prices we experienced during 2021 and 2022, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic
and the war in Ukraine, were unprecedented.

In 2021, we experienced a previously unprecedented increase in energy market prices, a trend which accelerated
in the fourth quarter of 2021, i.e. even before the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. In particular,
natural gas, power, carbon emission allowances, crude oil and coal showed extreme gains and reached all-time
highs. Based on increased demand, deployed gas storages and concerns about sufficient supplies for the winter
season, spot prices for gas reached peak levels just before the holiday season and more than doubled during
the fourth quarter of 2021, compared to the start of the quarter, before falling back to their starting levels at
the end of 2021. Forward gas prices for supply in 2022 also doubled during the fourth quarter of 2021, before
dropping sharply at the end of the quarter to close approximately 50% above the price levels during the third
quarter of 2021, with markets expecting an improving supply situation for gas in the longer term. Prices for
carbon certificates also more than doubled during 2021. Market prices for electricity followed the trend for
gas and carbon and were additionally supported by concerns in relation to the reliability of the French nuclear
fleet as new security checks were announced by the responsible authorities. Electricity prices peaked just
before the Christmas holidays, with spot prices more than doubling compared to the start of the fourth
quarter of 2021, before falling again sharply at the end of the fourth quarter of 2021. Forward electricity


-----

prices for delivery in 2022 also dropped, but remained approximately 50% above electricity price levels at the
end of the third quarter of 2021.

Throughout 2022, global energy markets were strongly impacted by reduced supplies following the Russian
invasion of Ukraine, but other factors that impacted global energy prices in 2022 included the reopening of
China’s economy following the lifting of the rigid COVID-19 measures, rumors about OPEC’s exploration
strategy, general economic sluggishness and rising interest rates. Forward gas prices for delivery in 2023
reached a high of six times higher than January 2022 and in the fourth quarter of 2022 ended up approximately
50% higher than corresponding price in January 2022. Prices for carbon certificates in in the fourth quarter
2022 ended up at the same price levels they started at the beginning of 2022. Electricity prices followed the
trend for fuels and carbon with forward electricity prices for delivery in 2023 reaching a high of almost ten
times higher than in January 2023 and ending up slightly higher than corresponding prices at the beginning of
2022.

During the first half of 2023, prices for crude oil were volatile, but at levels comparable to those before the
Russian invasion of Ukraine. However, a combination of factors that included increasing demand, limited
global exploration, comparably low storage levels, hopes for a pause in the US Federal Reserve System`s (Fed)
interest rate hikes and fears about further OPEC+ exploration cuts led to a significant increase in crude oil
prices in the third quarter of 2023. Despite of significant reduced Norwegian pipeline gas flows due to
scheduled maintenance work overall gas supply was still comfortable. Sufficient LNG supplies and continued
subdued demand reduced supply risks for the winter season and resulted in gas storage levels which were well
above the regulatory requirements and the last five -years-average. While European CO2 prices increased in a
volatile market environment during the first quarter of 2023, prices remained broadly stable during the second
quarter of 2023 and declined during the third quarter, while remaining highly volatile. Electricity generation
was sufficient during the first nine months of 2023, and in combination with moderate weather conditions,
spot market prices for electricity declined during the first two quarters of 2023 and remained broadly stable
during the third quarter at normal volatility levels. As the outlook for industrial demand remains subdued
and the gas storage situation has further improved, forward prices for power came under significant pressure.
Prices for next year supply declined significantly especially for Germany and for France as expected availability
of French nuclear plants has improved. The Hamas terrorist attacks against Israel at the beginning of
October 2023 and the ongoing hostilities have raised concerns about a further escalation of the conflict and
lifted all energy market prices in the short term, although market prices for energy have already fallen again.
As the supply of oil and gas was not significantly impacted as of the date of this offering memorandum, price
levels were almost back to pre-conflict levels, although the risk of new price increases certainly remains high.

In particular, in our core market of Germany, energy prices have also been strongly impacted by regulatory
decisions related to the so-called “energy transition” (Energiewende). This revised energy policy focuses on
promoting the development of renewable energy sources, resulted in the complete cessation of the production
of nuclear power by early 2023 and will also lead to a gradual reduction of coal fired power generation to
reach the German carbon reduction targets. Similar policies are being implemented at an EU level. To mitigate
the impact of the significant upwards pressure on electricity prices for energy-intensive industries, the German
Government (as well as other national governments) adopted rules that provided for various businesses,
including the Wepa Group, to be reimbursed for certain infrastructure investment surcharges necessary for
the implementation of the “Energiewende”. As the relevant rules have already been modified several times in
the past we expect further modifications and challenging conditions to continue to benefit from current
accommodations, reimbursement rules and/or energy tax refund schemes. See also “Risk Factors—Risks
_related to our Business—If the cost of key raw materials and energy increases, we may not be able to pass these_
_increased costs on to our customers in full”._

We attempt to limit our exposure to the volatility of electricity and gas prices through structurally adaptive
risk management measures as well as by covering parts of our projected energy requirements through fixed
future contracts. These contracts are entered into by different entities within the Wepa Group, mostly at the
local level, and have varying starting dates and durations. We usually take a staggered approach, pursuant to
which we hedge approximately 0% to 90% of our projected requirements over a 36-month period. In Italy, we
are part of an industrial syndicate which manages energy supply issues and the related regulatory issues for its
members. This includes locking in prices for a portion of projected energy requirements in coordination
between all syndicate members subject to market price developments. At our site in Giershagen, Germany,
approximately 33% of our electric power and almost 100% of our steam requirements for this site are provided
by Wepa Kraftwerk GmbH (“WKG”), a subsidiary of the Issuer operating a power plant which uses the
residual materials from our recycling processes in Arnsberg and Giershagen as a source of thermal energy.


-----

**Exposure to Fluctuations in Freight/Logistics Costs**

Our production operations require us to coordinate and monitor complex logistics processes between each
step of our internal value chain and our production processes to ensure the efficient flow of materials and
products. This includes the shipment of jumbo reels between production sites as well as the shipment of our
finished products to our customers. We meet our freight and logistics requirements mainly through the use of
external logistics companies. Due to the relatively large size and weight of our products compared to value,
freight and logistics expenses play an important role in our business, and fluctuations in freight prices can
have a significant impact on our profitability.

The continuous optimization of our logistics flows and freight costs has therefore been, and will continue to
be a key focus supply of our investment program. See “Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results
_of Operations—COVID-19 Pandemic” above with regard to the special logistics challenges as well as limited_
availability of pallets and freight capacity caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

**Exposure to Exchange Rate Fluctuations**

Given the growing geographic spread of our operations, we are increasingly exposed to currency exchange
rate fluctuations. We are particularly exposed to fluctuations in the exchange rates of the Polish zloty and the
British pound to the euro. For the first nine months ended September 30, 2023, 4.6% and 14.2% of our total
sales derived from sales in Polish zloty and British pounds, respectively. As a result of our recent investments
into a new paper machine and a new converting line at our production site in Piechowice, Poland as well as
our investments into our newest paper machine in Bridgend, United Kingdom, our exposure to both Polish
zloty and British pounds has increased further. Considering the expected growth rates of the British tissue
market as well as our plans to continue developing and optimizing our operations at our Bridgend site, we
expect our exposure in British pounds, in particular, to gradually increase over the coming years. See also
“—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of our Results of Operations—Expansion Projects and Investment
_Program; Sustainable Capacity Management” above._

We proactively monitor and assess the development of the exchange rates of the Polish zloty and the British
pound against the euro, and we have implemented adaptive risk management measures with regard to our
related exchange rate risks. Currently, we target a staggered hedge ratio from 0.0% to 80.0% of our exposure
to exchange rate fluctuations between the euro and the Polish zloty derived from our projected PLN revenues
over a 30-month period. A similar policy is also applied to the hedging of exchange rate fluctuations between
the euro and the British pound. To track the effectiveness of our risk management we have implemented
several controlling and reporting instruments, which enable us to routinely analyze our overall hedging
strategy. We do not currently hedge our exposure related to the PLN-denominated intra-group loans to our
Polish subsidiary, but intend to regularly re-evaluate this policy based on an ongoing assessment of any further
volatility in the exchange rate of the Polish zloty against euro.

Even if we do take further hedging measures in the future, there can be no guarantee that such measures will
be effective. As a result, fluctuations in the value of the Polish zloty, the British pound or other local currencies
against the euro have had, and may increasingly have in the future, a significant effect on our operations and
on our reported results in euro, and the comparability of our performance between financial periods can be
significantly affected by fluctuations in local currencies against the euro.

In addition, fluctuations in the exchange rate between the euro and the U.S. dollar can also have a significant
impact on our profitability. While the prices of some of our raw materials such as pulp and oil (which affect
our energy costs, freight costs and auxiliary costs such as packaging materials) are quoted in U.S. dollars in
international markets, we primarily generate our sales revenues in euros, Polish zloty and British pound.
Therefore, a weakening of the U.S. dollar compared to these currencies will generally have a positive impact
on our results, while a strengthening of the U.S. dollar against these currencies will generally have a negative
impact on our results.

Assuming a hypothetical pulp price of U.S.$600 per ton and an exchange rate of U.S.$1.10 per €1.00, a
fluctuation in the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar and the euro by U.S.$0.01 would result in a price increase or
decrease of approximately €4.96 per ton of pulp. Given that we consumed approximately 572,000 tons of
pulp in 2022, each U.S.$0.01 in exchange rate movement would have had an impact on our purchasing costs
for pulp of approximately €2.84 million, assuming we had not hedged our exposure to exchange rate
fluctuations. For information on our U.S. dollar-related hedging measures, see “—Exposure to Fluctuations in
_Pulp and Recovered Paper Prices”._


-----

**Expansion Projects and Investment Program; Sustainable Capacity Management**

Sharply rising raw material and freight costs and high energy prices not only pose a challenge for our Group,
but for our entire industry. We are therefore convinced that the continuous, incremental strategic development
of our asset base remains key to our continued success as a leading, cost efficient tissue producer in Europe.
This involves targeted expansion investments and sustainable capacity management measures intended to
drive further cost reductions, portfolio optimization, efficiency improvements and active working capital
management. To further strengthen our market position and competitiveness as the third largest producer in
the European tissue paper market and as part of our sustainable capacity management, we therefore
implemented a number of strategic capital expenditure projects between 2020 and 2023, notwithstanding the
special challenges we faced as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine. This included the
decision to invest in two new paper machines at our sites in Piechowice, Poland and Bridgend, United
Kingdom as well as in new converting lines at our manufacturing sites in Piechowice, Swalmen, Bridgend,
Giershagen, Lille, Troyes, Leuna and Kriebstein. In total, our capital expenditures amounted to €95.5 million
in 2020, €123.8 million in 2021, €61.6 million in 2022 and €35.1 in the first nine months of 2023. These
amounts included (i) investments in our two newest paper machines in Piechowice, Poland and Bridgend,
United Kingdom of €41.5 million in 2020, €57.8 million in 2021, €20.8 million in 2022 and €1.7 million in the
first nine months of 2023, (ii) investments in new converting capacities and stock preparation projects of
€19.4 million in 2020, €49.7 million in 2021, €25.0 million in 2022 and €8.4 in the first nine months of 2023, as
well as (iii) maintenance capital expenditures of €34.7 million in 2020, €16.3 million in 2021, €15.7 million in
2022 and €25.0 in the first nine months of 2023.

We started up our new paper machine and two new converting lines at our plant in Piechowice, Poland at the
end of September 2021. The new paper machine, which can process pulp as well as up to 100% recovered fiber,
replaced an old crepe machine we dismantled in the autumn of 2020. With an average operating capacity of
approximately 34,000 tons per year, the new paper machine increased the output of our manufacturing site at
Piechowice to approximately 65,000 tons of raw paper per year, strengthening our Professional business unit
and its market base in Eastern Europe. In addition, we commissioned two new converting lines for paper
towels and toilet paper at our site at Piechowice. These investments led to further improvements in machine
efficiency, sustainability and cost reduction, with regard to energy, raw materials and maintenance. Our total
investments into the new paper machine and two converting lines at Piechowice amounted to a combined
total of €41.5 million between 2020 and 2022.

Our newest paper machine at Bridgend, United Kingdom, with state-of-the-art technology and a planned
annual production capacity of 65,000 tons, commenced production in June 2022, more than doubling our
tissue paper production capacity in the United Kingdom and creating more than 50 new jobs. Despite Brexit,
the United Kingdom remains an important growth market for us, and the investment in state-of-the-art
technology is an important part of our strategy for “future-proofing” our business. We believe that the
increased tissue paper production capacity and modern technology of our new paper machine will enable us
to meet the expectations of our customers with regard to product quality, sustainability, reliability and cost
leadership even better. With the startup of our new paper machine in Bridgend, United Kingdom, we
eliminated the need to purchase jumbo reels in the UK market. We believe this positions us well for potential
future growth of our business in the UK and generally significantly strengthens our competitive position in
the UK market, in addition to achieving significant savings in energy, raw material and maintenance costs. We
see a potential to establish a clear leadership platform for Private Label quality in the UK market and at the
same time the possibility to move the Group into the lowest quartile cost segment in the UK, making our
business cost competitive across all quality segments. Our total investment into the new paper machine at
Bridgend, United Kingdom, amounted to a combined total of €96.9 million complemented by a €14.9 million
investment into two new converting lines between 2020 and 2023.

To be the partner of choice for our customers, we may make additional investments to expand and strengthen
our regional footprint, either in the form of investment into new or expanded production facilities or
opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions. Due to the consolidation amongst European retail groups, it has become
even more important that we can supply our customers across their respective markets. We want to be able to
offer our customers customized solutions for their own brands in all markets they operate within, including
bespoke specifications, qualities and price mechanisms. We therefore continue to carefully assess potential
bolt-on acquisitions from time to time, not only to be able to match the pan-European footprints of our
customers, but also to potentially acquire attractive customer bases, to further broaden our portfolio and/or
to leverage our asset base. See also “Business—Strategy—Partner of Choice for our Customers”. To meet our
sustainability goals, including environmental protection, fiber diversification, increased competitiveness,
regulatory compliance, and to take advantage of sustainable growth opportunities, we further plan to develop
an investment roadmap to identify how we can “future proof” our business, for example, by (i) increasing our


-----

use of renewable energy and reducing our reliance on conventional sources of energy, in particular gas,
(ii) improving and securing our access to “future fibers” and/or (iii) by further integrating circular economy
aspects into our production processes and product life cycles. See also “Business—Continuous Striving for
_Efficiency through Cost and Technology Leadership” above. In this regard, we expect to benefit from proposed_
future investments outside the Group by our Parent in complementary business areas such as renewable
energy, alternative fibers and circular economy business models.

In an opportunistic transaction that allowed us to acquire additional hygiene paper volumes with existing
Wepa customers, we further acquired the former Victor Güthoff Group, including 55 employees, in
October 2020 and integrated the hygiene paper activities of the acquired business, which represented the vast
part of the activities of the Victor Güthoff Group, into our existing organization. We then rebranded the
remaining business activities of the former Victor Güthoff Group “WEPA Category Solutions” with a view
to potentially retaining them and diversifying our business by offering our customers a broader range of select
products in the cleaning, foil and packaging sector, such as wipes, cleaning cloths for glasses, biodegradable
waste bags and cling bags. However, we are currently in the process of disposing of some of these non-core
activities, in particular an aluminum foil business.

On June 1, 2023, we acquired a stock preparation unit (used for the preparation of de-inked pulp from
recovered paper) located in close proximity to our tissue paper manufacturing site in Kriebstein, Germany
from the insolvent Kübler & Niethammer Papierfabrik Kriebstein GmbH. In addition to the asset acquisition,
we also took on 40 employees from Kübler & Niethammer Papierfabrik Kriebstein GmbH. Our
manufacturing site in Kriebstein is our European competence center for folded products. By integrating the
newly acquired stock preparation into our operations at Kriebstein, we believe we have generated synergies
for our manufacturing sites at Kriebstein and Leuna (Germany) and Piechowice (Poland) with regard to
efficiency and cost savings, as well as increased flexibility for the Group. With this latest investment, we believe
we further strengthen our strategic orientation and focus on sustainability as well as our long-term competitive
position. The purchase price for this acquisition amounted to €3.6 million.

**KEY STATEMENT OF INCOME ITEMS**

The following is a description of certain line items in our consolidated results of operations.

**Sales**

Sales include income derived from the sale of finished products both in our Consumer business unit and in
our Professional business unit as well as income from the sale of semi-finished products such as jumbo reels
and de-inked pulp. We report sales as sales in Germany and foreign sales revenue, respectively, based on the
invoicing entity within the Wepa Group. As a result, this geographic split does not reflect the location of our
customers or the location of production. Sales also reflect sales reductions like bonuses, cash discounts to
customers or advertising subsidies.

**Increase or decrease of inventory of finished and semi-finished products**

Our increase or decrease of inventory of finished and semi-finished products records the change in stocks of
finished and semi-finished products at manufacturing cost. The manufacturing costs include direct material
and labor costs as well as material and production overheads allocated proportionally on the assumption of
normal utilization of production capacity.

**Other internally produced and capitalized assets**

Other internally produced and capitalized assets during the periods under review relate to the construction of
our newest paper machine at our manufacturing site in Bridgend, United Kingdom. In connection with the
implementation of this latest paper machine project, several employees from Wepa UK Ltd., from Wepa
entities other than Wepa UK Ltd. as well as external consultants assisted with the implementation of the
project, and we capitalized the related costs.

**Other operating income**

Other operating income consists of all income from business activities not already recognized under other
income items. Other operating income includes, among other items, income from the release of provisions,
income from insurance refunds from damage events and income from the disposal of assets. In addition,
other operating income includes income from other periods (e.g. reimbursements in relation to energy matters


-----

as well as an appreciation in value of current assets related to our spare part inventories) and income from
exchange rate differences.

**Costs of materials**

The costs of materials consist of cost of raw materials, supplies and purchased goods such as pulp and
recovered paper, costs of chemicals, costs for auxiliary material as well as pallet costs. It also includes
third-party service costs (including energy used, cost of waste disposal and maintenance) and purchased
goods.

**Personnel expense**

Personnel expense includes all expenses for wages and salaries (including bonuses) and other employment
benefits, contributions to pension plans and social security contributions. Personnel costs also include the
costs of redundancy and partial retirement agreements.

**Other operating expenses**

Other operating expenses primarily include freight costs, expenses for external labor and other third party
services, expenses from exchange rate differences, expenses for management services from Wepa SE, expenses
from other periods, IT cost, legal and auditing charges as well as expenses for insurance, mandatory
contributions to the German recycling scheme (Grüner Punkt), security services, rent and leasing. Other
operating expenses may also include extraordinary items that consist of business activities outside our core
business activities and which have an exceptional importance and/or result in exceptional amounts. Freight
costs consist primarily of transportation costs to our customers and company internal transfers of finished
and semi-finished goods, but also include warehouse costs.

**Amortization and depreciation**

We incur expense for amortization and depreciation of intangible assets and property, plant and equipment
as a result of both scheduled depreciation and impairment losses on these assets. Amortization and
depreciation are usually charged on a straight-line basis over the expected useful life of the assets.

**Interest income/(expenses), net**

Interest income/(expenses), net includes income from loans under financial assets, other interest and similar
income, interest and similar expenses as well as income from disposal of financial assets and amortization of
financial assets. Interest and similar expenses primarily include interest expense and other financing costs
related to the Existing Notes, long-term loans, short-term bank liabilities, bank and bank guarantee provisions
and transaction costs for our ABS Program.

**Taxes**

Taxes comprise income taxes such as trade taxes, corporate taxes, foreign taxes and deferred taxes as well as
other taxes, such as taxes on substance (mainly real estate taxes in France and Italy) and energy taxes.

**_Sales_**

Total sales increased by €228.7 million, or 19.8%, from €1,153.3 million in the nine-month period ended
September 30, 2022 to €1,382.1 million in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023. This increase in
total sales was primarily attributable to the carry-over of incremental price increases which we negotiated with
our customers during the course of 2022, based on the substantial cost increases for input materials, especially
energy, during the course of 2022. See also “Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Exposure to
_Fluctuations in Pulp and Recovered Paper Prices”, “—Exposure to Fluctuations in Energy Prices” and_
“—Exposure to Fluctuations in Freight/Logistics Costs” above. During the first nine months ended
September 30, 2023, the average sales price of our finished products was approximately 21.2% higher
compared to the average sales price during the first nine months ended September 30, 2022, even though sales
prices did start to decline throughout 2023 following recent input price decreases, albeit with a significant
time lag. In addition, sales volumes of finished products increased by 17,000 tons, or 3.2%, from 524,000 tons
in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2022 to 541,000 tons in the nine-month period ended
September 30, 2023, due to a growth in customer demand in both our Consumer and Professional
business units. External sales volumes of semi-finished products decreased by about 14,000 tons, or 21%, from
67,000 tons in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2022 to 53,000 tons in the nine-month period
ended September 30, 2023, primarily because of higher internal needs in converting of finished products and
a reduced demand for de-inked pulp from the graphic paper industry.

**_Sales_**

Total sales increased significantly by €430.5 million, or 35.7%, from €1,205.9 million in 2021 to
€1,636.4 million in 2022. This significant increase in total sales was primarily attributable to multiple,
incremental price increases for our finished and semi-finished products we managed to negotiate with our
customers and implement in response to significant market-driven price increases for our main inputs,
especially energy prices. See also “Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Exposure to Fluctuations
_in Energy Prices”and “Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Russia-Ukraine_
_Conflict, Supply Shortages and Cost Inflation” above. As a result, the average sales price of finished products_
increased by 34.4% in 2022 compared to 2021, the average sales price of jumbo reels increased by 66.0% and
the average sales price for de-inked pulp by 14.3%. Total sales volume of finished products increased by 26,000
tons or 3.8%, from 681,000 tons in 2021 to 707,000 tons in 2022, mainly due to a normalization in demand in
both our Consumer and Professional business units, with the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic slowly
receding during the course of 2022. See also “Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of
_Operations—COVID-19 Pandemic” above. However, sales in 2022 were also negatively impacted by volume_
losses of approximately 20,000 tons as a consequence of technical delivery issues caused by a 2022 Cyber
Attack. In addition, sales volumes of semi-finished products decreased by 37,000 tons or 32.2%, from 115,000
tons in 2021 to 78,000 tons in 2022, as we made a strategic decision to reduce sales of semi-finished products
to third parties to enable us to increase our inventory of jumbo reels as a hedge against anticipated disruptions
to production related to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, including the possibility of a gas embargo and gas
shortages during the winter period of 2022.

Russian invasion of Ukraine, as described above. In addition, the significant increase in our finished and
semi-finished inventories during 2022 also reflected the significant increase in the relevant market prices over
the course of 2022. Generally, our inventory levels are influenced by both short term factors, such as special
promotion measures and inventory management measures taken by our key customers, and long term factors,
such as increases or decrease in sales as well as expansion projects and our investment program.

Cost of materials increased substantially by €376.7 million, or 52.7%, from €714.1 million in 2021 (59.2% of
sales, or 59.1% of total operating performance) to €1,090.8 million in 2022 (66.7% of sales, or 64.2% of total
operating performance). This cost increase was primarily related to market price inflation especially with
regard to our raw materials and energy. The increase in the cost of raw materials, supplies and purchased
goods by €225.9 million, or 40.9%, from €552.2 million in 2021 to €778.1 million in 2022, mainly resulted
from an increase in our pulp costs by 65.4% in 2022 compared to 2021, following (i) a significant increase in
the average price per ton for pulp in 2022 as well as (ii) additional pulp consumption due to the start-up of our
newest paper machine at our manufacturing site at Bridgend, United Kingdom, in May 2022. In addition,
costs for recovered paper increased by €11.1 million, or 12.1%, from €91.6 million in 2021 to €102.7 million in
2022, and packaging costs increased by €24.3 million, or 35.3%, from €68.8 million in 2021 to €93.1 million in
2022. The cost of raw materials, supplies and purchased goods increased substantially by 40.9% in 2022
compared to 2021, due to significant increases in the average price per ton for pulp and recovered paper. The
average pulp price per ton we paid in 2022 increased by 32.3%, from €487 in 2021 to €644 in 2022, mainly due
to inflated market prices for pulp, resulting in increasing pulp costs of €80.4 million, while the average price
for recovered paper increased by 26.6% from €205 per ton in 2021 to €260 per ton in 2022, leading to a


-----

recovered paper cost increase of €24.3 million. See also “Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—
_Exposure to Fluctuations in Pulp and Recovered Paper Prices” above._

In 2022, our consumption of pulp increased by 60,000 tons compared to 2021, primarily due to additional
pulp consumption as a result of the start-up of our newest paper machine at our manufacturing site at
Bridgend, United Kingdom, in May 2022, which resulted in increased pulp costs of €38.6 million in 2022. By
contrast, our consumption of recovered paper decreased by 51,000 tons in 2022 mainly due to reduced
production for external sale of our semi-finished product de-inked pulp. The lower consumption resulted in
reduced recovered paper costs of €13.3 million.

Third party service costs increased substantially by €150.8 million, or 93.1% in 2022, primarily due to an
increase of energy expenses by €147.5 million, or 126.7%, from €116.3 million in 2021 to €263.8 million in
2022 as a result of the significant market price increases for electricity and gas seen during 2022. Cost for
electricity increased by €59.8 million, or 105.7% from €56.5 million in 2021 to €116.3 million in 2022, cost for
gas by €70.1 million, or 152.7% from €45.9 million in 2021 to €116.0 million in 2022 and cost for steam by
€14.8 million, or 108.5% from €13.7 million in 2021 to €28.5 million in 2022. As a percentage of our total
operating performance, cost of purchased services increased by 5.0%, as increases in the sales prices for our
finished products largely compensated the significant increases in energy market price during the period.

Other operating expenses increased by €49.1 million, or 23.3%, from €210.8 million in 2021 to €259.9 million
in 2022. This increase was primarily due to an increase of freight costs by €15.5 million, or 13.9%, from
€111.5 million in 2021 to €127.0 million in 2022, mainly resulting from higher diesel prices, a higher market
demand for truck transportation and an increase in the sales of our finished products. Cost of third party
services increased by €1.8 million, or 12.0%, from €15.4 million in 2021 to €17.2 million in 2022, primarily
reflecting higher external personnel expenses in the areas of production, warehousing and internal logistics.
Expenses from exchange rate differences increased by €12.0 million, from €3.5 million in 2021 to €15.5 million
in 2022, primarily related to transactions in Polish Złoty and British Pounds, both including realized and
unrealized exchange rate losses, the latter in relation to the conversion of foreign currency balance sheet
liabilities into the relevant reporting currency. However, the increase in expenses from exchange rate differences
was largely offset by a corresponding income from exchange rate difference during the same period as
described under “other operating income” above. Expenses from other periods also increased by €2.4 million,
or 122.8%, from €2.0 million in 2021 to €4.4 million in 2022, mainly related to energy and valuation impacts
on spare part stocks related to other periods. Insurance expenses increased by €1.3 million, or 25.6%, from
€5.1 million in 2021 to €6.4 million in 2022 and intercompany other expenses increased by €2.2 million, or
23.0%, from €9.4 million in 2021 to €11.6 million in 2022, mainly as a result of higher management services
rendered by our parent WEPA SE. Other operating expenses in 2022 also include €3.8 million of extraordinary
expenses, mainly due to extraordinary expenses in relation to the 2022 Cyber Attack and expenses related to
a successful refinancing of our Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility and our ABS Program we completed in
2022. The increase in “others” of €10.5 million, from €34.1 million in 2021 to €44.6 million in 2022, among
other items, reflects (i) an increase in expenses for repair and spare parts of vehicles of €0.9 million, or 40.8%,
from €2.2 million in 2021 to €3.1 million in 2022, (ii) an increase in maintenance expenses on buildings of
€1.3 million, or 171.3%, from €0.8 million in 2021 to €2.1 million in 2022 and (iii) an increase in contract
penalties of €1.5 million, or 120.6%, from €1.3 million in 2021 to €2.8 million in 2022.

**_Sales_**

Total sales decreased by €48.4 million, or 3.9%, from €1,254.3 million in 2020 to €1,205.9 million in 2021.
During the same period, sales volumes of finished products decreased by 60,000 tons or 8.1%, from 741,000
tons in 2020 to 681,000 tons in 2021, mainly due to lower demand for finished products, especially in the first
quarter of 2021, as some retailers, in particular in Germany, had pursued a policy of high stock levels and
filled up their warehouses with various branded products from Eastern Europe and Russia in the fourth
quarter of 2020 in order to be prepared for further panic buying. See “Key Factors Affecting the Comparability
_of our Results of Operations—COVID-19 Pandemic”above. In addition, due to steep decreases in raw material_
prices in 2020, we faced strong pressure from our customers to reduce the prices for our products in almost all
regions, which resulted in price reductions in the third quarter of 2020. As a result, the average sales prices of
our finished products was 0.7% lower in 2021, compared to 2020. Sales of semi-finished products, on the
other hand, increased by 35,000 tons or 44.5%, from 80,000 tons in 2020 to 115,000 tons in 2021. Non-tissue
sales also increased in 2021, primarily as a result of the acquisition of the former Victor Güthoff Group (now
WEPA Category Solutions) in October 2020. See “Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—
_Expansion Projects and Investment Program; Sustainable Capacity Management”._

we paid in 2021 increased by 7.7%, from €452 in 2020 to €487 in 2021, mainly due to market price increases,
which was largely offset by our hedging in 2021, while the average price for recovered paper increased by
31.7% from €156 per ton in 2020 to €205 per ton in 2021, due to strong market price increases for all grades,
reinforced by lower availability of recovered paper. See also “Key Factors Affecting Our Results of
_Operations—Exposure to Fluctuations in Pulp and Recovered Paper Prices” above. Despite the increase in the_
average pulp price per ton we paid in 2021 compared to 2020, our pulp costs decreased by €17.0 million in
2021 due to the release of accruals for impending losses from pulp hedging positions we established in prior
periods. Our consumption of pulp decreased slightly by 1,000 tons from 513,000 tons in 2020 to 512,000 tons
in 2021. In addition, our consumption of recovered paper decreased by 24,000 tons from 470,000 tons in 2020
to 446,000 tons in 2021, driven by lower paper making output in 2021.

and unrealized exchange rate losses, the latter in relation to the conversion of foreign currency balance sheet
liabilities into the relevant reporting currency. Expenses from other periods also decreased by €0.8 million, or
30.0%, from €2.8 million in 2020 to €2.0 million in 2021. These expenses include several smaller expense items,
such as mandatory contributions related to the German national packaging recycling scheme “Grüner Punkt”
as well as consultancy and maintenance expenses attributable to the period of 2020. In addition, we recorded
significant extraordinary expenses of €4.3 million in 2020 in connection with portfolio and cost optimization
measures we implemented in Italy as well as refinancing expenses related to the tap offering of €50 million of
our Existing Fixed Rate Notes in the first quarter of 2020.

**LIQUIDITY AND CAPITALIZATION**

**Overview**

Our primary sources of financing are cash generated from our operating activities, the Existing Notes,
borrowings under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility, our ABS Program and bank loans of individual


-----

subsidiaries. We utilize cash primarily for debt and tax servicing requirements, the purchase of raw materials,
freight and energy, working capital, personnel expenses and capital expenditures.

Our ability to generate cash from our operating activities depends on our operating performance, which is in
turn dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other
factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed under “Risk Factors”. In
addition, we will only be able to draw the full commitments under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility
if, among other things, we meet the financial covenants set out in the facility agreement relating thereto. See
“Description of Other Indebtedness—Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility”.

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with the proceeds from
the Offering, capacity under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility, our ABS Program, bank loans of
individual subsidiaries and cash and cash equivalents, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and
debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating
activities or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to
pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs. Our ability to generate cash
from operating activities depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some
extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See
“Risk Factors”.

If our future cash flows from operating activities and other capital resources (including borrowings under our
current or any future credit facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our
liquidity needs, we may be forced to:

- reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures;

- sell certain of our assets;

- obtain additional debt or equity financing; or

- restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.

We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on
satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of the Notes and any future debt may limit our ability to
pursue any of these alternatives.

However, we believe that our short- to medium-term hedging measures, our ability to preserve cash in the
mid-term through the adaptation of the amount of our controlled capital expenditures, a stable financing
structure and long term improvements to our profitability and cash generation put us in a strong financial
position and give us significant flexibility to weather and/or adapt to challenges that may face us or our
industry as a whole (e.g. rapid increases in energy costs or raw material prices or increased competition).
