_Cash flow from operating activities_

In the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023, cash flow from operating activities increased by
€123.3 million, or 512.9%, from €24.0 million in the nine month period ended September 30, 2022 to
€147.4 million in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023. This increase was primarily due to the
€172.7 million, or 272.6%, EBITDA increase, from €63.4 million in the nine-month period ended
September 30, 2022 to €236.0 million in the nine month period ended September 30, 2023, mainly driven by
our ability to maintain higher sales pricing for our finished products at prices negotiated toward the end of
2022, based on the then-peak market prices for our input factors, while the market prices for our input factors
decreased significantly in 2023. However, the change in inventories, trade receivables and other assets of
€64.6 million, from an increase of €111.6 million in the nine month period ended September 30, 2022 to a
further increase €46.9 million in the nine month period ended September 30, 2023 created a negative impact
on the cash flow from operating activities, mainly driven by an increase in on-balance trade receivables due to
a reduced utilization of our ABS Program, partly offset by a reduction in gross trade receivables. In addition,
in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023, our inventory levels of raw and auxiliary materials
increased due to pulp volumes purchased at low-priced spot market for consumption in the following period,
partly offset by reduced stocks of semi-finished products. Furthermore, the change in trade payables and
other liabilities of €(68.8) million, from an increase of €34.5 million in the nine-month period ended
September 30, 2022 to a decrease of €34.3 million in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023 had a
negative impact on our cash flow from operating activities driven by lower trade payables, mainly due to
deflation effects and lower liabilities to shareholders. This was partly compensated by the increase in provisions
of €12.0 million in the nine month period ended September 30, 2023, mainly related to tax, anticipated losses,
personnel and energy. Our cash flow from operating activities in the nine-month period ended September 30,
2023 included income tax payments of €9.6 million compared to income tax payments of €5.1 million in the
nine-month period ended September 30, 2022.

In 2022, cash flow from operating activities decreased significantly by €80.4 million, or 51.4%, from
€156.3 million in 2021 to €75.9 million in 2022. The EBITDA contribution increased by €52.5 million, or
56.4% from €93.1 million in 2021 to €145.6 million in 2022, as we managed to successfully negotiate significant
consecutive increases for our finished and semi-finished products with our customers in response to increasing
market cost levels for our raw materials, packaging material, transportation as well as the tremendous price
hike in energy. We further succeeded in shortening contract cycles with our customers and took various
measures to enhance the energy efficiency of our production to allow us to respond more quickly to the
ongoing volatility of our input costs. However, the increase in inventories, trade receivables and other assets
of €196.7 million, from a decrease of €64.5 million in 2021 to an increase of €132.2 million in 2022 created a
negative impact on the cash flow from operating activities, mainly driven by the build-up of finished product
stocks to return to target levels after a demand peak end of 2021, as described above. In addition, trade
receivables were on a significantly elevated level due to a stronger demand and materialization of sales price
increases, though partly compensated by a higher utilization of our ABS Program. This was partly
compensated by the change in provisions of €61.5 million from a decrease of €22.8 million in 2021 to an
increase of €38.7 million in 2022 mainly due to increased provisions for energy, personnel and anticipated
losses. Furthermore the change in increase in trade payables and other liabilities of €3.3 million, from
€36.9 million in 2021 to €40.1 million in 2022 had a positive impact on the cash flow from operating activities,
driven by higher trade payables, mainly due to inflation effects, and higher other liabilities, related to our ABS
Program and higher liabilities to shareholders.

In 2021, our cash flow from operating activities increased by €84.4 million, or 117.3%, from €71.9 million in
2020 to €156.3 million in 2021. This increase was primarily driven by a change of €116.4 million in inventories,
trade receivables and other assets from decrease of €51.9 million in 2020 to an increase of €64.5 million in
2021 primarily due to lower receivables mainly caused by a higher utilization of the ABS Program to interim
finance capital expenditures projects which were part of our strategic investment program approved in 2020,
such as two new paper machines located at our manufacturing sites in Piechowice and Bridgend as well as the
investment in new converting lines at sites in Bridgend, Troyes, Lille, Giershagen, Leuna, Kriebstein,
Piechowice and Swalmen. Furthermore, cash flow from operating activities benefited from a change in trade
payables and other liabilities of €66.3 million, from a decrease of €29.4 million in 2020 to an increase of
€36.9 million in 2021. These increases were partly offset by a €77.1 million, or 45.3% decrease in EBITDA,
from €170.1 million in 2020 to €93.1 million in 2021, mainly driven by a decrease in net sales of €48.4 million,
or 3.9%, from €1,254.3 million in 2020 to €1,205.9 million in 2021 mainly due to lower demand for finished
products especially in the first quarter of 2021 as consequence of high stocks at our customers resulting from
stronger purchase in the fourth quarter of 2020 and ongoing regulations in the public sector due to the
COVID-19 pandemic as well as higher material costs which increased from 54.2% of sales in 2020 to 59.2% of


-----

sales in 2021. The increase in percentage cost of material in relation of sales revenue resulted from strong and
sudden market price increases especially for our raw materials, energy and transportation costs while, based
on tender maturities applied in 2020 and early 2021, our selling prices adapted to the higher input costs with
delay. In addition, a €30.2 million change in provisions from an increase of €7.4 million in 2020 to a decrease
of €22.8 million in 2021 as well as a €4.3 million decrease in expenses for extraordinary items, from €4.3 million
in 2020 to nil in 2021, which related to our exit from crepe paper production in 2020, had a negative impact on
cash flow from operating activities.

to production related to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, as described above. In addition, our finished and

_Cash flow from investing activities_

Cash flow from investing activities generally consists of cash outflows for investments in tangible and
intangible assets, payments to acquire entities included in the basis of consolidation, payments to acquire
long term financial assets as well as cash inflows from the disposal of fixed assets and financial assets, interest
and dividends received.

In the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023, our cash outflow from investing activities decreased by
€22.8 million, or 41.0%, from €55.7 million in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2022 to
€32.9 million in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023. The significantly higher cash outflows
from investment activities in the nine-month period ended September 30, 2022 was primarily due to capital
expenditures related to our strategic investment activities under our sustainable capacity management program
as described in more detail under “Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of our Results of Operations—
_Expansion Projects and Investment Program; Sustainable Capacity Management” above. In addition, low_
project investment activities especially during the first half-year 2023 were due to cautious investment
approvals in the prior year to preserve liquidity in response to the difficult operating environment and
performance.

In 2022, our cash outflow from investing activities decreased by €61.8 million, or 50.4%, from €122.6 million
in 2021 to €60.8 million in 2022. Cash outflows from investing activities in 2022 related primarily to our
standard maintenance investments, investments in energy efficiency (“Bluetec”) and the completion of our
strategic investment program initiated in 2020. In 2021, our cash outflow from investing activities increased
by €28.5 million, or 30.2%, from €94.1 million in 2020 to €122.6 million in 2021. This increase was primarily
due to higher strategic investment activities. While we reduced non-critical maintenance expenditure to
preserve liquidity in response to the difficult operating environment and performance, we resumed certain
strategic investment projects which included two new paper machines located at our manufacturing sites in
Piechowice and Bridgend as well as the investment in new converting lines at sites in Bridgend, Troyes, Lille,
Giershagen, Leuna, Kriebstein, Piechowice and Swalmen.

For more information about our capital expenditures, see also “Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of our
_Results of Operations—Expansion Projects and Investment Program; Sustainable Capacity Management”_
above “ and “—Capital Expenditures” below.

_Free cash flow_

We define “free cash flow” as the sum of cash flow from operating activities and cash flow from investing
activities. Free cash flow comprises the cash surplus or deficit after expenditure on investments and taxes but
before net cash used in/provided by financing activities and before taking into account cash proceeds and
payments relating to shareholders’ equity and financial liabilities. The reasons for changes in the free cash
flow are therefore the same as explained above. In the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023, our free
cash flow increased significantly by €146.1 million from a cash outflow of €31.6 million in the nine month
period ended September 30, 2022, to a cash inflow of €114.5 million in the nine-month period ended
September 30, 2023. In 2022, our free cash flow decreased by €18.6 million from a cash inflow of €33.7 million
in 2021 to a cash inflow of €15.2 million for 2022. In 2021, our free cash flow increased by €55.9 million or
from a cash outflow of €22.2 million in 2020 to a cash inflow of €33.7 million in 2021.

We believe that the continuous, step-by-step strategic development of our asset base remains key to our
continued success as a leading, cost efficient tissue producer in Europe. This involves investments in sustainable
capacity management measures intended to drive further cost reductions, portfolio optimization, efficiency
improvements and working capital reductions.

As part of this sustainable capacity management and to further strengthen our market position and
competitiveness as the third largest producer in the European tissue paper market, we initiated a number of
strategic investment projects in 2020. These included the decision to invest in two new paper machines at our
sites in Piechowice and Bridgend as well as in new converting lines at our manufacturing sites in Piechowice,

**_Liquidity management and cash pooling_**

While we intend to primarily meet our liquidity requirements with cash generated from our operating
activities, we expect to have sufficient capacity available under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility and
under our ABS Program to be able to meet any additional operating requirements. Upon completion of the
Offering and after giving effect to the transactions described under “Use of Proceeds”, we expect to have
undrawn capacity of €146.4 million under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility. While we do not expect
there to be any outstanding drawings under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility as of the Issue Date,
we expect to have used an amount of €3.6 million under the Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility in the
form of payment guarantees provided pursuant to an ancillary facility. In addition, we expect to have the
ability to sell certain additional receivables under the ABS Program.

To manage our liquidity, we maintain a largely centralized cash management system, which includes all our
subsidiaries. In particular, liquidity plans are prepared with the group budget on a monthly rolling period for
a current fiscal year in which the expected cash receipts and payments for the specified time period are set off
against each other. We prepare 12-week liquidity plans on a weekly rolling basis and include a deviation
analysis. For the purposes of improved cash management, we have implemented a group-wide, central cash
pooling system. This system comprises several cash pooling agreements with different banks. The balances
resulting from the daily settlement of accounts are subject to interest at the margin applicable under our
Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility from time to time. The general policy on subsidiary cash balances is to
transfer these to the accounts of the Issuer. This takes place daily for all participating entities.

**OFF-BALANCE SHEET ARRANGEMENTS**

The following discussion describes our material off-balance sheet arrangements, which consist of our ABS
Program, as well as operating leases and guarantee lines.

**ABS Program**

We optimize our liquidity by selling a portion of our trade receivables as part of an off balance asset backed
securities (ABS) program. Based on an agreement we originally entered into with Commerzbank AG, LBBW
and Raiffeisenbank International AG in 2018, and which we amended and extended in 2022 with
Commerzbank AG, DZ Bank and Raiffeisenbank International AG, for a 5 year term, we sell our trade
receivables to a special purpose vehicle (named Belvedere Financing) on a non-recourse basis in return for an
immediate cash payment. In order to cover the credit risk, we are paid the nominal amount of the sold
receivables minus pre agreed reserve amounts, a purchase price discount and transaction costs, which are
booked to the income statement. Trade receivables are sold on a revolving basis with a maximum aggregate
transaction volume of up to €220 million, currently committed with €184 million. The reduction down to a
level of €184 million was undertaken for cost control reasons. Within a time horizon of 120 days, the volume
can be increased again to € 220 million. As of September 30, 2023, we had €145.0 million of receivables
financed under our ABS Program.

**QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK**

We are exposed to a number of different market risks arising from our normal business activities.

Based on our assets, liabilities and pending and planned transactions, we are particularly exposed to risks
arising from changes in exchange rates, interest rates and commodity prices, as well as credit risks, such as the
risk of default by counterparties. Furthermore, solvency must be assured at all times (liquidity risk). The
objective of risk management is to use appropriate measures to control these risks where they affect our cash
flows. Derivative financial instruments are used only for hedging purposes. They are not used for trading or
speculative purposes. Exchange effects resulting from the translation of financial statements in foreign
currencies into our reporting currency are not hedged. The guidelines for risk hedging and their
implementation are defined and continuously monitored by our Group Risk Management.

**Raw material price risks**

Raw material price risks result primarily from fluctuations in the prices of pulp and recovered paper. Due to
the fact that fluctuations in the prices of raw materials often cannot be passed on to customers fully and/or in
a timely manner, partial hedging is undertaken with commodity derivative instruments. Currently, these consist
mainly of pulp forward exchange contracts, from which we receive payments or we transfer payments to that
depend on the development of the pulp stock price, and are therefore protected against price increases with
respect to the hedged raw material.

**Energy price risks**

Energy price risks result primarily from fluctuations in global energy prices and regulatory risks in Germany
and other markets in which we operate.

**Currency risk**

We primarily generate our sales in euro. Currency risk arises mainly on trade receivables and payable in foreign
currencies, on planned future sales revenue in foreign currency, and on existing and planned future contracts
for the supply of raw material where the purchase price is in a foreign currency. In addition, we currently
finance several of our foreign subsidiaries, including our Polish subsidiary Wepa Piechowice Sp. z o.o. and our


-----

English subsidiary Wepa UK Ltd. Throughout the years 2020, 2021 and 2022, there were currency risks
mainly in the exchange rates of the U.S. dollar, British pound and Polish zloty relative to the euro.

**Interest rate risk**

Currently, interest rate risks arise mainly on interest bearing liabilities that are denominated in euro. The ratio
of fixed interest and variable interest liabilities is constantly monitored by Group Risk Management. We
primarily manage interest rate risk through interest rate swaps or interest rate options.

Following completion of the Offering and the Transactions, we expect that our exposure to interest rate
fluctuations will relate primarily to drawings under our €150 million Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility
and to receivables financing under our ABS Program.

**Credit risks**

Credit risks arise mainly on trade receivables, bank balances and derivative financial instruments. In view of
our broadly diversified customer list, which extends over various regions, the impact of credit risk on trade
accounts receivable is limited. Further, almost all of our trade accounts receivable are credit insured for nearly
their full face value under credit insurance we purchase in connection with our ABS Program.

To minimize the credit risks from the operational business activity, transactions with external customers are
only entered into after an internal credit check and a credit approval process. Based on the internal credit
check, a limit for a maximum credit risk per customer is set.

**SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES**

In preparing our consolidated financial statements, assumptions and estimates have been made which affect
the amounts and presentation of the assets and liabilities recognized in the statement of financial position,
income and expenses, and contingent liabilities. Uncertainty about these assumptions and estimates could
result in outcomes that may require a material adjustment to the carrying amount of our assets and liabilities
in future periods.

By “significant”, we mean that the following accounting policies are both important to the portrayal of our
financial condition and results and require management’s subjective judgments, often as a result of the need
to estimate the effects of matters that are inherently uncertain. We discuss the impact and risks associated
with these significant accounting policies on our business operations throughout this discussion and analysis
where such policies affect our reported and expected financial results. You should note that the preparation of
our financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of
assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial statements and
the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during each reporting period.

All assumptions and estimates are made according to the best of management’s knowledge and belief in order
to present a true and fair view of our net assets, financial position and results of operations. Since the actual
values may, in individual cases, differ from the assumptions and estimates that were made, these are
continuously reviewed. Adjustments to the estimates that are relevant for the financial statements are made in
the period in which the change occurs, provided that the change relates only to this period. If the change
relates not only to the reporting period but also to subsequent periods, the change is taken into account both
in the period of the change and in the subsequent periods.

**Capital Consolidation**

Capital consolidation is undertaken by offsetting the acquisition costs of the investment against the group’s
share of newly measured equity in the consolidated subsidiaries at the time of the first consolidation and in
accordance with section 301, paragraph 1 of the German Commercial Code. Reportable assets, liabilities and
contingent liabilities of the subsidiaries are reflected at their fair value regardless of the level of the minority
share. Hidden reserves and charges in existence at the time of the initial consolidation were disclosed and
accounted for in accordance with the underlying Assets and Liabilities.

Remaining asset differences (goodwill) are capitalized and amortized or, if necessary, written off. Remaining
differences on the Liabilities side (negative goodwill) are treated in accordance with section 309, paragraph 2
of the German Commercial Code respectively German Accounting Standard GAS 23.

Goodwill amounted to €14.4 million and negative goodwill amounted to €18.3 million as of December 31,
2022.


-----

**Currency Translation**

The assets and liabilities in the consolidated financial statements are converted at the prevailing exchange
rates on the relevant reporting date, equity items at historic exchange rates and expenses and income at the
average annual exchange rate during the relevant period. Resulting conversion differences are stated without
affecting our operating result under the item “Difference in equity from currency translation” in equity. As a
matter of principle, exchange rate changes in the case of intra Group receivables and liabilities are recorded
without an effect on our operating result.

**Fixed Assets**

Intangible Fixed Assets acquired against payment are capitalized at acquisition cost and, if subject to wear
and tear, amortized over their estimated useful life using the straight line method.

Goodwill from capital consolidation is amortized using the straight line method over a period of 10 years
according to section 309 (1) in conjunction with section 253 (3) of the German Commercial Code. Current
developments are reflected by extraordinary depreciation, if necessary.

Tangible Fixed Assets are valued at acquisition cost, taking into account ordinary straight-line depreciation.
Extraordinary depreciation is taken into consideration in the case of a permanent impairment. Additions
during the Fiscal year are depreciated pro rata temporis applying the straight line method.

**Valuation of Inventories**

Raw materials, supplies and merchandise as well as spare parts are valued at the lower of acquisition cost or
market price. Semi-finished and predominantly finished products are measured at production cost, these
include in addition to direct manufacturing and material costs also appropriate portions of production,
material and administration overhead costs. Interest on debt is not included in production costs. Some
companies within the Group currently value the production cost using the reverse costing method by
deducting any upcoming direct selling costs and distribution overhead costs as well as the profit margin from
the net sales price. Inventory risks are taken into account by considering appropriate valuation allowances.

**Receivables and other assets**

Receivables and other assets are valued at the lower of the nominal value or the fair value as at the balance
sheet date. Appropriate bad debt allowances are provided for receivables that are jeopardized by specific risks,
the general credit risk is covered by a general allowance.

Several companies of the Wepa group sell a portion of their trade receivables as part of an off balance asset
backed securities (ABS) program to a special purpose vehicle (named Belvedere Financing S.A.) on a nonrecourse basis in return for an immediate cash payment. In order to cover the credit risk, we are paid the
nominal amount of the sold receivables minus pre agreed reserve amounts. A portion of the pre agreed reserve
amounts (so called “default reserve”), the purchase price discount and transaction costs are recorded as
expenses in our income statement. For a detailed description of our ABS Program, see “Description of Other
_Indebtedness—ABS Program”._

**Pension provisions**

Pension provisions for vested and current pension obligations are calculated using the projected unit credit
method based on the “Richttafeln 2018 G” (Generation Mortality Tables) of Professor Dr. Klaus Heubeck.
They are calculated in accordance with Section 253(1) sentence 2 and Section 253(2) of the German
Commercial Code (in similar application of IAS 19). Calculations are based on an Interest Rate of 1.78% as
of December 31, 2022 (prior year: 1.89%).

Anticipated salary and pension increases are reflected at a rate of 2.0% (prior year: 2.0%) and 2.0% (prior
year: 2.0%), respectively. A fluctuation rate of 0.0% (prior year: 0.0%) was used.

**Tax and Other Provisions**

Tax and other provisions are considered for all identifiable risks and uncertain liabilities. They have to be
assessed at the amount which is required to be paid according to a reasonable commercial assessment, taking
into account price and cost increases. Provisions with a remaining maturity of more than one year are
discounted with the average market interest rate for the past seven years corresponding to their residual
maturity.


-----

For the determination of deferred taxes caused by temporary or quasi permanent differences between the
commercial and the tax based valuation of assets and liabilities or caused by tax loss carryforwards and tax
credits, the amounts of the highly probable future tax charges or tax reductions are calculated using the
company individual tax rates at the time the differences will be effective, these amounts are not discounted.
The capitalization of deferred taxes in the Financial Statements of the consolidated companies was applied in
accordance with the existing disclosure option under Section 274(1) of the German Commercial Code. On
differences resulting from consolidation measures deferred taxes are accounted for in application of
section 306 paragraph 1 of the German commercial Code. As at December 31, 2022 the deferred tax assets
and tax liabilities are offset against each other and the surplus is disclosed as deferred tax liabilities.

**Derivative financial instruments**

Derivative financial instruments are used to hedge interest rate, currency and commodity risks associated
with realized, pending and planned underlying transactions.

Under German GAAP, the realized and pending underlying transactions can be recorded as valuation units
with the related hedging transactions, either as a micro hedge or as a portfolio hedge. The same applies to
planned transactions underlying a macro or portfolio hedge. Under German GAAP, valuation units are valued
individually as per the relevant balance sheet date.

We use the following valuation methods and assumptions in calculating the market value of our derivative
financial instruments:

Currency forwards and currency swaps are valued at the forward exchange rate as of the relevant balance
sheet date. Options are valued using the Black Scholes or Binomial Models depending on their structure.
Instruments designed to hedge interest rate and commodity risks are valued by discounting future cash flows.
Discounting is based on customary market interest rates over the remaining term of the instruments. Swap
amounts from these hedging instruments are recorded against profit and loss at the time of payment or when
accrued at the relevant balance sheet date.

According to German GAAP, a negative valuation result of the relevant hedging transaction leads to a
provision for contingent losses, provided that no valuation unit has been created, while a positive valuation
result is not taken into account.

**SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCES BETWEEN GERMAN GAAP AND IFRS**

Our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum have been prepared
on the basis of German GAAP, which differ in certain respects from IFRS. The following paragraphs
summarize certain significant differences between German GAAP and IFRS as of December 31, 2022.

The organizations that promulgate IFRS have ongoing projects that could have a significant impact on future
comparisons of German GAAP and IFRS. This description is not intended to provide a comprehensive
listing of all such differences specifically related to us or the industry in which we operate. IFRS are generally
more restrictive and more comprehensive than German GAAP regarding recognition and measurement of
transactions, account classification and presentation and disclosure requirements. We have not attempted to
identify all disclosure, presentation or classification differences that would affect the manner in which
transactions and events are presented in the consolidated financial statements or the notes thereto included
elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

We have not prepared audited consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS. Accordingly, we
cannot assure you that the differences described below would, in fact, be the accounting principles creating
the greatest material differences between our consolidated financial statements prepared under German
GAAP and under IFRS. In addition, we cannot estimate the net effect that applying IFRS would have on our
results of operations or our financial position, or any part of them, in any of the presentations of financial
information in this offering memorandum. The effect of such differences may be material and, in particular, it
may be that the total shareholders’ equity (capital deficit) and net income prepared on the basis of IFRS
would be materially different due to these differences.

**Financial Statement Presentation**

Under IFRS, the presentation of the balance sheet is based on a current/non-current distinction of assets and
liabilities. IFRS requires the presentation of assets and liabilities in order of liquidity only when a liquidity
presentation provides information that is reliable and is more relevant than a current/non-current presentation.
Under German GAAP, the presentation of the balance sheet is based on the liquidity of the assets and


-----

liabilities. This results, for example, in the different presentation of financial assets and liabilities and deferred
taxes in the statement of financial position under IFRS and German GAAP.

Unlike IFRS, German GAAP does not require the presentation of the statement of comprehensive income
and it is very common (but not required) that the income statement under the German GAAP will be prepared
using the “nature of expense”method and not the “cost of sales”method, which is generally used in the IFRS
financial statements. In addition, the disclosures required in the explanatory notes to the financial statements
are far more extensive under IFRS than under German GAAP.

**Consolidation Principles**

Under IFRS, an entity (investor) is required to consolidate another entity (investee), depending on whether it
controls the investee. An investor controls an investee when it has a power over an investee, is exposed, or has
rights to the variable returns from its involvement and due to his power can influence the amount of these
variable returns. The consolidation conclusions under IFRS will not differ significantly from the German
GAAP regulations for the most straightforward entities. However, some differences may arise where there are
complex group structures or where specific entities have been established. Investors that are most likely
affected have their involvements, for example, in with the following entities:

- Entities with a dominant investor without a majority of the voting or similar rights and where the rest of
voting rights belongs to the widely dispersed shareholders (de facto control);

- Structured entities (formerly “special purpose entities”) where voting or similar rights are not the
dominant means to determine the power.

Under German GAAP, an investor is required to consolidate the investee if an investor holds the majority of
voting rights, enjoys the right to appoint or dismiss the majority of the management and supervisory board
members, enjoys the right to exercise a controlling influence on financial and operating policies or in substance
obtains the majority of risks and rewards of an investee that has a narrow, well defined purpose (“special
purpose entity”).

**Business Combination**

Under IFRS 3 acquisition related cost (transaction cost) that incurs to effect a business combination are
accounted as expenses in the periods in which the costs are incurred and the services are received.

Acquisition related costs are not part of the consideration transferred to the seller in return for the business;
they are not part of the fair value of the acquired business; they do not represent an asset of the acquirer.
Acquisition related costs represent services that have been rendered to and consumed by the acquirer. As
such, IFRS 3 states that they are accounted for as an expense when the acquirer consumes the related service.

Under German GAAP certain cost which have been incurred after the decision to acquire an entity qualify for
capitalization and form part of the acquisition cost (e.g. due diligence cost, consultancy cost for valuation
reports). All expenses incurred prior to the decision making have to be expensed as incurred.

Costs related to the issuance of financial liabilities are expensed as incurred. Optionally, interest like expenses
are capitalized and amortized over the term of the debt.

For purchase price allocation all identifiable assets, liabilities, and contingent liabilities of the subsidiaries are
reflected at their fair value regardless of the level of minority share.

Under IFRS 3, goodwill acquired in a business combination, must be allocated to a cash generating unit
(CGU) or group(s) of CGUs. A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows
that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets.

Under German GAAP goodwill is allocated to the respective business unit to which it refers.

Under IFRS goodwill is not amortized but tested for impairment annually and if there is an indication that
goodwill may be impaired.

The recoverable amount of the CGU is compared with its carrying amount. Recoverable amount is defined as
the higher of an asset’s fair value less costs of disposal and its value in use. If the recoverable amount of an
asset or CGU is less than its carrying amount, an entity should reduce the carrying amount to the recoverable
amount. The reduction is an impairment loss. For assets carried on the depreciated historical cost basis the
impairment loss should be recognized in profit or loss immediately. For assets that are carried at revalued


-----

amounts an impairment loss is treated as a revaluation decrease. The loss is first set against any revaluation
surplus relating to the asset in other comprehensive income to the extent of the surplus and the remaining
balance of the loss (if any) is then treated as an expense in profit or loss.

Under German GAAP goodwill is amortized over its economic life. Goodwill should be reviewed for
impairment and its remaining useful life once a year. Goodwill is impaired if its carrying amount exceeds its
fair value.

**Property, plant and equipment**

Under IFRS, the recorded acquisition cost of property, plant and equipment includes appropriate
dismantling, removal and restoration costs. Borrowing costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition,
construction or production of a qualifying asset as part of the cost of that asset are capitalized as part of the
cost of that asset. Overhead costs, such as general and administrative costs and expenses for social services,
voluntary social benefits and company pensions are not part of the production cost. Under IFRS, individual
items within property, plant and equipment are frequently composed of different component parts with
varying useful lives or consumption patterns. These parts are individually replaced during the useful life of an
asset. Under IFRS, each such part of an item of property, plant and equipment with a cost that is significant
in relation to the total cost of the item is recognized and depreciated separately (component approach). Costs
of required and regular major inspections are capitalized and depreciated if it is probable that future economic
benefits associated with the item will flow to the reporting entity and the cost of the item can be measured
reliably. After initial recognition IFRS further offers an option to value items of property, plant and equipment
at either the (lower) cost of the item less any accumulated depreciation and impairment or at its fair value at
the date of revaluation less any subsequent accumulated depreciation and impairment.

Under German GAAP, property, plant and equipment is initially valued at purchase or production cost, the
latter may include general and administrative costs and expenses for social services, voluntary social benefits
and company pensions. Costs directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a
qualifying asset must be capitalized. The component approach is not specifically contemplated by German
GAAP rules, but its use for balance sheet purposes is generally permitted. Costs of regular major inspections
are recognized in the income statement as incurred. A revaluation model is not permitted. Costs of
demolishing or restoring an item of property, plant and equipment do not qualify for capitalization but are
required to be reported as provision over the item’s useful life. After initial recognition, property, plant and
equipment are accounted for at cost less any accumulated depreciation.

**Impairment of Assets**

Under IFRS, an impairment loss is recognized if the recoverable amount of an asset is less than its carrying
amount. An asset’s recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s or cash generating unit’s fair value less cost
of disposal and its value in use. The recoverable amount is determined for an individual asset unless the asset
does not generate cash inflows that are largely independent of those from other assets or groups of assets.

Under German GAAP, an impairment loss for non-current assets must only be recorded if a permanent
impairment in value is anticipated. The concept of cash generating units is not applicable under German
GAAP, and the impairment loss is determined on an item by item basis. An impairment loss is to be recognized
when the carrying amount of an asset exceeds its fair value.

**Provisions, Other Liabilities and Contingencies**

Some provisions in the financial statements under German GAAP will be required to be reported as other
liabilities in accordance with IFRS. Under IFRS, provisions are recognized if an enterprise has a present
obligation as a result of a past event, it is probable (i.e., more likely than not to occur) that an outflow of
resources will be required to settle the obligation and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the
obligation. In cases where the outflow of economic resources is expected to occur, an obligation will be
reported as a liability. The discount rate used to determine the amount of any provisions is determined by
reference to a pre-tax interest rate for a risk-free obligation that matches the maturity of the liability to which
the provision relates.

Under German GAAP, the criteria for the recognition of provisions and contingencies are less detailed and
prescriptive than under IFRS. Accordingly, there is greater flexibility under German GAAP to record
provisions for onerous contracts and restructuring expenses. In addition, German GAAP estimates are
typically made in a more conservative manner. The recognition of a provision with a probability lower than
50% is possible. German GAAP requires the recording of provisions for deferred maintenance that is expected


-----

to be performed within three months after the end of the reporting period, uncertain liabilities and expected
losses from executory contracts. Long term provisions (i.e., with a maturity of more than one year) are
discounted using a maturity matched average market interest rate for the preceding seven years as published
by the German Central Bank (Deutsche Bundesbank).

**Valuation of Assets and Liabilities; Currency Translation**

Under IFRS, initial recognition and subsequent measurement of financial assets and liabilities—if qualified
as financial assets and liabilities at fair value through profit and loss—is required at its fair value. Foreign
currency receivables and liabilities are measured at fair value.

Under German GAAP, current financial assets are required to be recorded at acquisition cost and financial
liabilities are required to be recorded at repayment cost. Current receivables and liabilities in foreign currency
are measured at fair value. The valuation of non-current currency receivables and liabilities with a maturity
more than one year has to be in line with lower of cost or market principle and higher carrying amount at the
balance sheet date respectively.

**Interest-Bearing Loans and Borrowings; Prepaid Expenses**

Under IFRS, all interest bearing loans and borrowings are initially recorded at the fair value of the
consideration received, less directly attributable transaction costs. After initial recognition, interest bearing
loans and borrowings are measured at amortized cost using the effective interest method.

Under German GAAP, interest bearing loans and borrowings are recorded at their repayment amounts.
Transaction costs, except for costs to be paid to the finance providers, are expensed as incurred. Only
equivalent to interest transaction costs paid to finance providers are deferred as prepaid expenses and
amortized on a straight line basis to interest expense.

**Sales, Trade Receivables**

Under German GAAP, the definition of “sales” includes all revenue derived from the regular business
activities of the reporting entity.

Under IFRS, “revenue from certain ancillary business activities is recorded as “other operating income”,
rather than “sales”.

Under German GAAP, valuation allowances for losses on individual trade receivables must be recorded. In
addition, a general provision for doubtful accounts—reflecting the general default risk of receivables—has to
be recorded.

Under IFRS, the recording of such a general provision for doubtful allowances would be prohibited.

**Leasing**

Under IFRS 16 all rent and leasing contracts are accounted on-balance as financial leases. The lessee has a
right-of-use asset and a respective lease liability.

The right-of-use asset is a lessee’s right to use an asset over the life of a lease. The asset is calculated as the
initial amount of the lease liability, plus any lease payments made to the lessor before the lease commencement
date, plus any initial direct costs incurred, minus any lease incentives received.

The amortization period for the right-of-use asset is beginning from the lease commencement date until the
earlier of the end of the lease term or the end of the useful life of the asset. An exception is when it is
reasonably certain that the lessee will exercise an option to purchase the asset, in which case the amortization
period is through the end of the asset’s useful life.

If a right-of-use asset is determined to be impaired, the impairment is immediately recorded, thereby reducing
the carrying amount of the asset. Its subsequent measurement is calculated as the carrying amount
immediately after the impairment transaction, minus any subsequent accumulated amortization.

At the termination of a lease, the right-of-use asset and associated lease liability are removed from the books
of the lessee. The difference between the two amounts is accounted for as a profit or loss at that time.

Under German GAAP, accounting for leases is mainly driven by tax regulations, so the lease contracts in
Germany typically consider such rules in order to avoid capitalization at the lessee level. These rules differ
from the IFRS rules in several respects.


-----

**Provisions for Pensions**

Under IFRS, provisions for defined benefit pension obligations are accounted for under the projected unit
credit method. The defined benefit obligation is measured using various actuarial assumptions, including
assumptions as to future compensation and benefits levels. Under IFRS, the discount rate reflects the long
term view of the plan and not current rates that could be used to settle the pension obligation. This discount
rate is derived at the reporting date based on then current capital market conditions. Under one of the options
provided by IFRS, remeasurement gains and losses that result from changes in actuarial assumptions
(including changes in mortality tables) or actual experience that differs from the underlying assumptions do
not require recognition of gains and losses as components of net pension cost of the period in which they
arise. Rather they are recognized in other comprehensive income, which will never be reclassified in profit or
loss in the future.

Pension reserves under German GAAP are also be accounted for under the projected unit credit method since
the enactment of the German Accounting Law Modernization Act in 2009. Under German GAAP, the
discount rate used represents a maturity matched ten year average market derived interest rate. Alternatively
provisions for pensions and similar obligations may be discounted at an interest rate with a 15 year maturity
at the respective balance sheet date. The interest rates to be applied are published by the Federal Bank of
Germany. In addition, German GAAP requires recognition of the remeasurement gain or losses in profit and
loss and not as other comprehensive income as required under IFRS.

**Deferred Taxes**

Deferred tax assets (DTA) and deferred tax liabilities (DTL) are the income taxes recoverable or payable in
future years. They are mainly based on the taxable or deductible temporary differences between the carrying
amount of an asset or liability and the respective tax base. Due to the IFRS accounting principles, the carrying
amount of an asset or liability can differ from the amount under German GAAP. Accordingly the respective
deferred tax assets and liabilities change as well.

Under German GAAP, net DTL must be recognized in full, while the recognition of net DTA is optional.
Unlike German GAAP, IFRS does not provide an option to capitalize net DTA and, therefore, both net DTA
and net DTL have to be recognized in the respective period.

Under IFRS, DTA shall also be recognized for tax loss carryforwards to the extent that it is probable that
future taxable profit will be available. Under German GAAP, the capitalization of DTA for loss carryforward
shall only be taken into consideration if the tax benefit from the tax loss carryforward can be expected to be
recovered within the next five years.

**Derivative Financial Instruments and Hedging**

Under IFRS, derivative financial instruments are recorded in the consolidated balance sheets at fair value
(mark to market). Any gains or losses arising from changes in the fair value of derivatives are taken directly to
the income statement, except for the effective portion of cash flow hedges, which is recognized in other
comprehensive income and reclassified to profit or loss for the period when the forecast transaction being
hedged occurs. Under IFRS, the criteria to be met to qualify for hedge accounting are quite strict. This
includes stringent documentation requirements.

Under German GAAP, there is more flexibility to include forecast transactions in hedge accounting. Further,
there is no need to separately account for fair values of derivative financial instruments that qualify for hedge
accounting (net hedge presentation method).

**EUROPEAN TISSUE MARKET**

Germany is the biggest Western European market for tissue products and comprised approximately 21% of
the Western European market with a demand of 1,467,000 tons in 2021. The Western European market
experienced a growth of 0.7% per annum in tissue consumption between 2011 and 2021 on average. The
demand for tissue products in the region is expected to grow broadly in line with historical growth levels
between 2021 and 2031 according to the RISI Report estimates. This increasing demand is expected to be
driven by population growth, demographic changes, development in tissue quality (e.g., the shift from two-ply
to three or four-ply products and softer toilet tissue despite of reduced fiber quantity per sheet), new product
specifications, limited substitution of products and increases in product penetration levels.

We also compete in the Eastern European market for tissue products with a sizeable presence in Poland which
is the second biggest market in the region and comprised approximately 25.6% of the Eastern European
market with a demand of 634,000 tons in 2021. The Eastern European market registered a growth of
approximately 5% per annum in tissue consumption between 2011 and 2021 on average. According to the
RISI Report, the demand for tissue products in the Eastern European market is expected to grow continually
at a higher average annual rate between 2021 and 2031 (+2.8% p.a.), but will not continue to outgrow Western
Europe between 2021 and 2031 as it has done in past with a 1.1% expected growth rate during the same time
period. Still, the higher demand is expected to be driven by economic growth, population developments,
increasing urbanization, the penetration of Western European retailers into the Eastern European retail
market and the increase of per capita consumption levels closer to average Western European levels, partly
driven by the expansion of Western European retailers in Eastern Europe.

In Western Europe, average per capita consumption increased from 12.2 kg in 1998 to 15.9 kg in 2021, which,
however, was still approximately 10 kg less than the per capita consumption in North America. Austria led the
region with a per capita consumption of 20.0 kg while Germany experienced a per capita consumption of
17.4 kg in 2021. In Eastern Europe, average per capita consumption increased from 1.7 kg in 1998 to 7.6 kg in
2021, which, however, was still significantly less than the levels in Western Europe and North America.

The European tissue market can be divided into two main market segments: the Consumer (or at-home)
segment which represented approximately 75% of total European demand of 9,312,000 tons in 2021 and the
AfH segment, which constituted approximately 25% of the 2021 demand.

The COVID-19 pandemic impacted the Consumer and the AfH segments differently, specifically at the
beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. Whereas the Consumer segment benefited from strong sales
due to panic hoarding of household necessities incl. toilet paper and tissue products, the AfH segment was
negatively impacted by the lockdowns, home-office working and limited public / recreational traffic.
Meanwhile the observed changes normalized again to pre-crisis behavior.

**CONSUMER SEGMENT**

The Consumer segment accounted for approximately 74% of tissue consumption in Western Europe in 2021.
The upgrading of product quality has helped the Consumer segment to grow further, among others, through
the shift towards three and four-ply toilet tissue in Central European countries such as Germany, the
Netherlands, Belgium and Austria. The Consumer segment experienced an average annual growth of 1.0% in
demand during 2011 and 2021 and is expected to grow by an annual growth rate of 0.9% between 2021 and
2031 according to the RISI Report. Toilet tissue is the biggest end-market product within the Consumer
segment followed by toweling, which represented approximately 64% and 23%, respectively, of the total
consumption in the segment in Western Europe in 2021.

In Eastern Europe, the Consumer segment accounted for approximately 79% of tissue consumption in 2021.
The segment experienced an average annual growth of 4.8% in demand during 2011 and 2021 and is expected
to grow at a lower average annual growth rate of 2.4% between 2021 and 2031 according to the RISI Report.
Toilet tissue dominates the Consumer segment, accounting for 72% of total consumption in 2021.

**AWAY-FROM-HOME (AFH) SEGMENT**

Unlike the Consumer segment, AfH products are not delivered to the end customer via larger retailers, but via
typically smaller, regional distributors specialized in professional hygiene solutions. These distributors serve
end customers such as industrial companies, hotels, restaurants, health care providers and other customers
with public washrooms.


-----

The AfH segment accounted for the remaining 26% of tissue consumption in Western Europe in 2021. The
AfH segment experienced an average annual growth of 0.1% in demand between 2011 and 2021 and is
expected to grow at an average annual growth rate of 1.9% between 2021 and 2031 according to the RISI
Report. Hand towels represent the biggest end-market product within the AfH segment and represented 46%
of total consumption within the segment in 2021.

In Eastern Europe, the AfH segment accounted for approximately 21% of tissue consumption in 2021. The
segment registered an average annual growth of 4.0% in demand during 2011 and 2021 and is expected to
grow at an average annual growth rate of 4.1% between 2021 and 2031, according to the RISI Report. Toweling
dominated consumption within the AfH segment and accounted for 38% of total consumption in 2021.

**PRIVATE LABEL VS. BRANDED**


The tissue industry is further classified between private label and branded products. Private label tissue
products are marketed and sold through retail stores under retailers’ in-house labels. The share of private
label products has shown continued growth in most European countries with currently approximately 71.5%
of total volume in tissue products being sold under private labels across main Western European consumer
tissue markets in 2022. This is partly driven by the continued expansion of European retailers, especially
discounters. Germany has one of the highest shares of private label products as compared to branded products
in Europe, with 78.2% share in 2022. However, given that the share of retailer labels is so high in Germany, the
share of private labels declined in the recent four years, as some of the main players such as Essity and Sofidel
have made strong efforts to increase sales of their branded products. In general, the private label sector has
proven to be more resilient than branded products during economic downturns.

Differences exist between countries in their mix of private label versus branded tissue products due to the
concentration (and in effect, negotiating power) of retailers, the position of discounters in the distribution
chain, the traditional market dominance of a few brand owners, product margins and pricing decisions, the
level of brand advertising and consumer attitudes.

In Western Europe, Spain, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Greece have the highest share of private
label products as compared to branded products (all around 80%), while Finland, Norway, Sweden and Italy
have a significantly higher share of branded products. The average Western European volume share of private
labels increased from 54.6% in 2004 to around 71.5% in 2022 when considering all consumer tissue product
categories. The chart below shows the development of private labels in recent years.

**COMPETITION**

Private label tissue manufacturers compete by way of tender procedures conducted by the respective retailers
on, currently, a three to six months basis. Tissue manufacturers with the best tenders would typically be
invited to a subsequent round of negotiations where prices are further discussed and ultimately agreed.


-----

**Western Europe**

In Western Europe, the top five players account for approximately 60% of the tissue product market (across
at-home, away-from-home, private label and branded products) in 2022. Essity continues to be the largest
Western European tissue supplier with a production capacity share of approximately 26.1% according to the
RISI Report. Wepa currently ranks third in Western Europe with a capacity share of approximately 10.2%
according to RISI.

There has been an ongoing consolidation process in the Western European tissue industry and the industry
has experienced several ownership changes since 2007. The degree of overall consolidation increased until
2012 but has since declined due to some mill closures and divestments to other investors. Notable transactions
include SCA’s (now Essity) acquisition of Georgia-Pacific’s European tissue business in 2012, which created a
clear market leader; Sofidel’s acquisition of LPC Group of the United Kingdom in 2010, which strengthened
Sofidel’s position in the UK market and provided access to the Nordic region and SCA’s (now Essity)
acquisition of Procter & Gamble’s entire European tissue operations in 2007. Similarly, we acquired most of
the assets of Kartogroup in 2009. In 2015, we acquired the former Lucart S.p.a. plant in Troyes, France. The
takeover of Van Houtum with a production site in Swalmen, the Netherlands followed in 2017. In 2018, we
acquired the remaining 50% share in the former joint venture Northwood & Wepa with a production plant in
Bridgend. In the second quarter of 2020, Italian Cartiere Carrara acquired Ideal Cart in Sermoneta from
Carind Goup. It also had acquired the converting assets under the name Carind and another converter CRC
at the beginning of 2020. In the second half of 2020, Kimberly-Clark announced its plan to sell its Swiss
paper mill in Niederbipp. The Queck family took over the mill with an annual capacity of 50,000 tons, which
now continues to operate as Tela GmbH after the transaction. In Germany, JUNG INV became the sole
owner of the Reisholz tissue mill following the self-administration phase of Hakle GmbH in late 2022 and
Hakle’s trademark rights were sold to Sofidel. In April 2023, Essity announced the strategic review of its stake
in Vinda, the listed Asian hygiene company, and its European Consumer Tissue Private Label business (the
latter with sales of approximately SEK 9.8 billion in 2022). Meanwhile Essity announced in December 2023
that it had concluded its strategic review and intended to maintain its European Consumer Tissue Private
Label business.

**Eastern Europe**

Abris Capital is currently the largest supplier of tissue products in Eastern Europe with an approximate 9.4%
share of production capacity. Hayat Kimya and Industrie Cartarie Tronchetti (ICT) are currently the second
and third largest suppliers of tissue products in Eastern Europe, each with a market share of 6.9%.

Unlike Western Europe, the Eastern European market is relatively fragmented with even the largest producer
controlling less than 10% of the region’s capacity. The top five manufacturers (Abris Capital, Hayat Kimya,
ICT, SHP Group and Metsä Tissue) have a combined market share of approximately 35%.

Between 2011 and 2021, Western European tissue production grew by about 397,000 tons. During the same
period, production in Italy, Germany and Portugal increased substantially with further investments in the


-----

area, resulting in these three countries accounting for the highest production increases, followed by France
and Spain. The total installed tissue production capacity in Western Europe by the end of 2022 was
8.05 million tons. Western Europe was a small net exporter in 2012–2013, but became a net importer thereafter,
largely due to the collapse in exports to Russia. The increase in production capacity coupled with the
weakening of the Russian ruble exchange rate had contributed to the reduced importing needs in Russia. It is
assumed that the region will remain a marginal net importer in the coming years. As a result, the average
capacity utilization rate is expected to remain low at 85-86% in 2023–2026.

**Eastern Europe**


Eastern European tissue production grew from 1.1 million tons in 2006 to 3.02 million tons in 2022,
representing about 5% of global consumption, according to the RISI Report. The increase took place mainly
in Russia, followed by Poland, Romania and Hungary. Eastern Europe exported more tissue than it imported
until the mid-1990s, with Western Europe as the main destination. Eastern Europe eventually became a net
importer of tissue products due to the increasing demand for imports of high-quality products. However, new
capacities in Russia, Romania and Poland dampened this trend and by 2017 regional trade was balanced and
had remained in a balanced corridor through the years until 2020 before net imports increased again in 2021.
The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in extra demand, but also delayed projects. As a result, capacity utilization
improved to almost 87% in 2020, but it returned to normal levels of 84% in 2021 and 82% in 2022. The impact
of new production capacities that have recently begun operations or are expected to begin operations in 2024
is expected to affect capacity utilization rates in the coming years. Therefore, operating rates are expected to
remain below 85% until 2025 even if there will be no additional projects.

**RAW MATERIAL MARKET**

**Pulp**


Pulp is one of the principal raw materials required to manufacture tissue paper and is traded on the
international market. Even though wood is the dominating source of fiber, pulp can also be produced from
“non-wood-plants. Wood pulp is classified according to the type of wood used (hardwood or softwood), the
manner in which it is processed (chemical or mechanical process), whether it is bleached, and how it is
bleached. Non-wood-pulps do not assume a significant role in Europe, but are used extensively in other
regions, particularly in China. Tissue paper can also be manufactured from recycled fiber.

Bleached chemical pulp (“BCP”), more commonly known as “white pulp” includes all bleached kraft and
sulphite pulp. Its end-uses are primarily printing and writing papers and tissue. There are several subgrades
used to define specific pulp qualities and this can be commonly split into two categories i.e., Bleached
Softwood Kraft Pulp (“BSKP”) and Bleached Hardwood Kraft Pulp (“BSKP”). Northern Bleached
Softwood Kraft (“NBSK”), otherwise known as BSKP-northern is part of the bleached softwood kraft family
produced exclusively from softwood trees in Canada and the Nordic countries. BSKP is a more generic
nomenclature for other short fiber hardwood species. Bleached Eucalyptus Kraft pulp (“BEKP”) is the
benchmark grade of short fiber chemical pulp exported globally. End products made from long-fiber BSKP
are considerably stronger than short-fiber BEKP since an increase in fiber length translates into more interfiber bonding which implies greater strength of the fibrous network materials.

In recent years, the tissue industry has responded to market price developments for the major pulp grades by
gradually changing the mix of different grades, provided that the quality of the paper grade was not affected
by these technical changes. As shown below, hardwood grades are usually cheaper than softwood grades, so
we have increased the hardwood share in our virgin fiber furnish to approximately 70%, whereas in 2009, it
was less than 50%. This behavior can also be observed in other parts of the industry and the supplier base has


-----

reacted by adding more hardwood production capacity to the market. However, it is important to note that
not only the price but also the availability of pulp grades is a factor.

Our products come in a variety of materials including pure pulp paper, recycled paper, and hybrid solutions
(combination of pure pulp and recycle fibers). With the increasing focus on sustainability and circular
economy, there is a heightened focus on recycled paper-based, recycled fibers and alternative virgin fibers as
raw materials. We have set the goal of reducing our environmental footprint relating to fiber raw materials by
25% by using at least 60% recovered fibers and virgin fiber alternatives by 2030. Although there is an ongoing
effort of diversifying our raw material portfolio, there is still a high reliance on traditional cellulose virgin
fibers in the short to medium term.

According to Hawkins Wright (“Outlook for Market Pulp”, August 2023), the BCP shipments were
60.5 million tons in 2022 and are forecasted to increase by 0.9 million tons over the course of 2022 and 2023.
Market pulp demand remains resilient with the continued growth in tissue and hygiene sectors despite the
secular decline in printing & writing industry (“P&W”). In 2022, tissue has become the largest end user of
bleached chemical pulp, accounting for 43% of global BCP shipments and expected to reach 45% of the
supply by end of 2023, from a share of 33% in 2012. Hawkins Wright forecasted a continued growth in global
tissue production of around 2.5-3% over the forecast period, which marks a key driver to BCP demand. As
consumer preference for high quality tissue grows, most of the growth has been in virgin fiber content tissue.

Based on Hawkins Wright estimates, the tissue industry will account for around 46% of global BCP sales by
2027, approximately 30 million tons, offsetting a 2.4 million tons contraction in the P&W sector to 10 million
tons, which is equivalent to around 15% of the market.

Although the supply-demand ratio is closely correlated with prices, the threshold that constitutes a balanced
market has fallen in recent years as logistical constraints and unforeseen mechanical outages have regularly
increased. This was particularly evident during the supply-side stress during 2021 and 2022, when prices rose
even though the ratio stood at 88-89% and market conditions were actually much tighter than the implied
headline ratio.

As illustrated in the graph above, the weak capacity growth during 2020 and 2021 was followed by supply
chain constraints caused by major production disruptions, i.e. various mill closures and conversions to
unbleached or dissolving pulp, offsetting any growth. Market pulp capacity growth has rebuilt pace in 2022
and is expected to continue to accelerate during 2024, backed by the normalization of the supply chain.
Although capacity growth has resumed, supply side vulnerability could be a prolonged issue with project
delays and ongoing logistical problems, not to mention that there have been more recent outages attributed to
extreme weather events. However, Hawkins Wright’s forecast believes that the growing occurrence of supplyside issues and the current pricing dynamics will lead to a quicker restoration of a balanced BCP market up to
90-91%.

**RAW MATERIAL PRICES**


With market pulp being the key raw material for tissue, the price development of market pulp has a
considerable influence on the manufacturing costs of tissue paper. However, changes in pulp prices can only
pass through with a certain time lag, considering the duration of supply agreements for tissue products. After
pulp markets have recently shown significant relief from their all-time-highs during 2023, we expect that the
market will find a new balance on higher than current price levels.

After approximately a year of price erosion and a leveling out in August, prices for both the benchmark pulp
grades started to move up in September 2023 despite the precarious condition of the European pulp market.
The situation on the NBSK market is not particularly defined, with sources noting that upticks in Chinese
market were responsible for driving price momentum in Europe as end-use markets in Europe remain weak.
While the upward trend is also observed in BEKP prices, pulp sellers were experiencing additional volume
requests from customers and hence were prepared to supply to regions with higher returns.

While pulp prices started to increase in September, there is general a mixed outlook for paper market in
Europe going into Q4 with points of concern surrounding demand recovery and developments in China.

**RECOVERED PAPER**

Recovered paper is the alternative raw material to virgin fiber in manufacturing tissue paper and is a globally
traded commodity. The use of recovered paper in the production of tissue presents several advantages,
including typically lower costs and sustainability aspects. Even though a world market does exist, the
international trading activity is prone to exchange rates, local supply and demand relationships and quality
requirements. Import restriction of untreated recovered paper into Asia and particularly China have caused
significant oversupply in certain paper grades in the rest of the world and a change in trade patterns. This,
however, predominantly concerns low grade recovered paper that is typically still not commonly used in tissue
production, but also influenced better grades and secured their availability in their homelands.

Through acquisitions, we have strategically developed the segment of recovered paper-based tissue. In addition
to Germany, we obtained a meaningful position as a consumer of recovered paper in the Netherlands and
France. Still Germany is the most important source of recyclable material, the price differences for comparable
paper grades are limited in the rest of Europe. The graph below illustrates the price development of the main
recovered paper grades between 2017 and 2023. Again, the COVID-19 pandemic was affecting the paper
markets severely. It changed the consumption patterns, soon followed by an adaptation of production, and
interrupted the collection of fresh recovered paper. Consequently, the markets were undersupplied and reacted
with a price rally, only to collapse again shortly after. By now, prices for better grades have normalized,
however they have massively decreased in availability. Lower grades are currently recovering from a period of
prices that were touching the cost of collection at times or even negative prices. There is ample availability of
lower grades and is availability is expected to exceed that of the traditionally preferred paper grades for tissue
making. This development also supports our sustainability strategy that led to the introduction of tissue
paper that is produced from such lower grades.

**BUSINESS**

**OUR COMPANY**

We are a leading European, family-owned producer and supplier of tissue products with a market share (by
production volumes) of 8.1% in Europe and 10.2% in Western Europe, both according to RISI. Based on our
Internal Private Label Mapping 2022, we believe we are the leading private label consumer tissue paper
producer in our core markets of Germany, the BeNeLux region, France and Italy with a market share, by
volume, between approximately 17-32% in these markets. In addition, we believe we are the second largest
private label consumer tissue paper producer in the UK and the third largest in Poland. We are convinced we
differentiate ourselves from our competitors through our strong and future-oriented commitment to the
European tissue paper business, with a clear focus on sustainability, product innovation and continuous
strategic investments in our asset base.

Headquartered in Arnsberg, Germany, we offer a full range of folded and rolled tissue products such as toilet
paper, kitchen towels, handkerchiefs, hand towels, facial tissues, napkins, industrial paper rolls and paper
towels as well as semi-finished products (i.e. jumbo reels and de-inked pulp). We produce our tissue products
on 22 paper machines and over 80 converting lines. Our fourteen production sites are located strategically
across Europe in Germany, Italy, France, Poland, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, and we had an
average of 3,785 employees in 2022. Our production capacities make us the third largest producer of tissue
products (by volume) in the European tissue market, a market exhibiting resilient demand characteristics with
low product substitution risk. As of the date of this offering memorandum, we have an installed tissue paper
production capacity of 850,000 tons and an installed tissue paper converting capacity of 847,000 tons to
convert tissue paper into tissue products. Approximately 48% of our production capacity and 45% of our
converting capacity is located in Germany, our core market and Europe’s largest tissue market. We also own
technologically advanced facilities for the production of de-inked pulp from recovered paper, with an annual
capacity of more than 390,000 tons. Due to this and our long-standing focus on sustainable products and
production, we believe we are the largest producer of tissue products from recovered paper and hybrid
products in Europe, with total sales of €1,636.4 million in 2022. In the twelve-month period ended
September 30, 2023, we sold 724,000 tons of finished tissue products, 35,000 tons of de-inked pulp and 29,000
tons of jumbo reels across Europe, which generated €1,865.1 million and €318.2 million of sales and EBITDA,
respectively, in such period.

We operate our business primarily through our two business units Consumer and Professional. In our
Consumer business unit, we are a private-label specialist for European retailers, selling our tissue products
branded under our retail customers’ own labels. Our Professional business unit with the brands BlackSatino
and Satino by WEPA stands for sustainable and professional hygiene solutions for large commercial and
institutional customers, served through leading distributors. In addition to our two core business units, and in
line with our vision to be the most sustainable, best-in-class partner for personal and professional hygiene
solutions, we have recently set up a “New Business Areas” business unit, focusing on the expansion of our
product and service portfolio, in particular through innovation, e-commerce and circular economy.

Our Consumer business unit, which represented 85% of our sales from finished products in our financial year
2022 and 86% of our sales from finished products in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023,
offers a full range of consumer tissue products: toilet paper, kitchen towels, facial tissues, handkerchiefs and
napkins. While the key focus of our Consumer business unit is on the private label sector, we also market some
products under our own brands such as Mach m!t…, Comprami, Perla and Scala. Our Professional business
unit, which has a more regional focus within Central Europe and Poland, focuses on tissue products for large
commercial and institutional customers, such as government agencies, hotels, restaurants, private enterprises,
hospitals and other healthcare providers. It offers a broad range of tissue products with a focus on our own
brands Satino by WEPA and BlackSatino, including toilet paper and paper towels, industrial rolls, kitchen
rolls as well as accessories like comprehensive dispenser systems for washrooms. In addition to the brand
business, our Professional business unit offers also private label and unbranded products. In both
business units, we also generate revenues from the sale of semi-finished products, such as de-inked pulp and
jumbo reels, with the amount of such sales varying and primarily depending on our own internal demand.

**OUR STRENGTHS**

We believe that we benefit from the following strengths.

**_Leading Market Positions in Attractive and Resilient End-Markets_**

We are the third largest producer by volume of tissue products in Western Europe, having increased our
market share in Europe from 6.9% in 2015 to 8.1% in 2022 according to RISI. In addition, we believe we are
the largest producer of private label consumer tissue products across our core markets, by volume. For
example, in our home market Germany, which is also our biggest market, we are the largest private label
consumer tissue producer, holding a market share of 28.5% by volume, and we also believe we hold leading
market positions in private label consumer tissue production in each of our other core markets France (first
by capacity, holding a market share of 32.9%), the BeNeLux region (first by capacity, holding a market share
of 27.6%), Italy (first by capacity, holding a market share of 16.8%), the United Kingdom (second by capacity,


-----

holding a market share of 22.1%) and Poland (third by capacity, holding a market share of 16.9%), all based
on our Internal Private Label Mapping 2022. With regard to sustainable tissue products, we believe we are the
largest producer of tissue products from recovered paper and hybrid products in Europe, with total volumes
of approximately 294,000 tons in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2023. Above all, we believe
that our significant existing scale, purchasing power, geographic coverage and strategically well-positioned
production sites give us a competitive advantage over smaller players and enhance our ability to compete with
other leading players in these markets more effectively. Additionally, we believe our competitive position
profits from our clear and future-oriented commitment to the European private label segment in the Consumer
business unit, focusing on long-term strategic customer relations, providing supply reliability, product
innovations and improvement potential for our customers’ sustainability footprint.

Our core tissue products benefit from utility-like consumer demand, high penetration rates, low substitution
risk and resilient demand characteristics. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a generally
increased awareness of hygiene and, as a result, demand for tissue products. Tissue consumption has seen
stable growth rates in Western Europe and strong growth rates in Eastern Europe. According to RISI,
consumption of tissue products in Western Europe grew by an average of 0.7% per annum and in Eastern
Europe by an average of 4.6% per annum between 2011 and 2021, to 6.8 million tons and 2.5 million tons of
tissue, respectively, in 2021. Demand for our core consumer tissue products increased by an average of 1.0%
per annum between 2011 and 2021 in Western Europe and by an average of 4.8% per annum in Eastern
Europe. For the period between 2021 and 2031, RISI expects the average growth rate of tissue consumption in
Western Europe to increase to 1.1% per annum, with growth rates in Eastern Europe expected to continue to
exceed rates in Western Europe, primarily due to the still significantly lower per capital consumption of tissue
paper in many Eastern European countries. We believe that demographic changes, increased urbanization,
higher product penetration levels, developments in tissue quality as well as increased pressure on our customers
to meet their self-imposed sustainability goals (where they are widely dependent on suppliers to provide
sustainably sourced raw materials due to the nature of the retail business model) will continue to underpin
demand growth for our products.
