**PROCUREMENT/PURCHASING**

**Overview**

Our most important input materials include pulp, recovered paper, energy and logistics, which collectively
accounted for 72% of our total procurement volume in 2022. We experienced sharp increases in the prices of
most of our input materials, including energy, logistics and recovered paper, through 2021 and 2022 due to
various factors, including global supply and demand imbalances and logistical disruptions as a result of the
COVID-19 pandemic and the Russian invasion in Ukraine, as well as changes in global trade patterns.

Although pulp prices remained relatively stable and low for most of 2022, they increased swiftly to
unprecedented high gross prices and plateaued at the beginning of 2023, largely due to the reasons described
above. The increases in costs of recovered paper were largely due to the effect that COVID-19 pandemic had
on recycling collection rates and hence the availability of paper for recycling.

**2020** **2021** **2022**
Pulp . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . €246.3 million €229.3 million €379.4 million
Recovered paper . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . €73.3 million €91.6 million €102.7 million
Energy . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . €76.8 million €116.3 million €263.8 million
Logistics . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . €102.3 million €111.5 million €127.0 million

Other procurement items, such as packing materials and chemicals, accounted for an aggregate €345.0 million
in 2022.

Our procurement activities are organized at a Group-wide level. Our procurement department separately
manages the procurement of key input materials such as pulp, recovered fiber, energy and auxiliary materials.
By centralizing our purchasing activities, we aim to maximize our pan-European purchasing power, while at
the same time building a high level of expertise. The markets and prices for the most important production
costs in our business, such as pulp, energy and recovered paper, are driven by international supply and demand
and require Group-wide purchasing strategies in order to optimize results. Our strategies include a mixture of
long-term supply contracts and spot purchasing. Price and currency risk management is performed in close
cooperation with our treasury department.

**Pulp and Recovered Paper**

The main raw materials for the production of our tissue paper products are pulp and recovered paper.
Purchasing for both is centralized at our headquarters in Arnsberg. In 2022, we consumed a total of
approximately 572,000 tons of pulp and 395,000 tons of recovered paper. We manage our supplier portfolio
actively, constantly striving to maintain competition among our pulp and recovered paper suppliers. By doing
so, we have been able to improve our average purchasing conditions significantly in recent years. Furthermore,
we are well positioned to make use of opportunities and to react on market developments such as changing
price differences between soft and hardwood pulp grades and the spot market.

For pulp, we aim to contract at least 85% of our demand on the basis of annual contracts with selected,
reliable suppliers, allowing us to ensure the majority of our demand while still being able to use spot
purchasing opportunities. The purchase price in our long-term contracts is either linked to the PIX Index or
subject to monthly negotiations, but might also comprise longer term rolling averages, cap and floor
agreements and fixed prices. While our long-term agreements ensure the availability of pulp, they give only
limited protection in respect of the prices we have to pay. In order to limit our exposure to fluctuations in the
price of pulp, we have developed a specific hedging strategy which involves a multistage process designed to


-----

separately address (i) fluctuations in the market price of pulp, as quoted in U.S. dollars as well as
(ii) fluctuations in the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar against the Euro, our reporting currency and the
currency in which we generate most of our sales revenues. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting our Result and Operations—Exposure_
_to Fluctuations in Pulp and Recovered Paper Prices”._

For recovered paper we utilize a wide variety of suppliers. For our production process, we require homogenous,
long fiber recovered paper that we purchase predominantly via long term supply agreements, but for which we
also use spot purchasing opportunities. The prices of the supply contracts are typically negotiated on a
monthly basis or fixed for periods of between three and four months. Unlike for pulp, there are no derivative
instruments available that would allow us to hedge our exposure to fluctuations in the prices of the recovered
paper grades we require. The only way to lock in recovered paper prices are therefore direct agreements with
our recovered paper suppliers.

**Energy**

Our production processes, in particular the production of de-inked pulp and the operation of our paper
machines, require large amounts of energy. The operation of our paper machines accounts for more than 90%
of our total energy demand and the operation of our converting lines and our de-inking facilities account for
substantially the remainder. Our primary sources of energy are electricity, natural gas and steam. Energy
expenses were our second largest procurement cost item in 2022 and amounted to €263.8 million, or 24.2%, of
our total cost of materials in 2022, compared to €116.3 million, or 16.3%, in 2021 and €76.8 million, or 11.3%,
in 2020. The key drivers of our energy expenses are fluctuations in the market prices for energy, as well as
regulatory decisions. Our total energy expenses have increased during recent years, primarily as a result of
higher production capacities and rising market prices for electricity and natural gas. However, the volatility
and sharp increases in energy prices we experienced during 2021 and 2022, as a result of the COVID-19
pandemic and the war in Ukraine, were unprecedented. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting our Result and Operations—Exposure_
_to Fluctuations in Energy Prices”._

We attempt to limit our exposure to the volatility of electricity and gas prices by covering parts of our
projected energy requirements through fixed future contracts. These contracts are entered into by different
entities within the Wepa Group, mostly at the local level, and have varying durations. For Germany we
typically try to lock in prices, on a rolling basis, for up to 60% (in the short-term even up to 90%, in a staggering
structure), 40% and 20% of our projected energy requirements with regard to the following 12-month period
(Y+1) and each of the subsequent two 12 month periods (Y+2 and Y+3), respectively, subject to developments
in the energy markets. In Italy, we are part of an industrial syndicate which manages energy supply issues and
the related regulatory issues for its members. This includes locking in prices for a portion of projected energy
requirements in coordination between all syndicate members subject to market price developments. At our
site in Giershagen, Germany, approximately 33% of our electric power and almost 100% of our steam
requirements for such site are covered by Wepa Kraftwerk GmbH, a subsidiary of the Issuer operating a
power plant which uses the residual materials from our recycling processes in Arnsberg and Giershagen as a
source of thermal energy.

**Freight/Logistics**

We deliver our products to our customers through external logistics companies. Due to the relatively large size
of our products compared to value, freight and logistics expenses play an important role in our business. The
selection and commissioning of the logistics companies is centrally organized by our logistics department in
Arnsberg, supported by our local organizations in France, Poland, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and
Italy. Orders are regularly tendered on web-based tendering platforms for logistics services. Due to
international supply chain disruptions during recent years and the ongoing Russian invasion in Ukraine, the
market for logistical services, especially with regards to truck transportation, has tightened compared to the
available capacity prior to 2020. Due to our focus on collaborating with our logistics providers and increasing
automation and digitalization of logistics, we have been able to secure transportation for our products without
interruption, although we have been impacted by the fluctuations in transportation costs. See also
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors
_Affecting our Result and Operations—Exposure to Fluctuations in Freight/Logistics Costs”._

**REGULATORY ENVIRONMENT**

Our business, and in particular the operation of our production sites, is subject to various regulatory
requirements. Applicable laws and regulations may differ from site to site due to different national and local


-----

laws. The regulatory requirements relate in particular to our production processes and include, inter alia, laws
and regulations relating to health and safety measures for employees, the technical safety requirements for
operating machines, the use and handling of chemicals, air and water emissions, soil contamination and the
management and disposal of waste, hazardous and toxic substances and other materials. For our sites and
operations, we are required to obtain and hold various permits and to comply with the requirements specified
therein. In addition, we are subject to rules that govern the safety of our products and the information we
include on the packaging of our products. We are further subject to foreign trade laws and may be required to
pay export duties or customs duties on materials and products that we export and import. We are subject to
further regulations in the various jurisdictions in which we operate, including antitrust laws and zoning and
occupancy laws that generally apply to manufacturing businesses and/or govern the promotion and sale of
certain products we offer, the operation of our facilities and our relationships with customers, suppliers and
competitors. The following is an overview of the main laws and regulations that are relevant to our activities
in Germany. Local laws and regulations that deal with similar aspects apply in other jurisdictions in which we
operate production sites or sell our products.

**Environmental Laws**

We are required to comply with various environmental laws and regulations. In particular, our operations are
subject to laws and regulations designed to limit emissions. This is particularly relevant for our sites that are
located, mostly for historic reasons, in mixed-use areas with nearby residential properties, such as our site in
Arnsberg. In Germany, the construction and operation of paper production and converting facilities such as
ours require a permit under the Federal Emission Control Act (Bundes Immisionsschutzgesetz, “BImSchG”),
which encompasses various approvals necessary for the construction and operation of facilities pursuant to
other laws, including public-law approvals, registrations and consents. The operation of the relevant facility
can generally not be challenged or contested by third parties as long as the respective facility operates in
compliance with its permit. In such cases, third parties can only require certain measures to mitigate any
negative impact of a facility on the environment. To the extent such measures are impossible or uneconomical
to implement based on state-of-the-art technology, the relevant third parties may only claim damages. Permits
and additional administrative orders under the BImSchG may impose certain limitations (e.g. stricter
requirements with regard to permissible emissions or the use of the relevant facilities), with which we have to
comply. A violation of the operator’s duties as determined in the respective permit (or an additional
administrative order) or a modification of the relevant legal standards may also lead to a restriction or, in
severe cases, a prohibition of the further operation of the facility and/or the revocation of its permit under
certain circumstances. The competent authority may even ask for removal of the facility.

Moreover, the operation of our production sites is subject to the various duties of the Federal Water
Management Act (Wasserhaushaltsgesetz), the State Water Acts in each of the German states
(Landeswassergesetze) and the respective federal and/or state regulations (Rechtsverordnungen). These
regulations govern the use of water during our production, particularly the production of de-inked pulp from
recovered paper and in preparing the liquid base stock (consisting primarily of water and pulp) for use in our
paper machines. According to the Federal Water Management Act, as well as the corresponding state (Länder)
laws, the use of water generally requires the approval by the competent authority. In particular, the extraction
of above-ground water, the discharge of waste water and the pouring and discharge of materials are all aspects
of production that require regulatory approval. In cases of violations of the relevant provisions, we may be
required to pay damages or become subject to penalties. Depending on the type of permit, it may either be
revoked any time or only under certain circumstances.

**Chemicals Legislation and Regulations**

We are subject to Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006 concerning the Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and
Restriction of Chemicals (“REACH”). We use certain chemicals, primarily in connection with the production
of de-inked pulp from recovered paper. The aim of REACH is to improve the protection of human health and
the environment through better and earlier identification of the intrinsic properties of chemical substances.
REACH places greater responsibility on industry participants to manage the risks from chemicals and to
provide safety information on the substances. As a “downstream user”pursuant to REACH, we are primarily
required to adhere to the recommended risk reduction measures, to forward our customers and suppliers the
relevant information and, if necessary, to arrange for a chemical safety report to be prepared.

In addition, we are subject to the provisions of the Chemicals Act (Gesetz zum Schutz vor gefährlichen
_Stoffen—Chemikaliengesetz) and related regulations (Rechtsverordnungen). The Chemicals Act is intended to_
minimize the risks from chemicals for humans and the environment. Based on the Chemicals Act and related
regulations, the competent authorities have the power to—among others—require that certain materials or


-----

chemicals (i) may either not be produced, marketed or used at all, (ii) may only be produced, marketed or used
in a certain manner or for specific purposes, (iii) may only be used under certain circumstances or (iv) may
only be distributed to certain persons. We are not aware of any such orders having been issued by the German
government authorities that would have an impact on our business.

**Regulation on Soil Contamination**

Pursuant to the German Federal Soil Protection Act (Bundes Bodenschutzgesetz, “BBodSchG”), the
responsibility for residual pollution and harmful changes to the soil lies with the party who caused a harmful
soil change or a contaminated site, its universal successor, the relevant property owner, the occupant of the
relevant real property and, if the title was transferred after March 1, 1999, the previous owner of the property,
if they knew or must have known about the contamination. There is no general statutory ranking as to which
of the aforementioned parties is primarily liable. Rather, this decision is made at the discretion of the relevant
local authority who will take into account the effectiveness of remediation as a prevailing factor. Thus, the
current owner of the contaminated property is usually the first party to be held responsible because the owner
is generally in the best position to undertake the necessary remediation work. However, the other responsible
parties are required to indemnify the party that carried out the remediation work, regardless of which party is
held liable by the relevant local authority. Where no other arrangements are agreed upon, the obligation to
provide compensation and the extent of the compensation to be provided depend on the extent to which the
hazard or damage was caused primarily by one party or the other. Liability is not based on fault. Thus, the
BBodSchG does not require the relevant local authority to prove negligence or intent on the part of the liable
parties.

According to the BBodSchG the competent authority may require risk inspections, investigations, remedial
measures and other measures necessary for the prevention of residual pollution or harmful changes in the
soil.

**Climate Change and Emission Trading**

In 2003, the European Parliament adopted the Emission Trading Directive 2003/87/EC which was
transformed into national law at the level of the EU member states. Through the trading system for emission
allowances, the EU intends to considerably reduce the output of greenhouse gases. Industrial sites, such as
our paper machines located at our sites within the European Union, to which the EU Emission Trading
System (“ETS”) applies, receive a certain number of allowances to emit greenhouse gases and must surrender
one allowance for each ton of greenhouse gases emitted. Sites that emit fewer tons of greenhouse gases than
their allowances cover are allowed to sell their excess allowances in the open market, whereas those that emit
more are required to buy additional allowances through the ETS. Participation in this system has been
mandatory since 2005 for all industries with high energy consumption levels, including the paper industry.
The emission allowance auctioning was introduced for the manufacturing sector beginning in 2013. Pursuant
to the amended version of the ETS, as modified by the 2018 Directive (EU) 2018/410, the 30% of free
allocations will be reduced after 2026 to 0% by 2030.

Under the ETS, the EU-wide cap of relevant emissions is lowered annually by a certain linear factor. Initially,
the factor amounted to 1.74% of the average annual total quantity of emission allowances issued in the EU in
the second trading period (2008 through 2012). As part of its Fit for 55 Package, the European Commission
announced in 2021 that the ETS aims to reduce emissions by around 43% by 2030 compared to 2005 levels.
According to calculations by the European Commission, sectors covered by the revised ETS, such as the
paper industry, will need to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions even more, by 61% compared to 2005 levels.
To achieve this, the annual emissions cap in line with the pathway to meeting the higher 2030 ambition will
need to be lowered. The EU Commission’s proposal is to increase the linear reduction factor from the current
2.2 % to 4.2%. As the fourth trading period has already started and the linear reduction factor can only be
adjusted at a later date, an additional one-off cap reduction is also intended to bring the cap trajectory onto a
linear emissions reduction path from 2021 onwards. As a result, affected companies whose emissions exceed
their emission allowances will have to purchase a significant, and steadily increasing, share of emission
allowances in auctions, which may result in substantial additional cost for such companies.

In Germany, the Emission Trading Directive 2003/87/EC has been implemented by the German Greenhouse
Gas Emission Trading Act (Treibhausgas Emissionshandelsgesetz), which provides the basis of the German
emission trading scheme. Moreover, plant operators are required to submit monitoring reports on a regular
basis.

**Other Regulations**

We are affected by the German Renewable Energy Financing Act (Energiefinanzierungsgesetz, “EnFG”) which
forms the basis of a series of German laws that originally provided a feed-in tariff scheme to encourage the
generation of electricity from renewable sources. The EnFG is used to finance the expenditures of the grid
operators under the Renewable Energy Sources Act (Erneuerbare-Energien-Gesetz, “EEG”) and the
Combined Heat and Power Act (Kraft-Wärme-Kopplungsgesetz, “KWKG”) as well as in connection with the
offshore grid connection. The law regulates, inter alia, the compensation of the KWKG financing
requirements and the offshore connection costs by levying levies, the reduction or limitation of levies when
they are levied and a compensation mechanism. The EnFG affects us both financially and administratively.

In Germany, it is also currently expected that certain parts of the German energy tax regulations will be
changed at the beginning of 2024, which could result in significantly lower energy tax reductions for the
German energy-intensive industry. At the same time, a general reduction of the German energy tax to the
European minimum tax level is being discussed to offset potential disadvantages for energy-intensive
companies manufacturing in Germany.

**INSURANCE**

We maintain various insurance policies for different aspects of our business. These policies are centrally
managed by our insurance department in Arnsberg, with the support of our insurance broker SüdVers. Our
insurance coverage includes all-risk policies insuring against property destruction, damage and loss, as well as
against business interruption directly resulting from any property damage. In addition, we maintain liability
insurance coverage with regard to general operating liability, radiation liability and environmental liability, as
well as transport and accident insurance. We obtain insurance coverage for particular risks based on an
internal risk analysis. We believe that we maintain adequate insurance coverage commensurate to our business
and production volumes and in line with industry practice, with deductibles and coverage limits that we
believe to be reasonable and appropriate. We continuously re-evaluate the appropriateness of our insurance
coverage in the ordinary course. There can be no assurance, however, that we will not suffer losses that may
either not be covered by insurance or that may exceed the coverage amount under the relevant insurance
policies.

**INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY**

Our IT & Digital department, which consisted of 64 employees (excluding those of our Parent and
Wepa.digital GmbH) as of September 30, 2023, is organized in a decentralized manner. The local IT teams at
each of our sites are supported by our central IT department in Arnsberg, Germany, and an outsourced
external IT provider based in Mumbai, India. On a project-by-project basis, we also make use of the services
of Wepa.digital GmbH, a subsidiary of our Parent based in Düsseldorf, which has a dedicated IT project
team.

We rely on a number of IT systems to support our business operations. We have implemented application
specific measures, such as stable and redundantly-designed IT systems, backup processes, virus and access
protection and encryption systems as well as standardized IT infrastructure and applications. We regularly
test and update our IT systems, and employees receive regular training on information and data protection. In
addition, a business recovery plan is in place that sets forth the procedures to follow in the event of an extended
outage of IT services in order to restore services as quickly as possible.

As such systems are vulnerable to a number of problems, such as software or hardware malfunctions, malicious
hacking, physical damage to vital data centers and computer virus infection, we make continuous investments
to adapt these complex and high-performing systems to changing business processes. In addition, our IT
systems are regularly upgraded to accommodate the expansion of our business and maintain the efficiency of
our operations.

Our core applications are currently being moved into a data center managed by Oracle in Frankfurt am Main,
Germany. Other non-core information technology systems are operated locally by our subsidiaries.

Following the 2022 Cyber Attack, we have further invested into the protection of our IT landscape from cyber
crime and to safeguard our digital assets. We also frequently review our processes to prevent, protect and react
in case of cyber crime events. We plan to continue to invest in our cyber defense capabilities and to continue
to train our user community with a view to improving awareness of cyber crime.

**SUSTAINABILITY**

Since its foundation in 1948, our Group has been oriented towards sustainability. The concept of sustainability
is firmly rooted in our corporate culture and is an integral part of our corporate strategy. Our holistic
philosophy values economic, ecological and social aspects of our performance. As early as 1983, we began
producing recycled tissue paper and subsequently started to invest significantly in facilities for the recycling of
recovered paper and in developing recycled tissue products. In 2010, we were the first tissue producer in
Europe to launch a range of high quality “hybrid” toilet paper and kitchen towels based on fresh fiber, but
with a minimum of 30% of recycled fiber content added to the raw material mix. Over the years, we have
gained significant additional expertise in recycled and hybrid products. Today, we believe we are the leading
producer of tissue products from recovered paper and hybrid products in Europe by volume. In the twelvemonth period ended September 30, 2023, approximately 50% of the finished products produced by us
consisted of recycled or hybrid tissue products, with 22.2% of our finished products being recycled paperbased products (of which 0.6%, or approximately 4,700 tons, related to our new OCC-based products in the
first year of introduction) and 25.4% being hybrid paper products. This compares to only approximately 41%
of finished products produced by us in the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2019 that consisted of
recycled or hybrid products, with only 20.1% of our finished products at such time being recycled paper-based
products and 17.2% being hybrid paper products. Our leading market position in the field of recycled and
hybrid tissue products is supported by our well-invested asset base for the recycling of recovered paper in
Arnsberg, Giershagen, Mainz and Kriebstein, Germany, Swalmen, the Netherlands, Piechowice, Poland and
Château-Thierry, France, with a total annual production capacity of more than 390,000 tons of de-inked
pulp.

In addition to our strong focus on recovered paper for the production of tissue paper, we have also become an
innovation leader for sustainable tissue products and operations. With our retailer customers increasingly
relying on their suppliers, such as us, to meet their own sustainability goals and with end-consumer demand
for products made from sustainable fibers continuously increasing, we have implemented our “4+1 Strategy”.
This strategy defines our sustainability goals in four distinct areas into which we have divided our sustainability
efforts: (i) future fibers, (ii) sustainable production, (iii) sustainable products and (iv) portfolio extension


-----

through innovation. The guiding principle for all of these goals and for how we want to operate as a business
is a strong value foundation (i.e. the “+1” in our “4+1 Strategy”) that encourages responsible conduct as an
employer, social commitment, compliance and product safety. For further information on our 4+1 Strategy,
see “—Our Strategy—Strong Commitment to Sustainability”. As part of our 4+1 Strategy, we have already
been able to reduce the emissions from our own production facilities, including purchased steam, and our
emissions generated from the use of purchased electricity by 16.7% by the end of 2022, compared to 2019.

As part of our increased focus on sustainability, we have recently developed new sustainable fibers made from
both OCC and miscanthus grass. We have been conducting research and development on miscanthus grass, a
particularly environmentally friendly raw material, since 2013. Due to the high cellulose content and rapid
growth of miscanthus grass, it has a particularly high yield of fiber. Miscanthus grass can be cultivated under
eco-friendly conditions (without fertilization or pesticides) because its roots remain in the soil after harvesting,
and extraction of miscanthus grass is extremely efficient. Due to these impressive features of fiber made from
miscanthus grass, we recently launched a new product line of toilet paper and paper towels in our Professional
business unit that combines the unbleached cellulose fibers of miscanthus grass with recovered paper from
paper cups, office paper and used paper towels.

Our sustainability efforts have been validated with various eco-labels and certifications for our products, such
as the “Blue Angel” (“Blauer Engel”) label in Germany, the EU Ecolabel and the Nordic Swan for Europe.
Furthermore, we were also awarded with a Silver Star award in EcoVadis’s sustainability rating, our
miscanthus-based product line BlackSatino GreenGrow has been awarded with the Purus Innovation Award
2023 and our Satino PureSoft products, made from OCC, have been awarded with the German Bundespreis
Ecodesign 2023 award. As a result, we are seeing an increasing demand for these products from retail and
commercial customers as well as the end consumer, which is driven by an increased general focus on
sustainability and the impact of human activity on the environment.

**QUALITY CONTROL**

We focus extensively on operational excellence with the objective of achieving a consistent and positive overall
consumer and customer experience. Our quality control standards are given a high level of importance and
are generally in line with the standards set by other reputable multinational competitors. In addition, we
established a groupwide “Quality Initiative” program to further strengthen important aspects like awareness,
communication as well as training and qualification.

Our internal quality controls include:

- Auditing of supplier qualifications;

- Consistent testing of production, sampling of finished products for workmanship and physical testing
for compliance to pre-approved specifications;

- Generating key performance indicators along with detailed test reports on all semi-finished and finished
products;

- Holding bi-monthly executive meetings to review results, track progress on major issues/opportunities
and set goals as needed;

- Establishing a Rapid Response and Retrieval system (or “RRR”) across our Group, including mock
recall exercises to promote preparedness; and

- Tracking all major start-ups by quality assurance and providing detailed reports to management
throughout the new product development process. All products receive annual specification reviews with
product development and marketing stakeholders.

Our third-party controls include:

- Auditing of all plants according to ISO 9001, ISO 14001 and ISO 50001;

- Certification and auditing of nearly all plants according to IFS Standard;

- Routine customer-initiated third-party audits of our sites; and

- Ranking of performance along key important customer metrics by independent surveys.

**RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT**

We consider research and development to be an important factor in staying competitive and strengthening
our customer relationships, in particular with a view to the continued implementation of our “concept sales”


-----

approach as further described under “—Our Strength—Partner of Choice for Our Customers” and our focus
on inventions in the area of sustainability. In order to ensure a constant flow of know-how and close
technological cooperation between our various Group companies, we centrally coordinate our research and
development activities through a small research department in our facility in Mainz, Germany. Due to our
product portfolio, which consists primarily of standardized, commodity-like tissue paper products, our budget
for research and development measures is, compared to other industries with higher innovation pressure,
relatively low. At the same time, due to our increased focus on sustainability issues as further described under
“—Sustainability”above, also our sustainability team materially contributes to our research and development
activities.

Our research and development activities are primarily focused on the constant improvement of our products
and production processes. In close cooperation with our customers, we constantly work on increasing the
quality of our products, such as softness and strength. We also regularly discuss and evaluate with our
customers their tissue paper product portfolio, the further development of our existing products as well as
special promotions by our customers. We believe that continuous contact with customers across almost all of
our product families, coupled with the scale of our operations, gives us a specific advantage in product and
process development. In addition, both our research and production departments have a strong focus on
constantly improving and optimizing our manufacturing process, aiming to reduce manufacturing, raw
material and transportation costs.

**SALES AND MARKETING**

Our sales and marketing team primarily develops and strengthens new and existing customer relationships
and acquires new orders and business. It plays an essential part in the continued implementation of our
“concept sales”approach as further described under “—Our Strength—Partner of Choice for Our Customers”.
In addition to the acquisition of orders and their handling, the team is also responsible for product
specifications and pricing. The team consisted of an average of 156 employees in 2022. The majority of team
members are located at our headquarters in Arnsberg, which is responsible for regional sales activities in
Germany as well as the coordinating and developing our group wide sales and marketing strategies and
activities. Our local Group companies in Italy, France, Poland, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom are
given certain responsibility for regional sales activities in their respective regions. Our Consumer business unit
accounts for approximately 60% of our marketing and sales team, while the remaining 40% of team members
are active for our Professional business unit or involved in the sale of semi-finished products.

Our marketing team is tasked with market research and supporting the sales team with marketing tools to
optimize our customer portfolios and to build brand equity for our smaller brand business. It plays a strategic
advisory role with retailers, assisting with category management and efficient promotional and shelf
assortment initiatives. Compared to branded label tissue producers, our marketing expense is low.

On December 12, 2019, the Issuer issued €350.0 million and on February 10, 2020, the Issuer issued an

conditions of issue dated as of December 12, 2019 and mature on December 15, 2027. The documentation
required to implement the issue of the Existing Fixed Rate Notes is referred to as the “Existing Fixed Rate
**Notes Documents”.**

The Existing Fixed Rate Notes are guaranteed by Wepa Deutschland GmbH & Co. KG, Wepa Professional
GmbH, Wepa Italia S.r.l., Wepa France S.A.S., Wepa Greenfield S.A.S., Wepa UK Ltd, Wepa Piechowice Sp.

The Existing Fixed Rate Notes constitute senior obligations of the Issuer and rank: (i) equal in right of

Hedging Liabilities and Cash Management Liabilities), (ii) senior in right of payment to any existing and
