**WEPA HYGIENEPRODUKTE GMBH, ARNSBERG**

**UNAUDITED CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE**
**FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)**

**FOR THE NINE-MONTH PERIOD ENDED SEPTEMBER 30, 2023**

The decrease in property, plant and equipment by EUR 3.6 million from EUR 755.2 million as at
31 December 2022 to EUR 751.6 million as at 30 September 2023 is mainly due to the current higher
depreciation related to investments. Offsetting effects result from the expansion of the Kriebstein site with the
purchase of land and buildings as well as facilities for waste paper processing. Furthermore, significant
amounts were invested in paper processing plants and energy-efficient technologies in Germany and abroad.
Depreciation and amortisation in the current year amounted to EUR 43.0 million, with currency effects of
EUR 5.2 million having a positive impact.

Financial assets increased by EUR 0.6 million from EUR 1.2 million as at 31 December 2022 to
EUR 1.8 million as at 30 September 2023 due to some legally required long term loans in France.

**_Inventories_**

Inventories increased by a total of EUR 15.8 million from EUR 333.7 million as at 31 December 2022 to
EUR 349.4 million as at 30 September 2023. This is mainly due to an increase in raw materials and supplies of
EUR 24.0 million from EUR 169.5 million to EUR 193.5 million, while inventories of semi-finished goods
fell by EUR 8.2 million from EUR 73.0 million to EUR 64.8 million.

Overall, inventories continue to be characterized by the inflation of market prices and the associated impact
on inventory valuation.

The EUR 24.0 million increase in raw materials, consumables and supplies is in particular due to the deliberate
build-up of inventories in the pulp area at favorable spot prices. Our inventories are generally influenced by
short-term factors such as seasonal and inflation-related fluctuations in purchase prices for raw materials,
energy and other production factors as well as our own inventory management strategy (e.g. due to potential
availability problems) and that of our main customers on the one hand and long-term factors such as
fluctuations in sales volumes, expansion projects and our investment program on the other.

**_Trade receivables_**

Trade receivables increased by EUR 21.9 million from EUR 122.3 million as at 31 December 2022 to
EUR 144.2 million as at 30 September 2023. The volume of receivables sold as part of the ABS program was
deliberately reduced, which led to a corresponding increase in trade receivables (EUR 70.7 million). In
contrast, trade receivables from operating activities decreased by EUR 48.5 million compared to
31 December 2022, this corresponds to the lower overall sales in the third quarter of 2023 compared to the last
quarter of 2022.

**_Equity_**

The share capital remains unchanged at EUR 18.1 million.

Equity increased by EUR 114.5 million from EUR 279.2 million as at 31 December 2022 to EUR 393.6 million
as at 30 September 2023.

This increase resulted in particular from the current positive result for the period totaling EUR 123.4 million.
A dividend of EUR 12.7 million was paid out to shareholders in the current financial year.

The negative difference from currency translation decreased by EUR 3.7 million from EUR -15.8 million as at
31 December 2022 to EUR -12.1 million as at 30 September 2023. This amount results from the currency
translation of the individual financial statements included in the consolidation with a functional currency
other than EUR (UK and Poland) and was calculated in accordance with section 308a German Commercial
Code.

**_Difference from capital consolidation_**

The difference from capital consolidation decreased by EUR 1.6 million from EUR 18.3 million as at
31 December 2022 to EUR 16.7 million as at 30 September 2023. The negative goodwill from capital
consolidation as at 31 December 2022 was released to schedule.

**WEPA HYGIENEPRODUKTE GMBH, ARNSBERG**

**UNAUDITED CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE**
**FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)**

**FOR THE NINE-MONTH PERIOD ENDED SEPTEMBER 30, 2023**

**_Provisions_**

Provisions increased by EUR 37.0 million from EUR 135.5 million as at 31 December 2022 to
EUR 172.5 million as at 30 September 2023. EUR 22.6 million of this increase is attributable to the increase
in tax provisions due to the improved result.

Other provisions increased by EUR 14.5 million, mainly due to the increase in impending losses for pending
transactions and for personnel and energy costs, while they declined in other areas.

Provisions are recognised for all identifiable risks and contingent liabilities. They were valued at the amount
required according to prudent business judgement.

**_Bonds and liabilities to banks_**

Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH has issued two bonds (Senior Secured Notes) in a total amount of
EUR 600,000 thousand. One note of EUR 400,000 thousand with a term until 2027 and a fixed interest
coupon of 2.875% and one note of EUR 200,000 thousand with a term until 2026 and a variable interest
coupon of 3-month EURIBOR plus 2.875%.

Liabilities to banks increased by EUR 0.9 million from EUR 0.8 million as at 31 December 2022 to
EUR 1.7 million as at 30 September 2023. This mainly relates to the liabilities of a subsidiary that was not
previously included in cash pooling.

The working capital credit line (RCF) with a volume of EUR 150,000 thousand has a term until
December 2026. EUR 3.6 million of this working capital credit line had been drawn down as at 30 June 2023
for sureties and guarantees. In addition, a guarantee for EUR 6.6 million was still in place with another bank
as at the reporting date.

**Notes to individual items in the income statement**

**_Sales revenues_**

Sales revenues increased by EUR 228.7 million (+19.8%) from EUR 1,153.3 million in the first nine months
to 30 September 2022 to EUR 1,382.0 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023. This sales
growth is mainly due to the increase in our sales prices in response to the sharp rise in purchase prices for our
raw materials and energy.

The total volume of finished goods sold increased by 16,543 tons (3.2%) from 523,972 tons in the first
nine months to 30 September 2022 to 540,516 tons in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

Sales of parent rolls decreased by 1,001 tons (-4.4%) from 22,942 tons in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to 21,941 tons in the first nine months to 30 September 2023. Sales of de-inked paper
decreased by 13,181 tons (-32.3%) from 40,806 tons in the first nine months to 30 September 2022 to 27,625
tons in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

**_Other operating income_**

Other operating income decreased by EUR 2.0 million from EUR 17.5 million in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to EUR 15.5 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

This is mainly due to the decrease of the income from currency exchange rates by EUR 9.5 million (from
EUR 12.1 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2022 to EUR 2.6 million in the first nine months
to 30 September 2023).

The release of provisions increased by EUR 4.5 million (from EUR 0.1 million in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to EUR 4.6 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023) and the income relating
to other periods increased by EUR 2.0 million from EUR 2.8 million in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to EUR 4.8 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.


-----

**WEPA HYGIENEPRODUKTE GMBH, ARNSBERG**

**UNAUDITED CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE**
**FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)**

**FOR THE NINE-MONTH PERIOD ENDED SEPTEMBER 30, 2023**

**_Cost of materials_**

The cost of materials decreased by EUR 23.5 million (-2.9%) from EUR 800.0 million in the first nine months
to 30 September 2022 to EUR 776.5 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

This reduction is mainly due to the reduction in purchase prices, particularly for waste paper and energy and
also other materials, some of which had become massively more expensive in previous periods.

The reduction of EUR 4.6 million or -0.8% in the cost of raw materials, consumables and supplies is
disproportionately attributable to waste paper costs (reduction of 29.0%). The value of purchases of
merchandise and parent rolls also decreased.

There was an opposite trend in the pulp area, where there was an increase of 9.9% due to further price
increases compared to the same period in the previous year.

Services purchased decreased by EUR 18.9 million (-8.1%) from EUR 232.5 million in the first nine months
to 30 September 2022 to EUR 213.7 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023. This includes a
reduction in energy costs of 13.3% or EUR 26.6 million from EUR 199.3 million in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to EUR 172.7 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

In relation to total operating performance, the cost of materials decreased from 66.3% in the first nine months
to 30 September 2022 to 56.4% in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

**_Personnel expense_**

Personnel expenses increased by EUR 20.9 million from EUR 170.8 million in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to EUR 191.7 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023, of which
EUR 17.2 million is attributable to wages and salaries and EUR 3.6 million to the corresponding social
security contributions.

The higher personnel costs are caused by a moderate further increase in personnel as well as increases in tariff
and non-tariff wages and salaries.

The average number of employees increased from 3,775 employees in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to 3,877 employees in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

**_Depreciation_**

Depreciation and amortisation increased by EUR 1.6 million from EUR 44.0 million in the first nine months
to 30 September 2022 to EUR 45.6 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023. This included
impairment losses of EUR 0.8 million in the current year, compared to EUR 0.4 million in the previous year.

**_Other operating expenses_**

Other operating expenses decreased by EUR 2.7 million from EUR 190.5 million in the first nine months to
30 September 2022 to EUR 187.8 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.

Expenses from currency exchange rates decreased by EUR 11.2 million from EUR 14.5 million in the first
nine months to 30 September 2022 to EUR 3.3 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023 and
expenses relating to other periods decreased by EUR 1.5 million from EUR 4.3 million in the first nine months
to 30 September 2022 to EUR 2.8 million by 30 September 2023.

In contrast, other expenses from operating activities increased by EUR 8.8 million from EUR 55.1 million in
the first nine months to 30 September 2022 to EUR 63.9 million in the first nine months to 30 September 2023.
These include various expenses such as increased expenses for IT licences, legal and consulting costs and the
costs of celebrating the Wepa Group’s 75th anniversary.

The following auditor’s report, prepared in accordance with § 322 HGB [“Handelsgesetzbuch”: “German
Commercial Code”], refers to the complete consolidated financial statements, comprising the consolidated
balance sheet, the consolidated statement of profit and loss, consolidated statement of changes in equity and
consolidated statement of cash flows, together with the group management report of the Wepa
Hygieneprodukte GmbH for the financial year from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022. The group
management report is not included in this prospectus. The above-mentioned auditor’s report and consolidated
financial statements are both translations of the respective German-language documents.

**Independent Auditor’s Report**

To Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH, Arnsberg

**Opinions**

We have audited the consolidated financial statements of Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH, Arnsberg and its
subsidiaries (the Group), which comprise the consolidated statement of financial position as at December 31,
2022, the consolidated statement of profit and loss, consolidated statement of changes in equity and
consolidated statement of cash flows for the financial year from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022, and
notes to the consolidated financial statements, including the recognition and measurement policies presented
therein. In addition, we have audited the group management report of Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH for the
financial year from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022.

In our opinion, on the basis of the knowledge obtained in the audit,

- the accompanying consolidated financial statements comply, in all material respects, with the
requirements of German commercial law and give a true and fair view of the assets, liabilities, and
financial position of the Group as at December 31, 2022, and of its financial performance for the financial
year from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022 in compliance with German Legally Required
Accounting Principles, and

- the accompanying group management report as a whole provides an appropriate view of the Group’s
position. In all material respects, this group management report is consistent with the consolidated
financial statements, complies with German legal requirements and appropriately presents the
opportunities and risks of future development.

Pursuant to Section 322 (3) sentence 1 HGB [Handelsgesetzbuch: German Commercial Code], we declare that
our audit has not led to any reservations relating to the legal compliance of the consolidated financial
statements and of the group management report.

**Basis for the Opinions**

We conducted our audit of the consolidated financial statements and of the group management report in
accordance with Section 317 HGB and in compliance with German Generally Accepted Standards for
Financial Statement Audits promulgated by the Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer [Institute of Public Auditors in
Germany] (IDW). Our responsibilities under those requirements and principles are further described in the
“Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and of the Group
Management Report”section of our auditor’s report. We are independent of the group entities in accordance
with the requirements of German commercial and professional law, and we have fulfilled our other German
professional responsibilities in accordance with these requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have
obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinions on the consolidated financial
statements and on the group management report.

**Responsibilities of Management for the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Group Management Report**

Management is responsible for the preparation of the consolidated financial statements that comply, in all
material respects, with the requirements of German commercial law and that the consolidated financial
statements, in compliance with German Legally Required Accounting Principles, give a true and fair view of
the assets, liabilities, financial position, and financial performance of the Group. In addition, management is
responsible for such internal control as they, in accordance with German Legally Required Accounting
Principles, have determined necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are
free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability
to continue as a going concern. They also have the responsibility for disclosing, as applicable, matters related


-----

to going concern. In addition, they are responsible for financial reporting based on the going concern basis of
accounting provided no actual or legal circumstances conflict therewith.

Furthermore, management is responsible for the preparation of the group management report that, as a
whole, provides an appropriate view of the Group’s position and is, in all material respects, consistent with the
consolidated financial statements, complies with German legal requirements, and appropriately presents the
opportunities and risks of future development. In addition, management is responsible for such arrangements
and measures (systems) as they have considered necessary to enable the preparation of a group management
report that is in accordance with the applicable German legal requirements, and to be able to provide sufficient
appropriate evidence for the assertions in the group management report.

**Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and of the Group Management**
**Report**

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a
whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and whether the group management
report as a whole provides an appropriate view of the Group’s position and, in all material respects, is
consistent with the consolidated financial statements and the knowledge obtained in the audit, complies with
the German legal requirements and appropriately presents the opportunities and risks of future development,
as well as to issue an auditor’s report that includes our opinions on the consolidated financial statements and
on the group management report. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee
that an audit conducted in accordance with Section 317 HGB and in compliance with German Generally
Accepted Standards for Financial Statement Audits promulgated by the Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer (IDW)
will always detect a material misstatement. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered
material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic
decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements and this group management
report.

We exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. We also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements and of the
group management report, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive
to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our
opinions. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one
resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations,
or the override of internal controls.

- Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit of the consolidated financial statements
and of arrangements and measures (systems) relevant to the audit of the group management report in
order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of
expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of these systems.

- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used by management and the reasonableness of
estimates made by management and related disclosures.

- Conclude on the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and,
based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions
that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that
a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in the auditor’s report to the related
disclosures in the consolidated financial statements and in the group management report or, if such
disclosures are inadequate, to modify our respective opinions. Our conclusions are based on the audit
evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause
the Group to cease to be able to continue as a going concern.

- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements,
including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements present the underlying
transactions and events in a manner that the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view
of the assets, liabilities, financial position and financial performance of the Group in compliance with
German Legally Required Accounting Principles.

- Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or
business activities within the Group to express [audit] opinions on the consolidated financial statements
and on the group management report. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance
of the group audit. We remain solely responsible for our [audit] opinions.


-----

- Evaluate the consistency of the group management report with the consolidated financial statements, its
conformity with [German] law, and the view of the Group’s position it provides.

- Perform audit procedures on the prospective information presented by management in the group
management report. On the basis of sufficient appropriate audit evidence we evaluate, in particular, the
significant assumptions used by management as a basis for the prospective information, and evaluate the
proper derivation of the prospective information from these assumptions. We do not express a separate
opinion on the prospective information and on the assumptions used as a basis. There is a substantial
unavoidable risk that future events will differ materially from the prospective information.

We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and
timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control
that we identify during our audit.

**Disclosures regarding consolidation methods**

The financial statements of the individual companies are prepared in accordance with uniform accounting
and valuation principles for inclusion in the consolidated financial statements.

Capital consolidation is carried out according to the revaluation method by offsetting the acquisition costs of
the participation against the Group’s share in the revalued equity of the consolidated subsidiaries at the time
of initial consolidation in accordance with § 301 Para. 1 HGB. The recognisable assets, liabilities and
contingent liabilities of the subsidiaries are recognised at their fair values, irrespective of the amount of the
minority interest.

Hidden reserves and charges in existence at the time of the initial consolidation are disclosed and accounted
for in accordance with the underlying assets and liabilities.

Remaining differences on the assets side (goodwill) are capitalised and depreciated according to schedule
pursuant to § 309 Para. 1 in conjunction with § 253 Para. 3 S. 4 HGB over 10 years or, if necessary, written
down on an unscheduled basis. Any remaining negative goodwill is treated in accordance with § 309 Para.
2 HGB or German Accounting Standard.

Shares in non-consolidated companies are valued at the lower of cost or fair value.

Intercompany profits, sales, expenses and income as well as all receivables and liabilities between the
consolidated companies are eliminated.

The translation of the annual financial statements of the consolidated companies prepared in foreign
currencies is carried out on the basis of § 308a HGB.

Accordingly, in the consolidated financial statements, the assets and liabilities of these companies are
translated at the closing rate, equity items are translated at historical rates, and expenses and income are
translated at the average rate for the year. Resulting translation differences are recognised directly in equity
under the item equity difference from currency translation. Changes in the exchange rates of intercompany
receivables and liabilities are generally recognised directly in equity.

**Disclosures regarding accounting and valuation methods**

The following accounting and valuation methods are authoritative for the preparation of the consolidated
financial statements:

**Intangible assets acquired for a consideration are capitalised at acquisition cost and, if they are subject to**
wear and tear, reduced by scheduled straight-line amortisation in accordance with their useful life.

The scheduled amortisation of goodwill from capital consolidation is carried out in accordance with
§ 309 Para. 1 in conjunction with § 253 Para. 3 S.3 HGB on a straight-line basis over a period of 10 years.
Current developments are taken into account—if necessary—through unscheduled depreciation.

**Property, plant and equipment are valued at acquisition cost, taking into account scheduled depreciation. In**
the event of permanent impairment, unscheduled depreciation is taken into account. Scheduled depreciation
on fixed assets is exclusively carried out according to the straight-line method.

**CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 2022 (Continued)**

**Financial assets are valued at acquisition cost. If the value to be attributed to the financial assets on the**
balance sheet date is expected to be permanently below the acquisition cost, this is recognised.

**Raw materials, consumables and supplies as well as merchandise are valued at acquisition cost in compliance**
with the strict principle of the lower of cost or market.

**Unfinished goods are recognised at production cost, which includes direct production and material costs as**
well as appropriate portions of production, material and administrative overheads and depreciation. Interest
on borrowed capital is not included in the production costs.

**Finished goods are predominantly determined by calculating the production costs; some companies value the**
production costs using the retrograde method. In addition to direct production and material costs, the
calculation of production costs also includes appropriate portions of production, material and administrative
overheads as well as depreciation. Interest on borrowed capital is not included in the manufacturing costs.
The valuation of production costs according to the retrograde method is carried out by deducting the sales
and distribution overheads still to be incurred as well as the profit margin from the sales price after sales
deductions.

In the current financial year, the production cost for the German companies was calculated for the first time
in order to improve the insight into the net assets, financial position and results of operations. This led to a
significant reduction in the valuation.

**Inventory risks are taken into account by applying appropriate valuation discounts.**

**Receivables and other assets are valued at nominal value or at the lower fair value on the balance sheet date.**
Appropriate individual value adjustments are made for receivables that are at risk due to individual risks; the
general credit risk is taken into account by means of lumpsum deductions. Receivables in foreign currencies
with a remaining term of less than one year are translated at the average spot exchange rate on the balance
sheet date. Receivables in foreign currency with a remaining term of more than one year are recognised at the
lower of cost or the value resulting from the valuation at the average spot exchange rate on the balance sheet
date.

Trade receivables are sold by WEPA Hygieneprodukte GmbH and various subsidiaries as part of ABS
transactions, with the credit risk being transferred to the buyer. The trade receivables are reported at a
correspondingly reduced level. The administration of the receivables is taken over for the buyer by WEPA
Hygieneprodukte GmbH or the respective subsidiary.

The share capital is fully paid in and is shown at nominal value.

The pension provisions for vested rights and current pension obligations are calculated according to the
projected unit credit method using the “2018 G mortality tables” (Generationsrichttafeln) by Prof. Dr Klaus
Heubeck. The calculation was made in accordance with § 253 Para. 1 S. 2 HGB, § 253 Para. 2 HGB.

The average market interest rate of the past 10 years with a remaining term of 15 years of 1.78% (previous
year: 1.89%) was used for discounting in accordance with the Ordinance on the Discounting of Provisions of
18 November 2009. A calculation using the average market interest rate of the past 7 financial years would
result in a pension provision that is kEUR 40.0 higher.

Expected salary increases were taken into account at 2.0 % (previous year: 2.0 %) and pension increases at
2.0 % (previous year: 2.0 %). As in the previous year, no fluctuation was taken into account. Expenses or
income resulting from changes in the discount rate are reported in the financial result.

The long-term obligations of the foreign companies towards their employees were calculated according to the
country-specific conditions in analogous application of the provisions of the German Commercial Code. The
corresponding obligations are reported under other provisions.

**Tax provisions and other provisions are made for all identifiable risks and uncertain liabilities. They are**
recognised at the settlement amount required according to reasonable commercial judgement, taking into
account price and cost increases. Provisions with a remaining term of more than one year are discounted at
the average market interest rate of the past seven financial years corresponding to their remaining term.

**Off-balance sheet transactions**

The WEPA Group has a receivables-based financing (ABS structure). This was restructured in the 2022
financial year. The term was extended until June 2027 (previously: until June 2023) and the financing volume
was increased to up to EUR 220.0 million (previously: up to EUR 150.0 million). The ABS financing is
available to WEPA Hygieneprodukte GmbH and various subsidiaries and was utilised by all companies in the
amount of EUR 216.0 million (previous year: EUR 130.0 million) on the balance sheet date.

As the Wepa Group no longer bears any credit risks from the sold receivables and these have been transferred
in full to the financing bank, economic ownership has been transferred and the receivables have been
derecognised by the Wepa Group. Apart from the intended inflow of liquidity, this procedure leads to a
reduction in trade receivables and—due to the use of the additional liquidity for the repayment of short-term
liabilities—a reduction of the balance sheet total.

**Derivative financial instruments**

Derivative financial instruments are used to hedge interest rate, foreign exchange and commodity procurement
risks from booked, pending and planned underlying transactions. Hedging is carried out exclusively in the
name and for the account of WEPA Hygieneprodukte GmbH.

The booked and pending underlying transactions can be combined with the hedging transactions within the
framework of micro and portfolio hedging to form HGB valuation units, separated according to commodity,
foreign exchange and interest rate hedging instruments. The HGB valuation units are valued individually as at
the balance sheet date.

The valuation methods and assumptions underlying the determination of the fair value are as follows:

Forward exchange transactions and swaps are valued at the forward rate on the balance sheet date. Options
are valued according to their design using Black-Scholes models or modifications thereof. Instruments to
hedge currency, interest rate and commodity risks are valued by discounting the future cash flows. Discounting
is based on market interest rates over the remaining term of the instruments. The exchange amounts from
these hedging instruments are recognised in profit or loss at the time of payment or accrual on the reporting
date.

According to valuation principles under German commercial law, a negative valuation result of the respective
hedging transaction leads to the formation of a provision for anticipated losses from pending transactions,
insofar as no effective valuation unit was initially formed, while a positive valuation result is not taken into
account.

The WEPA Group strives to achieve a balanced risk/reward ratio. Therefore, depending on the assessment of
the market situation, the total requirement for currencies or financing volume is generally hedged in a range
between 50% and 90% over the course of a year in order to be able to react to unpredictable developments in
interest rates and currencies when calculating prices. In the case of raw materials, purchase prices are hedged
via commodity swaps; here, too, depending on the market situation, hedging is aimed for, which generally
ranges from 30% to 90% over the course of a year. The primary objective remains to hedge the calculation
rates on which the planning is based.

**Independent Auditor’s Report**

To Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH, Arnsberg

**Opinions**

We have audited the consolidated financial statements of Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH, Arnsberg and its
subsidiaries (the Group), which comprise the consolidated statement of financial position as at December 31,
2021, the consolidated statement of profit and loss, consolidated statement of changes in equity and
consolidated statement of cash flows for the financial year from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021, and
notes to the consolidated financial statements, including the recognition and measurement policies presented
therein. In addition, we have audited the group management report of Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH for the
financial year from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021.

In our opinion, on the basis of the knowledge obtained in the audit,

- the accompanying consolidated financial statements comply, in all material respects, with the
requirements of German commercial law and give a true and fair view of the assets, liabilities, and
financial position of the Group as at December 31, 2021, and of its financial performance for the financial
year from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021 in compliance with German Legally Required
Accounting Principles, and

- the accompanying group management report as a whole provides an appropriate view of the Group’s
position. In all material respects, this group management report is consistent with the consolidated
financial statements, complies with German legal requirements and appropriately presents the
opportunities and risks of future development.

Pursuant to Section 322 (3) sentence 1 HGB [Handelsgesetzbuch: German Commercial Code], we declare that
our audit has not led to any reservations relating to the legal compliance of the consolidated financial
statements and of the group management report.

**Basis for the Opinions**

We conducted our audit of the consolidated financial statements and of the group management report in
accordance with Section 317 HGB and in compliance with German Generally Accepted Standards for
Financial Statement Audits promulgated by the Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer [Institute of Public Auditors in
Germany] (IDW). Our responsibilities under those requirements and principles are further described in the
“Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and of the Group
Management Report”section of our auditor’s report. We are independent of the group entities in accordance
with the requirements of German commercial and professional law, and we have fulfilled our other German
professional responsibilities in accordance with these requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have
obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinions on the consolidated financial
statements and on the group management report.

**Responsibilities of Management for the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Group Management Report**

Management is responsible for the preparation of the consolidated financial statements that comply, in all
material respects, with the requirements of German commercial law and that the consolidated financial
statements, in compliance with German Legally Required Accounting Principles, give a true and fair view of
the assets, liabilities, financial position, and financial performance of the Group. In addition, management is
responsible for such internal control as they, in accordance with German Legally Required Accounting
Principles, have determined necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are
free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability
to continue as a going concern. They also have the responsibility for disclosing, as applicable, matters related


-----

to going concern. In addition, they are responsible for financial reporting based on the going concern basis of
accounting provided no actual or legal circumstances conflict therewith.

Furthermore, management is responsible for the preparation of the group management report that, as a
whole, provides an appropriate view of the Group’s position and is, in all material respects, consistent with the
consolidated financial statements, complies with German legal requirements, and appropriately presents the
opportunities and risks of future development. In addition, management is responsible for such arrangements
and measures (systems) as they have considered necessary to enable the preparation of a group management
report that is in accordance with the applicable German legal requirements, and to be able to provide sufficient
appropriate evidence for the assertions in the group management report.

**Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and of the Group Management**
**Report**

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a
whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and whether the group management
report as a whole provides an appropriate view of the Group’s position and, in all material respects, is
consistent with the consolidated financial statements and the knowledge obtained in the audit, complies with
the German legal requirements and appropriately presents the opportunities and risks of future development,
as well as to issue an auditor’s report that includes our opinions on the consolidated financial statements and
on the group management report. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee
that an audit conducted in accordance with Section 317 HGB and in compliance with German Generally
Accepted Standards for Financial Statement Audits promulgated by the Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer (IDW)
will always detect a material misstatement. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered
material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic
decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements and this group management
report.

We exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. We also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements and of the
group management report, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive
to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our
opinions. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one
resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations,
or the override of internal controls.

- Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit of the consolidated financial statements
and of arrangements and measures (systems) relevant to the audit of the group management report in
order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of
expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of these systems.

- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used by management and the reasonableness of
estimates made by management and related disclosures.

- Conclude on the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and,
based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions
that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that
a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in the auditor’s report to the related
disclosures in the consolidated financial statements and in the group management report or, if such
disclosures are inadequate, to modify our respective opinions. Our conclusions are based on the audit
evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause
the Group to cease to be able to continue as a going concern.

- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements,
including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements present the underlying
transactions and events in a manner that the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view
of the assets, liabilities, financial position and financial performance of the Group in compliance with
German Legally Required Accounting Principles.

- Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or
business activities within the Group to express [audit] opinions on the consolidated financial statements
and on the group management report. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance
of the group audit. We remain solely responsible for our [audit] opinions.

- Evaluate the consistency of the group management report with the consolidated financial statements, its
conformity with [German] law, and the view of the Group’s position it provides.

- Perform audit procedures on the prospective information presented by management in the group
management report. On the basis of sufficient appropriate audit evidence we evaluate, in particular, the
significant assumptions used by management as a basis for the prospective information, and evaluate the
proper derivation of the prospective information from these assumptions. We do not express a separate
opinion on the prospective information and on the assumptions used as a basis. There is a substantial
unavoidable risk that future events will differ materially from the prospective information.

We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and
timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control
that we identify during our audit.

**Disclosures regarding consolidation methods**

The financial statements of the individual companies are prepared in accordance with uniform accounting
and valuation principles for inclusion in the consolidated financial statements.

Capital consolidation is carried out according to the revaluation method by offsetting the acquisition costs of
the participation against the Group’s share in the revalued equity of the consolidated subsidiaries at the time
of initial consolidation in accordance with § 301 (1) of the German Commercial Code. The recognisable
assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities of the subsidiaries are recognised at their fair values, irrespective of
the amount of the minority interest.

Hidden reserves and liabilities existing at the time of initial consolidation are disclosed and ccounted for in
accordance with the underlying assets and liabilities.

Remaining differences on the assets side (goodwill) are capitalised and depreciated according to schedule
pursuant to § 309 para. 1 in conjunction with § 253 para. 3 sentence 4 of the German Commercial Code over
10 years or, if necessary, written down on an unscheduled basis. Any remaining negative goodwill is treated in
accordance with § 309 para. 2 of the German Commercial Code or German Accounting Standard 4,
respectively.

Shares in non-consolidated companies are valued at the lower of cost or fair value.

Intercompany profits, sales, expenses and income as well as all receivables and liabilities between the
consolidated companies are eliminated.

The translation of the annual financial statements of the consolidated companies prepared in foreign
currencies is carried out on the basis of § 308a of the German Commercial Code.

Accordingly, in the consolidated financial statements, the assets and liabilities of these companies are
translated at the closing rate, equity items are translated at historical rates, and expenses and income are
translated at the average rate for the year. Resulting translation differences are recognised directly in equity
under the item equity difference from currency translation. Changes in the exchange rates of intercompany
receivables and liabilities are generally recognised directly in equity.

**Disclosures on accounting and valuation methods**

The financial statements of the individual companies are prepared in accordance with uniform accounting
and valuation principles for inclusion in the consolidated financial statements.

**Intangible assets acquired against payment are capitalised at acquisition cost and, if they are subject to wear**
and tear, reduced by scheduled amortisation in accordance with their useful life.

The scheduled amortisation of goodwill from capital consolidation is carried out in accordance with § 309
Para. 1 in conjunction with § 253 Para. 3 sentence 3 of the German Commercial Code on a straight-line basis
over a period of 10 years. Current developments are taken into account—if necessary—through unscheduled
depreciation.

**Tangible assets are valued at acquisition cost, taking into account scheduled depreciation. In the event of**
permanent impairment, unscheduled depreciation is taken into account. Scheduled depreciation on fixed
assets is exclusively carried out according to the straight-line method.

**WEPA HYGIENEPRODUKTE GMBH, ARNSBERG**

**CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 2021 (Continued)**

**Financial assets are valued at acquisition cost. If the value to be attributed to the financial assets on the**
balance sheet date is permanently below the acquisition cost, this is recognised.

**Raw materials and supplies as well as merchandise are valued at acquisition cost in compliance with the strict**
principle of the lower of cost or market.

**Unfinished goods are recognised at production cost, which includes direct production and material costs as**
well as an appropriate share of production, material and administrative overheads. Interest on borrowed
capital is not included in the production costs.

**Finished goods are valued according to the retrograde method by deducting the sales and distribution**
overheads still to be incurred as well as the profit margin from the sales price after sales deductions.

**Inventory risks are taken into account by considering appropriate valuation discounts.**

**Receivables and other assets are valued at nominal value or at the lower fair value on the balance sheet date.**
Appropriate individual value adjustments are made for receivables that are at risk due to individual risks; the
general credit risk is taken into account by means of lumpsum deductions. Receivables in foreign currencies
with a remaining term of less than one year are translated at the average spot exchange rate on the balance
sheet date. Receivables in foreign currency with a remaining term of more than one year are recognised at the
lower of cost or the value resulting from the valuation at the average spot exchange rate on the balance sheet
date.

Trade receivables are sold by WEPA Hygieneprodukte GmbH and various subsidiaries as part of ABS
transactions, with the credit risk being transferred to the buyer. The trade receivables are reported at a
correspondingly reduced level. The administration of the receivables is taken over for the buyer by WEPA
Hygieneprodukte GmbH or the respective subsidiary.

The share capital is fully paid in and is shown at nominal value.

The pension provisions for vested rights and current pension obligations are calculated according to the
projected unit credit method using the “2018 G mortality tables” (Generationsrichttafeln) by Prof. Dr. Klaus
Heubeck. The calculation was made in accordance with § 253 para. 1 sentence 2 of the German Commercial
Code, § 253 para. 2 of the German Commercial Code.

The average market interest rate of the past 10 years with a remaining term of 15 years of 1.89% (previous
year: 2.32%) was used for discounting in accordance with the Ordinance on the Discounting of Provisions of
18 November 2009. A calculation using the average market interest rate of the past 7 financial years would
result in a pension provision that is EUR 80,000 higher.

Expected salary increases were taken into account at 2.0% (previous year: 2.0%) and pension increases at 2.0%
(previous year: 2.0%). As in the previous year, no fluctuation was taken into account. Expenses or income
resulting from changes in the discount rate are reported in the financial result.

The assets that serve exclusively to fulfil the pension obligations and are not accessible to all other creditors
(plan assets) are offset against the provisions at their fair value.

The long-term obligations of the foreign companies towards their employees were calculated according to the
country-specific conditions in analogous application of the provisions of commercial law. The corresponding
obligations are reported under other provisions.

**Tax provisions and other provisions are made for all identifiable risks and uncertain liabilities. They are**
recognised at the settlement amount required according to reasonable commercial judgement, taking into
account price and cost increases. Provisions with a remaining term of more than one year are discounted at
the average market interest rate of the past seven financial years corresponding to their remaining term.

**Liabilities are recognised at the settlement amount. Liabilities in foreign currency with a remaining term of**
less than one year are translated at the average spot exchange rate on the balance sheet date. Liabilities in
foreign currencies with a remaining term of more than one year are recognised on the balance sheet date at the
higher of the acquisition cost or the value resulting from the valuation at the average spot exchange rate.

**Derivative financial instruments**

Derivative financial instruments are used to hedge interest rate, foreign exchange and commodity procurement
risks from booked, pending and planned underlying transactions. Hedging is carried out exclusively in the
name and for the account of WEPA Hygieneprodukte GmbH.

The booked and pending underlying transactions can be combined with the hedging transactions within the
framework of micro and portfolio hedging to form German Commercial Code valuation units, separated


-----

**WEPA HYGIENEPRODUKTE GMBH, ARNSBERG**

**CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 2021 (Continued)**

according to commodity, foreign exchange and interest rate hedging instruments. The German Commercial
Code valuation units are valued individually as at the balance sheet date.

The valuation methods and assumptions underlying the determination of the fair value are as follows:

Forward exchange transactions and swaps are valued at the forward rate on the balance sheet date. Options
are valued according to their design using Black-Scholes models or modifications thereof. Instruments to
hedge currency, interest rate and commodity risks are valued by discounting the future cash flows. Discounting
is based on market interest rates over the remaining term of the instruments. The exchange amounts from
these hedging instruments are recognised in profit or loss at the time of payment or accrual on the reporting
date.

According to valuation principles under commercial law, a negative valuation result of the respective hedging
transaction leads to the recognition of a provision for anticipated losses from pending transactions, insofar as
no effective valuation unit was initially formed, while a positive valuation result is not taken into account.

The WEPA Group strives to achieve a balanced risk / opportunity ratio. Therefore, depending on the
assessment of the market situation, the total requirement for currencies or financing volume over the course
of a year is generally hedged in a range between 50% and 90% in order to be able to react to unexpected
developments in interest rates and currencies when calculating prices. In the case of raw materials, purchase
prices are hedged via commodity swaps; here too, depending on the market situation, hedging is aimed for,
which generally ranges from 30% to 90% over the course of a year. The primary objective remains to hedge
the calculation rates on which the planning is based.

The following auditor’s report, prepared in accordance with § 322 HGB [“Handelsgesetzbuch”: “German
Commercial Code”], refers to the complete consolidated financial statements, comprising the consolidated
balance sheet, the consolidated statement of profit and loss, consolidated statement of changes in equity and
consolidated statement of cash flows, together with the group management report of the Wepa
Hygieneprodukte GmbH for the financial year from January 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020. The group
management report is not included in this prospectus. The above-mentioned auditor’s report and consolidated
financial statements are both translations of the respective German-language documents.

**Independent Auditor’s Report**

To Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH, Arnsberg

**Opinions**

We have audited the consolidated financial statements of Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH, Arnsberg and its
subsidiaries (the Group), which comprise the consolidated statement of financial position as at December 31,
2020, the consolidated statement of profit and loss, consolidated statement of changes in equity and
consolidated statement of cash flows for the financial year from January 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020, and
notes to the consolidated financial statements, including the recognition and measurement policies presented
therein. In addition, we have audited the group management report of Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH for the
financial year from January 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020.

In our opinion, on the basis of the knowledge obtained in the audit,

- the accompanying consolidated financial statements comply, in all material respects, with the
requirements of German commercial law and give a true and fair view of the assets, liabilities, and
financial position of the Group as at December 31, 2020, and of its financial performance for the financial
year from January 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020 in compliance with German Legally Required
Accounting Principles, and

- the accompanying group management report as a whole provides an appropriate view of the Group’s
position. In all material respects, this group management report is consistent with the consolidated
financial statements, complies with German legal requirements and appropriately presents the
opportunities and risks of future development.

Pursuant to Section 322 (3) sentence 1 HGB [Handelsgesetzbuch: German Commercial Code], we declare that
our audit has not led to any reservations relating to the legal compliance of the consolidated financial
statements and of the group management report.

**Basis for the Opinions**

We conducted our audit of the consolidated financial statements and of the group management report in
accordance with Section 317 HGB and in compliance with German Generally Accepted Standards for
Financial Statement Audits promulgated by the Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer [Institute of Public Auditors in
Germany] (IDW). Our responsibilities under those requirements and principles are further described in the
“Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and of the Group
Management Report”section of our auditor’s report. We are independent of the group entities in accordance
with the requirements of German commercial and professional law, and we have fulfilled our other German
professional responsibilities in accordance with these requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have
obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinions on the consolidated financial
statements and on the group management report.

**Responsibilities of Management for the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Group Management Report**

Management is responsible for the preparation of the consolidated financial statements that comply, in all
material respects, with the requirements of German commercial law and that the consolidated financial
statements, in compliance with German Legally Required Accounting Principles, give a true and fair view of
the assets, liabilities, financial position, and financial performance of the Group. In addition, management is
responsible for such internal control as they, in accordance with German Legally Required Accounting
Principles, have determined necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are
free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability
to continue as a going concern. They also have the responsibility for disclosing, as applicable, matters related


-----

to going concern. In addition, they are responsible for financial reporting based on the going concern basis of
accounting provided no actual or legal circumstances conflict therewith.

Furthermore, management is responsible for the preparation of the group management report that, as a
whole, provides an appropriate view of the Group’s position and is, in all material respects, consistent with the
consolidated financial statements, complies with German legal requirements, and appropriately presents the
opportunities and risks of future development. In addition, management is responsible for such arrangements
and measures (systems) as they have considered necessary to enable the preparation of a group management
report that is in accordance with the applicable German legal requirements, and to be able to provide sufficient
appropriate evidence for the assertions in the group management report.

**Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and of the Group Management**
**Report**

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a
whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and whether the group management
report as a whole provides an appropriate view of the Group’s position and, in all material respects, is
consistent with the consolidated financial statements and the knowledge obtained in the audit, complies with
the German legal requirements and appropriately presents the opportunities and risks of future development,
as well as to issue an auditor’s report that includes our opinions on the consolidated financial statements and
on the group management report. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee
that an audit conducted in accordance with Section 317 HGB and in compliance with German Generally
Accepted Standards for Financial Statement Audits promulgated by the Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer (IDW)
will always detect a material misstatement. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered
material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic
decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements and this group management
report.

We exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. We also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements and of the
group management report, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive
to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our
opinions. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one
resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations,
or the override of internal controls.

- Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit of the consolidated financial statements
and of arrangements and measures (systems) relevant to the audit of the group management report in
order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of
expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of these systems.

- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used by management and the reasonableness of
estimates made by management and related disclosures.

- Conclude on the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and,
based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions
that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that
a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in the auditor’s report to the related
disclosures in the consolidated financial statements and in the group management report or, if such
disclosures are inadequate, to modify our respective opinions. Our conclusions are based on the audit
evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause
the Group to cease to be able to continue as a going concern.

- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements,
including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements present the underlying
transactions and events in a manner that the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view
of the assets, liabilities, financial position and financial performance of the Group in compliance with
German Legally Required Accounting Principles.

- Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or
business activities within the Group to express [audit] opinions on the consolidated financial statements
and on the group management report. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance
of the group audit. We remain solely responsible for our [audit] opinions.


-----

- Evaluate the consistency of the group management report with the consolidated financial statements, its
conformity with [German] law, and the view of the Group’s position it provides.

- Perform audit procedures on the prospective information presented by management in the group
management report. On the basis of sufficient appropriate audit evidence we evaluate, in particular, the
significant assumptions used by management as a basis for the prospective information, and evaluate the
proper derivation of the prospective information from these assumptions. We do not express a separate
opinion on the prospective information and on the assumptions used as a basis. There is a substantial
unavoidable risk that future events will differ materially from the prospective information.

We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and
timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control
that we identify during our audit.

**Disclosures regarding consolidation methods**

The financial statements of the individual companies are prepared in accordance with uniform accounting
and valuation principles for inclusion in the consolidated financial statements.

Capital consolidation is carried out according to the revaluation method by offsetting the acquisition costs of
the participation against the Group’s share in the revalued equity of the consolidated subsidiaries at the time
of initial consolidation in accordance with § 301 (1) of the German Commercial Code. The recognisable
assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities of the subsidiaries are recognised at their fair values, irrespective of
the amount of the minority interest.

Hidden reserves and charges existing at the time of initial consolidation are disclosed and accounted for in
accordance with the underlying assets and liabilities.

Remaining differences on the assets side (goodwill) are capitalised and depreciated according to schedule
pursuant to § 309 para. 1 in conjunction with § 253 para. 3 sentence 4 of the German Commercial Code over
10 years or, if necessary, written down on an unscheduled basis. Any remaining negative goodwill is treated in
accordance with § 309 para. 2 of the German Commercial Code and German Accounting Standards
4 respectively.

Shares in non-consolidated companies are valued at cost of purchase or at less fair value.

Intercompany profits, sales, expenses and income as well as all receivables and liabilities between the
consolidated companies are eliminated.

The currency conversion of the annual financial statements of the consolidated companies denominated in
foreign currencies is carried out on the basis of § 308a of the German Commercial Code.

Accordingly, in the consolidated financial statements, the assets and liabilities of these companies are
translated at the closing rate, equity items are translated at historical rates, and expenses and income are
translated at the average rate for the year. Resulting translation differences are recognised directly in equity
under the item difference in equity from currency translation. Changes in the exchange rates of intercompany
receivables and liabilities are generally recognised directly in equity as a matter of principle.

**Disclosures on accounting and valuation methods**

The following accounting and valuation methods are authoritative for the preparation of the consolidated
financial statements.

**Intangible assets acquired against payment are capitalised at acquisition cost and, if they are subject to wear**
and tear, reduced by scheduled amortisation in accordance with their useful life.


-----

**WEPA HYGIENEPRODUKTE GMBH, ARNSBERG**

**CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 2020 (Continued)**

The scheduled amortisation of goodwill from capital consolidation is carried out in accordance with
§ 309 Para. 1 in conjunction with § 253 Para. 3 sentence 3 of the German Commercial Code on a straight-line
basis over a period of 10 years. Current developments are taken into account—if necessary—through
unscheduled amortisation.

**Tangible assets are valued at acquisition cost, taking into account scheduled depreciation. In the event of**
permanent impairment, unscheduled depreciation is taken into account. Scheduled depreciation on fixed
assets is exclusively carried out according to the straight-line method. Economic useful lives are used in the
consolidated financial statements instead of the tax useful lives used in the annual financial statement of the
parent company.

**Financial assets are valued at acquisition cost. If the value to be attributed to the financial assets on the**
balance sheet date is permanently impaired, this is recognised.

The valuation of raw materials and supplies as well as merchandise are carried out at acquisition cost in
compliance with the strict principle of low value.

**Unfinished goods are recognised at production cost, which includes direct production and material costs as**
well as an appropriate share of production, material and administrative overheads. Interest on borrowed
capital is not included in the production costs.

**Finished goods are valued according to the retrograde method by deducting the sales and distribution**
overheads still to be incurred as well as the profit margin from the sales price after sales deductions.

**Inventory risks are taken into account by applying appropriate valuation discounts.**

**Receivables and other assets are valued at nominal value or at the lower fair value on the balance sheet date.**
Appropriate individual value adjustments are made for receivables that are at risk due to individual risks; the
general credit risk is taken into account by means of lumpsum deductions. Receivables in foreign currencies
with a remaining term of less than one year are translated at the average spot exchange rate on the balance
sheet date. Receivables in foreign currency with a remaining term of more than one year are recognised at the
lower of cost or the value resulting from the valuation at the average spot exchange rate on the balance sheet
date.

Trade receivables are sold by Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH and various subsidiaries within the framework
of ABS transactions; the credit risk is thereby transferred to the buyer. The trade receivables are reported at a
correspondingly reduced level. The administration of the receivables for the purchasers is carried out by Wepa
Hygieneprodukte GmbH or the respective subsidiary.

The subscribed capital is fully paid in and is shown at nominal value.

The pension provisions for vested rights and current pension obligations are calculated according to the
projected unit credit method using the “2018 G mortality tables” (Generationenrichttafeln) by Professor
Dr. Klaus Heubeck. The calculation was made in accordance with § 253 para. 1 sentence 2 of the German
Commercial Code, § 253 para. 2 of the German Commercial Code.

The average market interest rate of the past 10 financial years with a remaining term of 15 years of 2.32%
(previous year: 2.69%) was used for discounting in accordance with the Ordinance on the Discounting of
Provisions of 18 November 2009. A calculation using the average market interest rate of the past
7 financial years would result in a pension provision that is EUR 105,000 higher.

Expected salary increases were estimated at 2.0% (previous year: 2.0%) and pension increases at 2.0% (previous
year: 2.0%)were taken into account. As in the previous year, no fluctuation was taken into account. Expenses
or income resulting from changes in the discount rate are reported in the financial result.

The assets serving exclusively to fulfil the pension obligations and not accessible to all other creditors (plan
assets) are offset against the provisions at their fair value.

The long-term obligations of the foreign companies towards their employees were calculated according to the
country-specific conditions in analogous application of the provisions of commercial law. The corresponding
obligations are reported under other provisions.

**WEPA HYGIENEPRODUKTE GMBH, ARNSBERG**

**CONSOLIDATED NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 2020 (Continued)**

**Tax provisions and other provisions are made for all identifiable risks and uncertain liabilities. They are**
recognised at the settlement amount required according to reasonable commercial judgement, taking into
account price and cost increases. Provisions with a remaining term of more than one year are discounted at
the average market interest rate corresponding to their remaining term over the past seven financial years.

**Liabilities are recognised at the settlement amount. Liabilities in foreign currency with a remaining term of**
less than one year are translated at the average spot exchange rate on the balance sheet date. Liabilities in
foreign currencies with a remaining term of more than one year are recognised on the balance sheet date at the
higher of the acquisition cost or the value resulting from the valuation at the average spot exchange rate.

For the calculation of deferred taxes due to temporary or quasi-permanent differences between the commercial
law valuations of assets and liabilities and their tax valuations or due to tax loss carryforwards and tax credits,
the amounts of the tax burdens and tax relief expected to arise in the future are valued at the companyspecific tax rates at the time of the expected elimination of the differences and are not discounted.

As at 31 December 2020, deferred tax assets and liabilities from the individual financial statements and from
consolidation measures were netted as in the previous year and the excess was reported as deferred tax
liabilities.

**Derivative financial instruments**

Derivative financial instruments are used to hedge interest rate, foreign exchange and raw material
procurement risks from booked, pending and planned underlying transactions. Hedging is carried out
exclusively in the name and for the account of Wepa Hygieneprodukte GmbH.

The booked and pending underlying transactions can be combined with the hedging transactions in micro
hedge and portfolio hedge German Commercial Code valuation units, separated according to commodity,
foreign exchange and interest rate hedging instruments. The valuation units of the German Commercial Code
are valued individually as at the balance sheet date.

The valuation methods and assumptions underlying the determination of the fair value are as follows:

FX forwards and FX swaps are valued at the forward rate on the balance sheet date. Options are evaluated
according to their design using Black-Scholes models or derived modifications. Instruments to hedge currency,
interest rate and commodity risks are valued by discounting the future cash flows. The discounting is carried
out using the market interest rates at the time of valuation over the remaining term of the instruments. The
amounts exchanged from these hedging instruments are recognised in profit or loss at the time of payment or
accrual on the reporting date.

According to valuation principles under commercial law, a negative valuation result of the respective hedging
transaction leads to the recognition of a provision for anticipated losses from pending transactions, insofar as
no effective valuation unit was initially formed, while a positive valuation result is not taken into account.

The WEPA Group strives to achieve a balanced risk/opportunity ratio. Therefore, depending on the
assessment of the market situation, the total requirement for currencies or financing volume over the course
of a year is generally hedged in a range between 50 % and 90 % in order to be able to adapt the price
calculations in case of unforeseen developments in interest rates and currencies. In the case of raw materials,
purchase prices are hedged via commodity swaps; here too, depending on the market situation, hedging is
aimed for, which generally ranges from 30 % to 90 % over the course of a year. The primary objective remains
to hedge the calculation rates on which the planning is based.
